questions.question: When you cast *Acid Arrow* and the ranged spell attack misses, how much damage does the target take, and does it take any damage at the end of its next turn?
questions.answer: On a miss, the arrow splashes the target for half as much of the initial damage, and the target takes no damage at the end of its next turn.

questions.question: When you cast *Acid Splash*, under what condition can you target two creatures instead of one, and what saving throw do they make on a hit?
questions.answer: You can target two creatures if both are within the spell’s 60-foot range and within 5 feet of each other. Each target must make a Dexterity saving throw or take the spell’s acid damage.

questions.question: For the *Acid Splash* cantrip, what’s its range, and how does its damage scale as you gain levels?
questions.answer: *Acid Splash* has a range of 60 feet. It deals 1d6 acid damage on a failed Dexterity saving throw, increasing by 1d6 at 5th level (2d6), 11th level (3d6), and 17th level (4d6).

questions.question: For the *Acid Splash* cantrip, what components do you need to cast it, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: It requires verbal and somatic components (V, S), and its duration is instantaneous.

questions.question: If a wizard wants to use *Acid Splash* in combat, what’s the spell’s casting time, and which classes have it on their spell list?
questions.answer: *Acid Splash* has a casting time of **1 action**, and it’s on the **Sorcerer** and **Wizard** spell lists.

questions.question: What school of magic is *Acid Splash*, and is it a cantrip or a leveled spell?
questions.answer: *Acid Splash* is a **conjuration cantrip** (i.e., a cantrip in the Conjuration school).

questions.question: For the Aid spell, what’s the range, how many creatures can you target, and how much do their current and maximum hit points increase—and for how long?
questions.answer: Aid has a range of 30 feet. You choose up to three creatures within range; each target’s hit point maximum and current hit points increase by 5 for the spell’s duration, which is 8 hours.

questions.question: To cast *aid*, what components do you need, and what specific material component is required?
questions.answer: *Aid* requires verbal, somatic, and material components (V, S, M). The material component is a tiny strip of white cloth.

questions.question: When you cast Alarm, what are the two alert modes you can choose, and what are their effective distances/effects?
questions.answer: You can choose a **mental** or **audible** alarm. A **mental alarm** gives you a ping in your mind if you are within **1 mile** of the warded area (and it awakens you if you’re sleeping). An **audible alarm** produces the sound of a hand bell for **10 seconds** within **60 feet**.

questions.question: When you cast *Alarm*, what maximum size area (or what objects) can you ward, and what creatures will trigger the alarm if they enter or touch it?
questions.answer: You can ward a door, a window, or an area within range no larger than a 20-foot cube. Until the spell ends, the alarm is triggered when a Tiny or larger creature touches or enters the warded area (except any creatures you designate when casting that won’t set it off).

questions.question: Does the *Alarm* spell have the ritual tag, and what are its casting time and duration?
questions.answer: Yes—*Alarm* is a 1st-level abjuration spell with the ritual tag. Casting Time: 1 minute. Duration: 8 hours.

questions.question: Which classes have access to the *Alarm* spell?
questions.answer: Ranger, Ritual Caster, and Wizard.

questions.question: When casting *Alarm*, what components are required, and what specific material component do you need?
questions.answer: *Alarm* requires verbal, somatic, and material components (V, S, M). The material component is a tiny bell and a piece of fine silver wire.

questions.question: When you use Alter Self to gain Natural Weapons, what damage die do your unarmed strikes use, and do you get any bonus to the attack and damage rolls?
questions.answer: With the Natural Weapons option, your unarmed strikes deal 1d6 bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage (appropriate to the weapon), and the natural weapon is magic; you get a +1 bonus to the attack and damage rolls you make using it.

questions.question: With the Alter Self spell’s Change Appearance option, can you make yourself a different size or change your basic body shape (for example, turn from a biped into a quadruped)?
questions.answer: No. Change Appearance lets you alter cosmetic details and even appear as another race, but you can’t appear as a creature of a different size than you, and your basic shape stays the same (so a biped can’t become quadrupedal).

questions.question: While Alter Self is still active, can you switch from one option (like Aquatic Adaptation) to another, and what action does it take to do so?
questions.answer: Yes. While the spell lasts, you can end your current option as an action to gain the benefits of a different Alter Self option.

questions.question: Does the Alter Self spell require concentration, and how long does it last?
questions.answer: Alter Self does not require concentration (its duration line is just “Up to 1 hour”), and it lasts up to 1 hour.

questions.question: If you cast **Alter Self** and choose **Aquatic Adaptation**, what movement and breathing benefits do you gain for the spell’s duration?
questions.answer: You can breathe underwater, and you gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

questions.question: When you cast **Animal Friendship**, what saving throw does the beast make to resist the spell, and what happens if you or one of your companions harms the target afterward?
questions.answer: The beast must succeed on a **Wisdom saving throw** or be **charmed** by you for the spell’s duration. If you or one of your companions harms the target, **the spell ends**.

questions.question: If I upcast **Animal Friendship** using a 3rd-level spell slot, how many beasts can I affect with the casting?
questions.answer: You can affect **3 beasts** total. The spell affects one beast at 1st level, and when cast with a slot of 2nd level or higher you can affect **one additional beast for each slot level above 1st** (so +2 at 3rd level).

questions.question: Can you use **Animal Friendship** to charm a beast whose Intelligence is 4 or higher (for example, an ape), or does the spell do anything to it?
questions.answer: No. If the beast’s Intelligence is 4 or higher, **Animal Friendship** simply fails and has no effect on that target.

questions.question: For the spell **Animal Friendship**, what components do you need to cast it, and what is the specific material component?
questions.answer: Animal Friendship requires verbal and somatic components, plus a material component: **a morsel of food** (V, S, M).

questions.question: For **Animal Friendship**, what are the line-of-sight and sensory requirements on the target—do you need to see the beast, and does it need to be able to see and hear you?
questions.answer: You choose a beast **that you can see within range**, and the beast **must see and hear you** to be affected.

questions.question: When you cast *Animal Messenger*, how far can the chosen Tiny beast travel during the spell’s duration, and how does that distance differ for a flying messenger versus other animals?
questions.answer: The messenger travels toward the specified location for the spell’s duration, covering about **50 miles per 24 hours** if it’s a **flying** messenger, or about **25 miles per 24 hours** for **other animals**.

questions.question: For *Animal Messenger*, what happens if the Tiny beast doesn’t reach the specified destination before the spell’s duration ends?
questions.answer: If the messenger doesn’t reach its destination before the spell ends, the message is lost, and the beast makes its way back to where you cast the spell.

questions.question: When you cast *Animal Messenger*, what’s the maximum length of the message you can send, and who will the messenger actually speak the message to when it arrives?
questions.answer: You can speak a message of up to twenty-five words. When the messenger arrives, it delivers the message (replicating the sound of your voice) only to a creature that matches the general description you specified.

questions.question: When you cast **Animal Shapes**, what’s the maximum size and challenge rating of the beast form you can turn a willing creature into?
questions.answer: Each target can be transformed into the form of a **Large or smaller** beast with a **challenge rating of 4 or lower**.

questions.question: With **Animal Shapes**, if a transformed creature’s beast form is reduced to 0 hit points, how does the spell handle any excess damage and does the creature fall unconscious when it reverts?
questions.answer: When the beast form drops to 0 hit points and the target reverts, any excess damage carries over to the creature’s normal form. If that excess damage doesn’t reduce the normal form to 0 hit points, the creature isn’t knocked unconscious.

questions.question: When you transform allies with **Animal Shapes**, what happens to their worn or carried gear—can they still wield or gain benefits from their equipment while in beast form?
questions.answer: The target’s gear melds into the new form, and the creature can’t activate, wield, or otherwise benefit from any of its equipment while transformed.

questions.question: With **Animal Shapes** active, can you change an affected creature into a different beast form after the initial casting, and what does it cost you to do so?
questions.answer: Yes. On subsequent turns, you can use your **action** to transform affected creatures into new forms.

questions.question: When you cast **Animal Shapes**, what are the spell’s targeting requirements—how many creatures can you affect, do they have to be willing, do you need to see them, and what’s the range?
questions.answer: You choose **any number of willing creatures** that you **can see** **within 30 feet** of you.

questions.question: When you use Animate Dead, what action does it take to command your undead on your turn, and how close do you need to be to issue that command?
questions.answer: On each of your turns you use a bonus action to mentally command any creature you made with Animate Dead, and the undead must be within 60 feet of you to receive the command.

questions.question: If my 24-hour control over Animate Dead undead is about to expire, how many undead can I reassert control over with a recast, and how does that number increase when using a 4th-level or higher spell slot?
questions.answer: Recasting Animate Dead on an existing undead before the 24-hour period ends reasserts your control over up to four creatures you animated with the spell (instead of creating a new one). If you use a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you can animate or reassert control over two additional undead for each slot level above 3rd (each from a different corpse or pile of bones).

questions.question: When you cast **Animate Dead**, what kind of remains are valid targets, and what undead do you create if you choose a pile of bones versus a corpse?
questions.answer: You must target **a pile of bones or a corpse of a Medium or Small humanoid** within range. The target becomes a **skeleton** if you chose bones, or a **zombie** if you chose a corpse.

questions.question: When you cast **Animate Dead**, what specific material components do you need for the spell’s M component?
questions.answer: It requires material components of **a drop of blood, a piece of flesh, and a pinch of bone dust** (along with V and S components).

questions.question: Does **Animate Dead** require concentration, and what is the spell’s duration?
questions.answer: No. Animate Dead does not require concentration; its duration is **Instantaneous**.

questions.question: When you cast *Animate Objects*, how far away can you be and still mentally command the animated creatures with your bonus action?
questions.answer: You can mentally command any creature you animated with the spell as a bonus action as long as the creature is within 500 feet of you.

questions.question: With *animate objects*, if one of the animated objects is reduced to 0 hit points, what happens to it—and does any leftover damage carry over to the original object?
questions.answer: When an animated object drops to 0 hit points, it reverts to its original object form, and any remaining (excess) damage carries over to that original object form.

questions.question: If you cast *Animate Objects* using a 7th-level spell slot, how many objects can you animate total?
questions.answer: You can animate 14 objects total. The spell animates up to ten objects normally, and when cast with a 6th-level slot or higher you animate two additional objects per slot level above 5th (so +4 at 7th level).

questions.question: When you cast *Animate Objects* on something that has no legs or appendages for locomotion, what movement does the animated object have?
questions.answer: Its speed is 30 feet, but if the object lacks legs or other appendages it can use for locomotion, it instead has a flying speed of 30 feet and can hover.

questions.question: When you use *Animate Objects* to animate a Large object, what AC and hit points does it have, and what is its slam attack bonus and damage?
questions.answer: A Large animated object has AC 10 and 50 hit points, and it makes a slam attack at +6 to hit that deals 2d10 + 2 bludgeoning damage.

questions.question: If a caster drops an *antimagic field*, can another character use *dispel magic* (or a similar effect) to get rid of the field—and do overlapping *antimagic field* spheres cancel each other out?
questions.answer: No. Spells and magical effects such as *dispel magic* have no effect on an *antimagic field*. Likewise, spheres created by different *antimagic field* spells don’t nullify each other.

questions.question: In *antimagic field*, what happens to a magic weapon or piece of magic ammunition if it’s used to attack a target inside the antimagic sphere—and when does it regain its magic if it leaves the sphere?
questions.answer: The properties and powers of magic items are suppressed inside the antimagic sphere. A magic weapon’s properties and powers are suppressed if it is used against a target in the sphere or wielded by an attacker in the sphere. If a magic weapon or piece of magic ammunition fully leaves the sphere (for example, a fired magic arrow or thrown magic spear at a target outside the sphere), its magic stops being suppressed as soon as it exits.

questions.question: If an antimagic field is centered on you, can a creature use teleportation/planar travel to enter or leave the sphere, and what happens to portals or extradimensional entrances (like a rope trick opening) that fall within the field?
questions.answer: No. Teleportation and planar travel fail to work in the antimagic field, whether the sphere is the destination or the departure point. Any portal to another location/world/plane, and any opening to an extradimensional space (such as from rope trick), temporarily closes while it is within the sphere.

questions.question: If an *antimagic field* overlaps an ongoing area spell like *wall of fire*, what happens to the part of the spell’s area inside the antimagic sphere?
questions.answer: An area of another spell or magical effect can’t extend into the antimagic sphere. If the antimagic field overlaps an area of magic, the portion of that area covered by the sphere is suppressed (for example, *wall of fire*’s flames are suppressed within the sphere, potentially creating a gap in the wall).

questions.question: If you try to cast a spell while inside an *antimagic field* and the spell is suppressed, do you still expend the spell slot—and does the spell’s duration keep running while it’s suppressed?
questions.answer: Yes. A slot expended to cast a suppressed spell is still consumed, and while the effect is suppressed it doesn’t function but the time it spends suppressed counts against its duration.

questions.question: For Antipathy/Sympathy, what saving throw do affected creatures make when they first come within 60 feet of (or can see) the target, and what condition or forced movement happens on a failed save for each version?
questions.answer:
When a designated creature can see the target or comes within 60 feet of it, it makes a Wisdom saving throw.
- Antipathy: On a failed save, it becomes frightened and must use its movement to move to the nearest safe spot from which it can’t see the target (remaining frightened while it can see the target or is within 60 feet).
- Sympathy: On a failed save, it must use its movement on each of its turns to enter the area or move within reach of the target; once it has done so, it can’t willingly move away from the target.

questions.question: For *Antipathy/Sympathy*, how can an affected creature end the spell’s effect on itself, and how often does it get additional saving throws while the spell lasts (including any temporary immunity after a successful save)?
questions.answer: If an affected creature ends its turn while it’s neither within 60 feet of the target nor able to see it, it makes a Wisdom saving throw; on a success it’s no longer affected and recognizes the feeling as magical. It also gets another Wisdom saving throw every 24 hours while the spell persists. A creature that successfully saves is immune to the effect for 1 minute, after which it can be affected again.

questions.question: For the spell *Antipathy/Sympathy*, what kinds of targets are valid, and what’s the largest area you can choose if you target an area instead of a creature or object?
questions.answer: You choose a target within 60 feet that is either (a) a Huge or smaller object, (b) a Huge or smaller creature, or (c) an area no larger than a 200-foot cube.

questions.question: When casting *Antipathy/Sympathy*, what material component do you need for the antipathy version versus the sympathy version?
questions.answer: The spell’s material component is either **a lump of alum soaked in vinegar** (for the **antipathy** effect) or **a drop of honey** (for the **sympathy** effect).

questions.question: For the spell *Antipathy/Sympathy*, what’s its duration, and does it require concentration?
questions.answer: *Antipathy/Sympathy* lasts **10 days** and **does not require concentration** (its duration is listed simply as “10 days,” not “Concentration, up to …”).

questions.question: For the spell *Arcane Eye*, how far can you move the eye each turn, and can it pass through tiny openings or cross into other planes?
questions.answer: You can move the eye up to 30 feet in any direction as an action. It can pass through an opening as small as 1 inch in diameter, but it can’t enter another plane of existence (and solid barriers block its movement).

questions.question: When you cast *Arcane Eye*, what kind of vision does the magical eye have, and how far does its darkvision extend?
questions.answer: The eye has normal vision and darkvision out to 30 feet.

questions.question: When you cast *Arcane Eye* in play, what’s its casting time, what material component does it require, and how long does the spell last?
questions.answer: *Arcane Eye* has a casting time of **1 action**, requires **V, S, M** with the material component **a bit of bat fur**, and its duration is **up to 1 hour**.

questions.question: If you cast *Arcane Eye* to scout, can other creatures see the eye you create (i.e., is it visible or invisible)?
questions.answer: The spell creates an **invisible** magical eye within range that hovers in the air for the duration.

questions.question: When you cast *Arcane Eye* to scout, does the eye have to face a direction, or can it see all around—and how do you perceive what it sees?
questions.answer: The arcane eye "can look in every direction," and you "mentally receive visual information from the eye."

questions.question: When you cast *Arcane Hand*, how far can you move the hand on your turn, and what action is required to command it after the turn you cast the spell?
questions.answer: On the turn you cast it and as a bonus action on your subsequent turns, you can move the hand up to 60 feet and then have it perform one of its listed effects.

questions.question: When you use Arcane Hand’s Interposing Hand option, what benefit does it give you against the chosen creature, and under what Strength condition can that creature move through the hand’s space (and with what movement penalty if it can)?
questions.answer: Interposing Hand positions itself between you and the chosen creature and gives you half cover against that creature. The creature can’t move through the hand’s space if its Strength score is less than or equal to the hand’s Strength score; if its Strength score is higher, it can move through, but that space is difficult terrain for it.

questions.question: When you use Arcane Hand’s Forceful Hand option, what rolls are made to resolve the push, and how far can the hand push the target on a success (including the size-based advantage clause)?
questions.answer: To use Forceful Hand, you make a Strength check using the hand contested by the target’s Strength (Athletics) check. If the target is Medium or smaller, you have advantage on the check. On a success, the hand pushes the target up to 5 feet + a number of feet equal to five times your spellcasting ability modifier, and the hand moves with the target to stay within 5 feet of it.

questions.question: When Arcane Hand uses its Grasping Hand option and then crushes a grappled target, what action do you take to crush it, and how much damage does the crush deal?
questions.answer: While the hand is grappling a target, you can use a bonus action to have the hand crush it; the target takes bludgeoning damage equal to 2d6 + your spellcasting ability modifier.

questions.question: When you cast Arcane Hand, what are the hand’s Armor Class and hit points, and what happens to the spell if the hand drops to 0 hit points?
questions.answer: The hand is an object with AC 20 and hit points equal to your hit point maximum. If it drops to 0 hit points, the spell ends.

questions.question: If someone casts **knock** on an entryway sealed with **arcane lock**, how long is the arcane lock suppressed?
questions.answer: Casting *knock* on the object suppresses *arcane lock* for **10 minutes**.

questions.question: When an entryway is protected by **arcane lock**, how much does it increase the DC to break it open or pick its lock?
questions.answer: While affected by **arcane lock**, the DC to break the object or pick any locks on it increases by **10**.

questions.question: For **arcane lock**, if the caster sets a password, how close does someone need to be when speaking it, and how long does the spell get suppressed?
questions.answer: The password must be spoken within 5 feet of the object, and it suppresses *arcane lock* for 1 minute.

questions.question: When casting **arcane lock**, what material component do you need, what’s its minimum value, and is it consumed by the spell?
questions.answer: Arcane lock requires **gold dust worth at least 25 gp** as its material component, and the spell **consumes** the gold dust.

questions.question: When you cast **arcane lock** on a door or similar entryway, who can still open the object normally while the spell lasts?
questions.answer: The caster and any creatures the caster designates when casting the spell can open the locked object normally.

questions.question: When you cast **Arcane Sword**, what’s its casting range, and on subsequent turns how far can you move the sword and what attack/damage does it make?
questions.answer: Arcane Sword has a **range of 60 feet**. When it appears (and again on later turns as a **bonus action**), you can **move the sword up to 20 feet** to a spot you can see and make a **melee spell attack** against a target **within 5 feet of the sword**; on a hit it deals **3d10 force damage**.

questions.question: When casting **Arcane Sword**, what specific material component do you need, and how much must it be worth?
questions.answer: Arcane Sword requires a material component: **a miniature platinum sword with a grip and pommel of copper and zinc, worth 250 gp** (in addition to the V and S components).

questions.question: For **Arcane Sword**, which classes can cast the spell, and what’s its duration?
questions.answer: Arcane Sword is available to **Bards and Wizards**, and its duration is **up to 1 minute**.

questions.question: With **Arcane Sword**, when you use your bonus action on later turns to move the sword and repeat the attack, can you choose a different target than the one you attacked before (and how close does that target need to be to the sword)?
questions.answer: Yes. Until the spell ends, you can use a bonus action each turn to move the sword up to 20 feet and repeat the melee spell attack against the same target or a different one, as long as the target is within 5 feet of the sword.

questions.question: Does **Arcane Sword** require concentration to maintain once it’s cast?
questions.answer: No. The spell’s duration is listed as “Up to 1 minute” with no concentration requirement.

questions.question: For *Arcanist’s Magic Aura*, how long does the illusion last normally, and what do you have to do to make it last until it’s dispelled?
questions.answer: Normally the spell lasts 24 hours. If you cast it on the same creature or object every day for 30 days, applying the same effect each time, the illusion then lasts until it is dispelled.

questions.question: For *Arcanist’s Magic Aura*, what are the valid targets—can you cast it on an unwilling creature or on an object that’s being carried or worn?
questions.answer: You can target only a **willing creature** or an **object that isn’t being carried or worn by another creature**—so you can’t cast it on an unwilling creature, and you can’t cast it on an object currently carried or worn.

questions.question: When you use *Arcanist’s Magic Aura*’s **False Aura** option on an object, what changes can you make to how it reads to effects like *detect magic*, and can the fake aura be noticeable to someone who handles the item?
questions.answer: With **False Aura**, you can make a nonmagical object appear magical, make a magical object appear nonmagical, or change the object’s magical aura so it appears to belong to a specific school of magic you choose. If you use this effect on an object, you can also make the false magic apparent to any creature that handles the item.

questions.question: When you cast *Arcanist’s Magic Aura* using the **Mask** option, what kinds of detection does it fool, and what do you choose to make the target register as?
questions.answer: The Mask effect changes how the target appears to spells and magical effects that detect creature types (for example, a paladin’s Divine Sense or the trigger condition of a *symbol* spell). You choose a creature type, and those spells/effects treat the target as if it were a creature of that type or of that alignment.

questions.question: During play, what are the casting time, range, and material component required to cast *Arcanist’s Magic Aura*?
questions.answer: *Arcanist’s Magic Aura* has a casting time of 1 action, a range of Touch, and requires V, S, M components with a material component of a small square of silk.

questions.question: With the Astral Projection spell, what events can end the spell early for a creature, and what happens if the caster is returned to their body prematurely while companions are still projecting?
questions.answer: Astral Projection can end early for a creature if a successful dispel magic is used against that creature’s astral or physical body, or if the creature’s original body or its astral form drops to 0 hit points. If the caster is returned to their body prematurely, their companions remain in their astral forms and must find their own way back to their bodies—usually by dropping to 0 hit points.

questions.question: For the Astral Projection spell, what material components are required per creature affected, what are they worth, and are they consumed by the spell?
questions.answer: For each creature affected, you must provide one jacinth worth at least 1,000 gp and one ornately carved bar of silver worth at least 100 gp, and the spell consumes these material components.

questions.question: When you cast **Astral Projection**, what state is your physical body left in, and does it need food/air or continue aging while you're projecting?
questions.answer: Your material body is left behind **unconscious and in a state of suspended animation**; while in that state it **doesn't need food or air and doesn't age**.

questions.question: When you cast **Astral Projection**, how many willing creatures can you bring with you, and what happens if you cast the spell while you’re already on the Astral Plane?
questions.answer: You can project yourself and up to eight willing creatures within range. If you are already on the Astral Plane when you cast it, the spell fails and the casting is wasted.

questions.question: In **Astral Projection**, how long is the caster’s silvery cord visible before it fades, and what happens if the cord is cut?
questions.answer: The silvery cord extends from between your shoulder blades and trails behind you, **fading to invisibility after 1 foot**. If the cord is cut (only by an effect that specifically says it can), **your soul and body are separated and you die instantly**.

questions.question: If I cast **Augury** more than once before I finish my next long rest, what are the odds that the spell gives a random reading instead of a true omen?
questions.answer: If you cast Augury two or more times before completing your next long rest, there is a cumulative **25 percent** chance for **each casting after the first** that you get a random reading (the DM rolls in secret).

questions.question: For the **Augury** spell, what material component do you need, and what’s the minimum value it must be worth?
questions.answer: Augury requires specially marked sticks, bones, or similar tokens as a material component, worth at least **25 gp**.

questions.question: When you cast **Augury**, how far into the future can the spell predict outcomes for your planned course of action, and what possible omens can the DM give you?
questions.answer: Augury gives an omen about the results of a specific course of action you plan to take **within the next 30 minutes**. The DM chooses one of four omens: **Weal** (good results), **Woe** (bad results), **Weal and woe** (both good and bad), or **Nothing** (results that aren’t especially good or bad).

questions.question: If I cast **Augury** and then change my plans (like casting additional spells or gaining/losing a companion), does the omen account for those new circumstances?
questions.answer: No. Augury “doesn't take into account any possible circumstances that might change the outcome,” such as casting additional spells or the loss or gain of a companion.

questions.question: During play, how long does **Augury** take to cast, what’s its range, and how long does its effect last (duration)?
questions.answer: **Casting Time:** 1 minute; **Range:** Self; **Duration:** Instantaneous.

questions.question: When you cast **Awaken**, how long is the awakened beast or plant charmed by you, and what ends that charm early?
questions.answer: The awakened creature is charmed by you for **30 days**, or until **you or your companions do anything harmful to it**, which ends the charm early.

questions.question: For the spell **Awaken**, what material component is required, what minimum value must it have, and is it consumed by the spell?
questions.answer: Awaken requires an agate worth at least 1,000 gp as its material component, and the spell consumes the agate.

questions.question: When casting **Awaken**, what kinds of creatures can you target (including size), and what Intelligence requirement must the target meet?
questions.answer: You can target a **Huge or smaller beast or plant** that has **no Intelligence score or an Intelligence of 3 or less**.

questions.question: For the spell **Awaken**, what is the casting time and range?
questions.answer: **Casting Time:** 8 hours; **Range:** Touch.

questions.question: If you use **Awaken** on a plant, what new capabilities does the awakened plant gain beyond increased Intelligence?
questions.answer: An awakened plant gains the ability to move its limbs, roots, vines, creepers, and so forth, and it gains senses similar to a human’s (in addition to gaining Intelligence 10 and the ability to speak one language you know).

questions.question: When you cast **Bane**, what is the spell’s range, what saving throw do the targets make, and what penalty die is applied if they fail?
questions.answer: Bane has a range of **30 feet**. Up to three creatures you can see within range make a **Charisma saving throw**. On a failed save, whenever the target makes an **attack roll or a saving throw** before the spell ends, it rolls a **d4 and subtracts** the number rolled from the roll (for up to 1 minute).

questions.question: If you cast **Bane** using a 3rd-level spell slot, how many creatures can you target?
questions.answer: Bane normally targets up to three creatures. When cast with a 3rd-level slot, it can target two additional creatures (one per slot level above 1st), for a total of **up to five creatures**.

questions.question: For the **Bane** spell, what components do you need to cast it, and what is the specific material component?
questions.answer: Bane requires **verbal, somatic, and material** components (V, S, M). The material component is **a drop of blood**.

questions.question: During combat, if you want to cast **Bane**, what’s the spell’s casting time and how long does it last?
questions.answer: Bane has a casting time of **1 action** and a duration of **up to 1 minute**.

questions.question: When you cast **Bane**, do you need to be able to see the creatures you’re targeting, and how many can you choose at base level?
questions.answer: Yes—Bane targets "up to three creatures of your choice that you can see within range."

questions.question: When you upcast *Banishment*, how does the number of creatures you can target change with a higher-level spell slot?
questions.answer: If you cast *Banishment* using a 5th-level spell slot or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 4th.

questions.question: For the *Banishment* spell, what saving throw does the target make, and what happens to a creature that’s not native to your current plane if you keep the spell going for the full duration?
questions.answer: The target makes a Charisma saving throw. If the target is native to a different plane than the one you’re on and the spell lasts the full 1 minute, it is banished back to its home plane and doesn’t return.

questions.question: When you successfully cast *Banishment* on a creature that’s native to your current plane, where does it go and what condition is it in until the spell ends?
questions.answer: A creature native to your current plane is banished to a harmless demiplane, where it is incapacitated until the spell ends (then it reappears where it left, or the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied).

questions.question: When casting *Banishment*, what material component do you need to provide?
questions.answer: The material component is **an item distasteful to the target** (components: V, S, M).

questions.question: For the *Banishment* spell, what are its casting time and range?
questions.answer: Casting Time: 1 action. Range: 60 feet.

questions.question: When you cast *Barkskin* on a willing creature, what is the minimum AC the target can have for the spell’s duration, regardless of what armor it’s wearing?
questions.answer: For the duration, the target’s AC can’t be less than 16, regardless of what kind of armor it is wearing.

questions.question: What material component is required to cast *Barkskin*?
questions.answer: A handful of oak bark.

questions.question: In play, how long does it take to cast *Barkskin*, and what’s its range?
questions.answer: *Barkskin* has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **Touch**.

questions.question: Which character classes have access to the *Barkskin* spell?
questions.answer: Cleric, Druid, and Ranger.

questions.question: When casting *Barkskin*, does the target have to be a willing creature, or can you cast it on an unwilling target?
questions.answer: The target must be a willing creature; you touch a willing creature to cast *Barkskin*.

questions.question: When you cast Beacon of Hope, what saving throws do the affected creatures have advantage on, and how does it change the amount of hit points they regain from healing?
questions.answer: For the duration, each target has advantage on Wisdom saving throws and death saving throws, and it regains the maximum number of hit points possible from any healing.

questions.question: During play, if you need to cast Beacon of Hope quickly, what are the spell’s casting time, range, and duration?
questions.answer: Beacon of Hope has a casting time of 1 action, a range of 30 feet, and a duration of up to 1 minute.

questions.question: In the middle of combat, which classes can cast **Beacon of Hope**, and what components do you need to provide to cast it?
questions.answer: Beacon of Hope is available to **Clerics and Paladins**, and it requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**.

questions.question: When you cast **Beacon of Hope**, how many creatures can you target, and what’s the targeting limitation?
questions.answer: You can choose **any number of creatures within range** (30 feet).

questions.question: If you’re deciding whether Beacon of Hope can be cast from a 3rd-level slot or higher (and for spell-school interactions like Counterspell or Abjuration features), what level and school is Beacon of Hope?
questions.answer: Beacon of Hope is a 3rd-level Abjuration spell.

questions.question: If I upcast Bestow Curse, at what spell-slot level does it stop requiring concentration, and how long does the curse last at that level?
questions.answer: Using a 5th-level spell slot or higher grants a duration that doesn’t require concentration; at 5th level the curse lasts 8 hours.

questions.question: For *Bestow Curse*, if you choose the option that makes your attacks and spells hurt the target more, what extra damage does it deal (die and damage type), and how can that effect be ended?
questions.answer: While the target is cursed, your attacks and spells deal an extra **1d8 necrotic damage** to it, and a **remove curse** spell ends this effect.

questions.question: For *Bestow Curse*, if you choose the curse that can make the target lose its action each turn, when does the target make the saving throw and what happens if it fails?
questions.answer: If the target fails the initial Wisdom save and you choose that option, it must make a Wisdom saving throw at the start of each of its turns; on a failed save, it wastes its action that turn doing nothing.

questions.question: With *Bestow Curse*, if you pick the option to curse one ability score, what exact penalties does the target suffer while the spell lasts?
questions.answer: You choose one ability score; while cursed, the target has disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws made with that ability score.

questions.question: When you cast *Bestow Curse*, what saving throw does the target make when you touch it, and what happens if it succeeds?
questions.answer: The creature makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a success, it isn’t cursed (the spell has no effect).

questions.question: In Black Tentacles, if a creature gets restrained by the tentacles, how can it try to break free on later turns, and what kind of roll does it make?
questions.answer: A creature restrained by the tentacles can use its action to make a Strength or Dexterity check (its choice) against your spell save DC; on a success, it frees itself.

questions.question: For the Black Tentacles spell, what size area does it create, and what happens (save and damage) when a creature first enters the area or starts its turn there?
questions.answer: Black Tentacles fills a 20-foot square on the ground within range. When a creature enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must make a Dexterity saving throw; on a failure it takes 3d6 bludgeoning damage and is restrained by the tentacles until the spell ends.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast Black Tentacles?
questions.answer: A piece of tentacle from a giant octopus or a giant squid.

questions.question: When you cast Black Tentacles, what are its casting time and range?
questions.answer: Black Tentacles has a casting time of 1 action and a range of 90 feet.

questions.question: While Black Tentacles is active, what does it do to the ground in the affected area (terrain-wise)?
questions.answer: For the duration, the tentacles turn the ground in the spell’s 20-foot-square area into difficult terrain.

questions.question: For the Blade Barrier spell, what saving throw does a creature make when it enters the wall or starts its turn there, and how much damage does it take on a failed save (and on a successful save)?
questions.answer: A creature must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save it takes 6d10 slashing damage; on a successful save it takes half as much damage.

questions.question: When you cast *blade barrier*, what shapes can you form the wall into and what are the maximum dimensions for each option?
questions.answer: You can form it as either (1) a straight wall up to 100 feet long, 20 feet high, and 5 feet thick, or (2) a ringed wall up to 60 feet in diameter, 20 feet high, and 5 feet thick.

questions.question: When you create a *blade barrier*, what kind of cover does the wall grant to creatures behind it, and how does it affect movement through the wall’s space?
questions.answer: The wall provides three-quarters cover to creatures behind it, and the wall’s space is difficult terrain.

questions.question: When casting *blade barrier*, what are the spell’s casting time, range, and components?
questions.answer: *Blade barrier* has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **90 feet**, and requires **V, S** components.

questions.question: When I cast *Bless*, how many creatures can I target, and what die do they add to attack rolls and saving throws while the spell lasts?
questions.answer: You can bless up to three creatures within 30 feet, and each target can roll a d4 and add it to an attack roll or saving throw made before the spell ends.

questions.question: When I cast *Bless*, what’s its range, and what material component do I need to provide?
questions.answer: *Bless* has a range of 30 feet, and its material component is a sprinkling of holy water (components: V, S, M).

questions.question: When you cast *Blight* on a plant creature or magical plant, does it get any special saving throw treatment and how much damage does the spell deal if it fails?
questions.answer: A plant creature or magical plant makes its Constitution saving throw with disadvantage, and if it fails the spell deals maximum damage (i.e., maximum on the 8d8 necrotic damage).

questions.question: For the Blindness/Deafness spell, what saving throw does the target make, and when can it retry the save to end the effect?
questions.answer: The target makes a Constitution saving throw when the spell is cast. If it fails, it is blinded or deafened (caster’s choice) for up to 1 minute, and at the end of each of its turns it can make another Constitution saving throw; on a success, the spell ends.

questions.question: If I cast Blindness/Deafness using a higher-level spell slot, how does the number of targets scale?
questions.answer: When cast with a 3rd-level slot or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 2nd (so +1 target per level above 2nd).

questions.question: Does Blindness/Deafness require concentration, and how long does its effect last if the target keeps failing its saves?
questions.answer: No—Blindness/Deafness does not require concentration. Its duration is 1 minute (though the target can end it early by succeeding on a Constitution saving throw at the end of its turns).

questions.question: During play, if I want to cast **Blindness/Deafness**, what are its casting time and range?
questions.answer: Blindness/Deafness has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **30 feet**.

questions.question: When I cast **Blindness/Deafness**, what spell components are required (verbal, somatic, and/or material)?
questions.answer: It requires only a **verbal** component (V); it has no somatic (S) or material (M) components.

questions.question: When you cast *Blink*, what check do you make each turn to see if you shift to the Ethereal Plane, and where can you reappear when you return?
questions.answer: At the end of each of your turns, you roll a d20; on an 11 or higher you vanish to the Ethereal Plane. At the start of your next turn (and when the spell ends if you’re still ethereal), you return to an unoccupied space you can see within 10 feet of the space you vanished from; if none is available, you appear in the nearest unoccupied space (randomly chosen if there’s a tie).

questions.question: While you’re under the effects of *blink* and you shift into the Ethereal Plane, what can you see/hear from your original plane, and can creatures on your original plane perceive or interact with you?
questions.answer: While on the Ethereal Plane, you can see and hear the plane you originated from, but it’s cast in shades of gray and you can’t see anything there more than 60 feet away. You can only affect and be affected by other creatures on the Ethereal Plane—creatures that aren’t there can’t perceive or interact with you unless they have a special ability to do so.

questions.question: When a character has Blur active, under what circumstances does an attacker *not* suffer disadvantage on attack rolls against them?
questions.answer: Attackers are immune to Blur’s disadvantage if they don’t rely on sight (for example, if they have blindsight) or if they can see through illusions (for example, with truesight).

questions.question: In play, if you want to cast *blur*, what’s its casting time and which classes have it on their spell list?
questions.answer: *Blur* has a casting time of **1 action**, and it’s available to the **Druid, Sorcerer, and Wizard** classes.

questions.question: During a fight, if you want to cast *blur*, what’s its range and which spell components does it require?
questions.answer: *Blur* has a range of **Self** and requires only a **verbal (V)** component.

questions.question: In the middle of combat, what spell level and school is **blur**, and how long does it last once cast?
questions.answer: *Blur* is a **2nd-level Illusion** spell, and its duration is **up to 1 minute**.

questions.question: When you land your next weapon hit while Branding Smite is active, what extra damage does it deal and what does it do to a target's invisibility (including the light it sheds)?
questions.answer: The next time you hit with a weapon attack before the spell ends, the attack deals an extra 2d6 radiant damage. The target becomes visible if it’s invisible, sheds dim light in a 5-foot radius, and can’t become invisible until the spell ends.

questions.question: In play, what are Branding Smite’s casting time, range, components, and duration?
questions.answer: Branding Smite has a casting time of 1 bonus action, a range of Self, components V, and a duration of up to 1 minute.

questions.question: If a paladin casts Branding Smite using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, how does the spell’s extra radiant damage on the next weapon hit scale with slot level?
questions.answer: When cast with a 3rd-level or higher slot, the extra damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 2nd (base extra damage is 2d6 radiant).

questions.question: Which class can prepare/cast the spell Branding Smite (i.e., what class’s spell list is it on in the SRD)?
questions.answer: Branding Smite is on the Paladin spell list (Classes: Paladin).

questions.question: When you cast *Burning Hands*, what area does it affect, what saving throw do targets make, and how much damage do they take on a failed vs. successful save?
questions.answer: *Burning Hands* affects creatures in a **15-foot cone** originating from you. Each creature in the cone makes a **Dexterity saving throw**. A creature takes **3d6 fire damage** on a failed save, or **half as much** on a successful one.

questions.question: If you cast *Burning Hands* using a spell slot higher than 1st level, how does the spell’s damage scale with the slot level?
questions.answer: *Burning Hands* deals 3d6 fire damage at 1st level, and when cast with a 2nd-level or higher slot, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 1st.

questions.question: When you cast *Burning Hands*, does it ignite objects in the affected area, and if so, which objects are set on fire?
questions.answer: Yes. The fire ignites any flammable objects in the area that aren’t being worn or carried.

questions.question: When casting *Burning Hands*, what is its casting time, what range does it have, and which components are required?
questions.answer: *Burning Hands* has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **Self** (it projects a **15-foot cone** from you), and requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**.

questions.question: Which classes can cast *Burning Hands* (i.e., have it on their spell list)?
questions.answer: *Burning Hands* is available to Cleric, Sorcerer, Warlock, and Wizard.

questions.question: For *Call Lightning*, what saving throw do creatures make, and what’s the spell’s damage on a failed save (including the effect if you cast it outdoors in stormy conditions)?
questions.answer: Creatures within 5 feet of the targeted point make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save they take 3d10 lightning damage; if you cast the spell outdoors in stormy conditions, the damage increases by 1d10 (to 4d10 on a failed save).

questions.question: For the *Call Lightning* spell, where exactly does the storm cloud appear relative to the caster, and when does the spell fail because there isn’t enough open space/line of sight for the cloud?
questions.answer: A storm cloud appears as a cylinder 10 feet tall with a 60-foot radius, centered on a point you can see 100 feet directly above you. The spell fails if you can’t see a point in the air where the storm cloud could appear—for example, if you’re in a room that can’t accommodate the cloud.

questions.question: After you cast *Call Lightning*, what do you have to do on later turns to strike again, and can you choose a different target point each time?
questions.answer: On each of your turns until the spell ends, you can use your action to call down lightning again, and you can target the same point or a different point you can see within range.

questions.question: If a cleric wants to cast *Call Lightning* during a fight, what’s the spell’s casting time, range, and required components?
questions.answer: *Call Lightning* has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **120 feet**, and requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**.

questions.question: If I cast *Call Lightning* using a higher-level spell slot, how does the lightning bolt’s damage scale with slot level?
questions.answer: When you cast *Call Lightning* using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d10 for each slot level above 3rd.

questions.question: For *Calm Emotions*, what’s the spell’s area of effect and what saving throw do affected creatures make (including any special option they have with that save)?
questions.answer: It affects each humanoid in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point you choose within 60 feet. Each affected creature makes a Charisma saving throw, and a creature can choose to fail the saving throw if it wishes.

questions.question: When you use *Calm Emotions* to make a hostile humanoid indifferent, what causes that indifference to end early, and what happens when the spell ends?
questions.answer: The indifference ends early if the target is attacked or harmed by a spell, or if it witnesses any of its friends being harmed. When the spell ends, the creature becomes hostile again, unless the DM rules otherwise.

questions.question: When you cast **Chain Lightning**, what saving throw does each target make, and how much damage does it take on a failed save versus a successful one?
questions.answer: Each target makes a **Dexterity saving throw**. It takes **10d8 lightning damage** on a failed save, or **half as much** damage on a successful save.

questions.question: When you cast **Chain Lightning**, how many creatures or objects can it potentially strike, and how close do the secondary targets need to be to the first target?
questions.answer: Chain Lightning can strike one primary target you can see within 150 feet, and then up to three additional targets. Each additional target must be within 30 feet of the first target, and no target can be hit by more than one bolt.

questions.question: What material components do you need to cast *Chain Lightning*?
questions.answer: It requires the following material components: a bit of fur; a piece of amber, glass, or a crystal rod; and three silver pins.

questions.question: If you upcast **Chain Lightning** using an 8th-level spell slot, how many additional bolts leap from the first target compared to casting it at 6th level?
questions.answer: One additional bolt leaps from the first target for each slot level above 6th. So at 8th level (two levels above 6th), you get **2 additional bolts** compared to casting it at 6th level.

questions.question: In play, how long does it take to cast **Chain Lightning**, how far away can you target the first creature/object, and how long does the spell last?
questions.answer: **Chain Lightning** has a **casting time of 1 action**, a **range of 150 feet** for the initial target, and a **duration of instantaneous**.

questions.question: When you cast *charm person*, when does the target get advantage on its Wisdom saving throw, and does it realize it was magically charmed after the spell ends?
questions.answer: The target makes the Wisdom saving throw with advantage if you or your companions are fighting it. When the spell ends, the creature knows it was charmed by you.

questions.question: When you upcast *charm person*, how many additional creatures can you target, and what positioning restriction applies to those targets?
questions.answer: If you cast *charm person* using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 1st, and the creatures must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them.

questions.question: During play, what can cause *charm person* to end early on a creature (before the 1-hour duration is up)?
questions.answer: The charm lasts until the spell ends **or** until you or your companions do anything harmful to the target—doing something harmful ends the spell’s effect early.

questions.question: For *charm person*, what kind of creature can you target, and what saving throw does it make to resist the spell?
questions.answer: You target a humanoid you can see within range, and it must make a Wisdom saving throw to resist.

questions.question: In combat, how long does it take to cast *charm person*, and what components do you need for it?
questions.answer: *Charm person* has a casting time of **1 action** and requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**.

questions.question: When you hit with *Chill Touch*, how long is the target prevented from regaining hit points, and what extra effect happens if the target is undead?
questions.answer: On a hit, the target can’t regain hit points until the start of your next turn. If the target is undead, it also has disadvantage on attack rolls against you until the end of your next turn.

questions.question: How does *Chill Touch*’s damage scale as you gain levels (what damage dice does it deal at 1st, 5th, 11th, and 17th level)?
questions.answer: *Chill Touch* deals 1d8 necrotic damage on a hit at 1st level. Its damage increases by 1d8 at 5th level (2d8), 11th level (3d8), and 17th level (4d8).

questions.question: What’s the range of *Chill Touch*, and what components (V/S/M) does it require to cast?
questions.answer: *Chill Touch* has a range of 120 feet, and it requires verbal and somatic components (V, S) with no material component.

questions.question: When casting *Chill Touch*, do you make an attack roll or does the target make a saving throw—and what kind of attack is it?
questions.answer: You make a **ranged spell attack** against the target (it’s not a saving throw).

questions.question: When *Chill Touch* hits a creature, what damage type does it deal and how much damage does it do before scaling with level?
questions.answer: On a hit, *Chill Touch* deals **1d8 necrotic damage** (before any increases at higher character levels).

questions.question: When a caster uses **Circle of Death**, what are the spell’s range and area of effect, what saving throw does it call for, and how much necrotic damage does it deal on a failed vs. successful save (including how the damage scales when upcast)?
questions.answer: Circle of Death has a range of **150 feet**. It creates a **60-foot-radius sphere** of negative energy centered on a point within range. Creatures in the area make a **Constitution saving throw**, taking **8d6 necrotic damage** on a failed save, or **half as much** on a successful one. **At higher levels:** if cast with a **7th-level or higher** slot, the damage increases by **2d6 per slot level above 6th**.

questions.question: For **Circle of Death**, what’s the casting time and duration, and what material component (including its minimum gp value) is required to cast it?
questions.answer: Circle of Death has a casting time of **1 action** and a duration of **instantaneous**. Its material component is **the powder of a crushed black pearl worth at least 500 gp** (along with verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: If a player wants to learn **Circle of Death**, which character classes have it on their spell list?
questions.answer: Circle of Death is on the spell lists for **Sorcerer, Warlock, and Wizard**.

questions.question: What level spell is **Circle of Death**, and what school of magic is it?
questions.answer: Circle of Death is a 6th-level Necromancy spell.

questions.question: When casting **Circle of Death**, is the burst centered on the caster, or can you choose where it originates—and what kinds of targets in the area are forced to save?
questions.answer: You choose a point within the spell’s range as the origin (it isn’t automatically centered on the caster). The negative energy ripples out from that point, and **each creature** in the area must make the saving throw.

questions.question: For the Clairvoyance spell, what are the casting time and range, and how long does the invisible sensor last?
questions.answer: Clairvoyance has a casting time of 10 minutes, a range of 1 mile, and the invisible sensor lasts for up to 10 minutes.

questions.question: With the Clairvoyance spell, if you initially choose seeing (or hearing), can you later switch the sensor’s sense during the duration, and what action does that take?
questions.answer: Yes. After choosing seeing or hearing when you cast the spell, you can switch between seeing and hearing as your action.

questions.question: For the Clairvoyance spell, what material component do you need, what’s its minimum value, and how does it differ if you want hearing versus seeing?
questions.answer: Clairvoyance requires a material focus worth at least 100 gp: a jeweled horn if you’re using the sensor for hearing, or a glass eye if you’re using it for seeing.

questions.question: When you cast *Clairvoyance*, can other creatures attack or otherwise interact with the invisible sensor, and what does a creature with *see invisibility* or truesight perceive if it can see the sensor?
questions.answer: The sensor remains in place for the spell’s duration and **can’t be attacked or otherwise interacted with**. A creature that can see it (such as one benefiting from *see invisibility* or truesight) sees **a luminous, intangible orb about the size of your fist**.

questions.question: When casting *Clairvoyance*, what restrictions apply to where you can place the invisible sensor—what counts as a “location familiar to you” versus an obvious but unfamiliar location?
questions.answer: You can create the invisible sensor within range either (1) in a location familiar to you—defined as a place you have visited or seen before—or (2) in an obvious location that is unfamiliar to you, such as behind a door, around a corner, or in a grove of trees.

questions.question: For the Clone spell, how long does it take the duplicate body to grow to full size and maturity, and what has to be true for the original creature’s soul to transfer into the clone when the original dies?
questions.answer: The clone grows to full size and maturity after 120 days. After it matures, if the original creature dies, the soul transfers to the clone as long as the soul is free and willing to return.

questions.question: After Clone triggers and the original creature’s soul transfers into the matured clone, what happens to the original body’s remains—can that body be brought back to life—and does the clone come back with the original’s equipment?
questions.answer: The clone is physically identical and has the same personality, memories, and abilities, but it has none of the original creature’s equipment. The original creature’s physical remains (if they still exist) become inert and can’t thereafter be restored to life, because the creature’s soul is now elsewhere.

questions.question: For the *clone* spell, what material components are required, and what are the minimum gp values of those components?
questions.answer: Clone requires material components of (1) a diamond worth at least 1,000 gp and at least 1 cubic inch of flesh of the creature to be cloned (the spell consumes these), and (2) a vessel worth at least 2,000 gp with a sealable lid, large enough to hold a Medium creature (for example, a huge urn, coffin, mud-filled cyst, or a crystal container filled with salt water).

questions.question: In play, how long does it take to cast *clone*, what’s its range, and what’s the spell’s duration?
questions.answer: *Clone* has a casting time of **1 hour**, a range of **Touch**, and a duration of **Instantaneous**.

questions.question: When you cast *cloudkill*, what saving throw do creatures make when they enter or start their turn in the fog, and how much damage does the spell deal on a failed save (and on a successful save)?
questions.answer: A creature that enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a Constitution saving throw. It takes 5d8 poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

questions.question: When you cast *cloudkill*, how does the fog cloud move on subsequent turns, and what (besides its duration ending) can cause the spell to end early?
questions.answer: The fog moves **10 feet away from you at the start of each of your turns**, rolling along the ground; because it’s heavier than air it **sinks to the lowest level of the land**, even pouring down openings. It ends early if **strong wind disperses the fog**.

questions.question: If a creature holds its breath or doesn’t need to breathe (like an undead), does *cloudkill* still affect it when it enters the fog or starts its turn there?
questions.answer: Yes. *Cloudkill* affects creatures even if they hold their breath or don’t need to breathe; they still make the Constitution saving throw when they enter the area for the first time on a turn or start their turn there.

questions.question: When you cast **Color Spray**, what area does it affect, and how do you determine which creatures in that area are blinded?
questions.answer: Color Spray affects creatures in a **15-foot cone originating from you**. You **roll 6d10**; the total is the number of hit points of creatures the spell can affect. Creatures in the cone are affected **in ascending order of their current hit points** (ignoring unconscious creatures and creatures that can’t see). Starting with the lowest current hit points, each creature is **blinded until the spell ends**, and you subtract each affected creature’s current hit points from the remaining total until you can’t cover the next creature.

questions.question: If you cast **Color Spray** using a higher-level spell slot, how does the spell scale—what extra dice do you roll per slot level above 1st to determine the hit point total affected?
questions.answer: When cast with a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you roll an additional **2d10** for each slot level above 1st (on top of the base 6d10).

questions.question: When you cast **Color Spray**, what are its casting time, duration, and required components (including the specific material component)?
questions.answer: Color Spray has a casting time of **1 action** and a duration of **1 round**. Its components are **V, S, M**, with the material component being **a pinch of powder or sand colored red, yellow, and blue**.

questions.question: Which character classes have access to the *color spray* spell?
questions.answer: *Color spray* is available to **Sorcerers** and **Wizards**.

questions.question: If I cast *command* using a higher-level spell slot, how does it scale—how many extra creatures can I target, and do the targets have to be positioned a certain way?
questions.answer: When you cast *command* with a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can affect one additional creature for each slot level above 1st, and all the targeted creatures must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them.

questions.question: If I cast *command* and use the one-word order “Halt” on a flying creature, what does it do on its next turn—does it fall, or can it stay in the air?
questions.answer: On its next turn, the target doesn’t move and takes no actions. A flying creature stays aloft as long as it’s able to do so; if it must move to stay aloft, it flies the minimum distance needed to remain in the air.

questions.question: When does the *command* spell have no effect on a target (e.g., creature type, language, or harmful command restrictions)?
questions.answer: *Command* has no effect if the target is undead, if it doesn’t understand your language, or if the one-word command is directly harmful to it.

questions.question: For the *command* spell, what saving throw does the target make, and what happens on a failed save versus a successful one?
questions.answer: The target makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it follows your one-word command on its next turn; on a successful save, the spell has no effect on that target.

questions.question: When I cast *command* and choose the one-word order “Approach,” how exactly does the target move, and what causes it to end its turn?
questions.answer: With “Approach,” the target moves toward you by the shortest and most direct route, and it ends its turn if it moves within 5 feet of you.

questions.question: When you cast Commune with Nature, how far out can you sense information outdoors versus in natural underground areas like caves, and where does the spell fail to function?
questions.answer: Outdoors, you gain knowledge of the land within 3 miles of you. In caves and other natural underground settings, the radius is limited to 300 feet. The spell doesn’t function where nature has been replaced by construction, such as in dungeons and towns.

questions.question: When you cast *Commune with Nature*, how many separate facts can you learn, and what kinds of subjects can those facts be about?
questions.answer: You instantly gain knowledge of up to three facts of your choice. Each fact must be about one of these subjects as it relates to the area: (1) terrain and bodies of water, (2) prevalent plants, minerals, animals, or peoples, (3) powerful celestials, fey, fiends, elementals, or undead, (4) influence from other planes of existence, or (5) buildings.

questions.question: For *Commune with Nature*, do you need to maintain concentration, and what are the spell’s casting time and duration?
questions.answer: *Commune with Nature* does not require concentration; its casting time is 1 minute and its duration is instantaneous.

questions.question: For *Commune with Nature*, is it a ritual, and what spell level and school is it?
questions.answer: *Commune with Nature* is a **5th-level Divination** spell, and it can be cast as a **ritual**.

questions.question: What components do you need to cast *Commune with Nature*?
questions.answer: *Commune with Nature* requires verbal and somatic components (V, S).

questions.question: If you cast Commune more than once before your next long rest, what’s the chance that you get no answer on each casting after the first?
questions.answer: If you cast Commune two or more times before finishing your next long rest, there is a cumulative 25 percent chance for each casting after the first that you get no answer (the DM rolls this in secret).

questions.question: When you cast *Commune*, how many questions can you ask your deity, and what form can the answers take if a straight yes/no would be misleading or beyond the deity’s knowledge?
questions.answer: You can ask up to three questions, each of which can be answered with a yes or no. If the information is beyond the deity’s knowledge you might receive “unclear,” and if a one-word answer would be misleading or contrary to the deity’s interests, the DM may instead give a short phrase as the answer.

questions.question: For the *Commune* spell, what material components do you need to provide when casting it?
questions.answer: You need incense and a vial of holy or unholy water (in addition to the verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: For the *Commune* spell, what are the casting time and the spell’s duration?
questions.answer: *Commune* has a casting time of **1 minute** and a duration of **1 minute**.

questions.question: Which classes can cast the *Commune* spell?
questions.answer: *Commune* is available to Clerics and Paladins, and it can also be cast by a Ritual Caster.

questions.question: When you cast *Comprehend Languages*, do you need to touch a written text to understand it, and does the spell decode secret messages or arcane sigils?
questions.answer: You can understand any written language you see only if you are touching the surface the words are written on. The spell doesn’t decode secret messages in a text or a glyph (such as an arcane sigil) that isn’t part of a written language.

questions.question: If you cast *Comprehend Languages* to read a written document, how long does it take you to read one page, and how long does the spell last?
questions.answer: It takes about **1 minute** to read one page of text, and the spell’s **duration is 1 hour**.

questions.question: When casting *Comprehend Languages*, what’s the casting time and required components (including the material), and is it a ritual spell?
questions.answer: *Comprehend Languages* has a casting time of 1 action and requires V, S, M components; the material component is a pinch of soot and salt. It is a 1st-level divination spell with the ritual tag, so it can be cast as a ritual.

questions.question: If a character wants to cast *Comprehend Languages*, what is the spell’s range, and which classes can cast it?
questions.answer: *Comprehend Languages* has a range of **Self**. It’s available to **Bard, Sorcerer, Warlock, and Wizard** (and also **Ritual Caster**).

questions.question: While *Comprehend Languages* is active, what exactly do you get from a creature’s speech—does the spell let you understand any spoken language you hear, and is that understanding only the literal meaning?
questions.answer: For the spell’s duration, you understand the literal meaning of any spoken language that you hear.

questions.question: For the 4th-level spell Compulsion, what saving throw do affected creatures make, and when can they make additional saves to end the effect?
questions.answer: Targets that can hear you must make a Wisdom saving throw (automatically succeeding if they can’t be charmed). If they fail and are affected, after they move in the designated direction on their turn, they can make another Wisdom saving throw to try to end the effect.

questions.question: In play, what are the casting time, range, and duration of the spell *Compulsion*?
questions.answer: *Compulsion* has a casting time of 1 action, a range of 30 feet, and a duration of up to 1 minute.

questions.question: When you cast *Compulsion*, do affected creatures get to take their action before the forced movement, and are they ever compelled to move into obviously deadly hazards (and do they provoke opportunity attacks while moving)?
questions.answer: Each affected target can take its action before it moves. It isn’t compelled to move into an obviously deadly hazard (such as a fire or pit), but it will provoke opportunity attacks to move in the designated direction.

questions.question: For the spell *Compulsion*, what creatures can you target—do the targets need to be able to see/hear you, and how does the spell interact with creatures that can’t be charmed?
questions.answer: You choose creatures you can see within 30 feet that can hear you. Each makes a Wisdom saving throw, but any target that can’t be charmed automatically succeeds on that save (so it isn’t affected).

questions.question: What components are required to cast *Compulsion*, and which class has it on its spell list in the SRD?
questions.answer: *Compulsion* requires verbal and somatic components (V, S), and it’s available to the Bard.

questions.question: When you cast Cone of Cold, what kind of saving throw do affected creatures make, and what damage do they take on a failed save versus a successful one?
questions.answer: Each creature in the 60-foot cone makes a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save it takes 8d8 cold damage; on a successful save it takes half as much damage.

questions.question: If Cone of Cold reduces a creature to 0 hit points (kills it), what happens to that creature’s body?
questions.answer: A creature killed by Cone of Cold becomes a frozen statue until it thaws.

questions.question: For Cone of Cold, what material component do you need to cast it, and how does its damage change when you upcast it with a higher-level spell slot?
questions.answer: Cone of Cold requires V, S, and a material component: a small crystal or glass cone. When cast using a 6th-level slot or higher, the spell’s damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 5th.

questions.question: Does Cone of Cold require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: No—Cone of Cold doesn’t require concentration. Its duration is instantaneous.

questions.question: For **Cone of Cold**, what is the spell’s range, and what area does it affect when you cast it?
questions.answer: Its range is **Self**, and it affects **each creature in a 60-foot cone** erupting from the caster’s hands.

questions.question: When you cast *Confusion*, what area does it affect and what saving throw do creatures in that area make to resist it?
questions.answer: It affects each creature in a **10-foot-radius sphere** centered on a point you choose within the spell’s **90-foot range**, and affected creatures must make a **Wisdom saving throw** when you cast the spell to resist it.

questions.question: While a creature is affected by the *Confusion* spell, what happens on its turn if it rolls a 7–8 on the d10 for the spell’s behavior table?
questions.answer: On a 7–8, the creature uses its action to make a melee attack against a randomly determined creature within its reach; if there’s no creature within reach, it does nothing that turn.

questions.question: If I upcast *Confusion* using a 6th-level spell slot, what’s the spell’s new area of effect (sphere radius)?
questions.answer: *Confusion* normally affects a 10-foot-radius sphere. At higher levels, the radius increases by 5 feet for each slot level above 4th—so with a 6th-level slot (two levels higher), the radius is 20 feet.

questions.question: After a creature fails its initial save against *Confusion*, when does it get to make additional saving throws to end the spell, and what save is it?
questions.answer: At the end of each of its turns, an affected target can make a Wisdom saving throw; on a success, the effect ends for that target.

questions.question: Under the *Confusion* spell, can an affected creature take reactions, and when does it roll to determine what it does on its turn?
questions.answer: No. An affected target can’t take reactions, and it rolls a d10 at the start of each of its turns to determine its behavior for that turn.

questions.question: When you upcast *Conjure Animals*, how does the number of summoned creatures change if you use a 5th-, 7th-, or 9th-level spell slot?
questions.answer: You choose one of the normal summoning options, and the number of creatures increases: twice as many with a 5th-level slot, three times as many with a 7th-level slot, and four times as many with a 9th-level slot.

questions.question: When you cast *Conjure Animals*, what’s the spell’s range, and where can the summoned beasts appear?
questions.answer: The spell has a range of 60 feet. The summoned beasts appear in unoccupied spaces you can see within that range.

questions.question: When you cast *Conjure Animals*, do the summoned beasts take their turns on your initiative, and do you have to spend an action to command them each round?
questions.answer: You roll initiative for the summoned creatures as a group, and that group has its own turns (separate from yours). They obey any verbal commands you issue to them, and issuing those commands requires no action from you. If you don’t give commands, they defend themselves from hostile creatures but otherwise take no actions.

questions.question: When you cast Conjure Animals, what creature type are the summoned beasts considered, and when do they disappear?
questions.answer: The spell summons fey spirits in beast form; each summoned beast is also considered fey, and it disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

questions.question: When you cast **Conjure Animals**, what are the spell’s casting time and required components?
questions.answer:
**Casting Time:** 1 action.
**Components:** V, S.

questions.question: When you cast **Conjure Celestial**, what’s the maximum challenge rating (CR) celestial you can summon normally, and how does that change if you upcast it using a 9th-level slot?
questions.answer: Normally, Conjure Celestial summons a celestial of **CR 4 or lower**. If cast using a **9th-level spell slot**, it can summon a celestial of **CR 5 or lower**.

questions.question: When you cast **Conjure Celestial**, how does the summoned celestial act if you don’t give it any verbal commands?
questions.answer: If you don’t issue any commands to the celestial, it defends itself from hostile creatures but otherwise takes no actions.
