questions.question: Which classes have *faerie fire* on their spell lists, and what components are required to cast it?
questions.answer: *Faerie fire* is available to Bards, Clerics, Druids, and Warlocks, and it requires only a verbal component (V).

questions.question: What are the casting time and range of *faerie fire*?
questions.answer: *Faerie fire* has a casting time of 1 action and a range of 60 feet.

questions.question: When you cast *faerie fire*, do objects in the targeted area get outlined automatically, and what colors can you choose for the outlining light?
questions.answer: Yes. Each object in the 20-foot cube within range is outlined automatically, and you choose whether the outlining light is blue, green, or violet.

questions.question: For the *faithful hound* spell, what triggers the hound to start barking, and how much damage does its bite deal on a hit?
questions.answer: The hound starts barking loudly when a Small or larger creature comes within 30 feet of it without first speaking the password you specified when casting the spell. At the start of each of your turns it can bite a hostile creature within 5 feet; on a hit the bite deals 4d8 piercing damage.

questions.question: When you cast *False Life*, how many temporary hit points do you gain, and how does that amount increase if you upcast it?
questions.answer: You gain 1d4 + 4 temporary hit points for 1 hour. If you cast it with a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you gain 5 additional temporary hit points for each slot level above 1st.

questions.question: When you cast *False Life*, what are its casting time, range, and duration?
questions.answer: Casting Time: 1 action; Range: Self; Duration: 1 hour.

questions.question: When casting *False Life*, what components do you need, including the specific material component?
questions.answer: *False Life* requires verbal and somatic components, plus a material component: a small amount of alcohol or distilled spirits (V, S, M).

questions.question: Which classes can learn or prepare the *False Life* spell in the SRD?
questions.answer: In the SRD, *False Life* is available to Sorcerers and Wizards.

questions.question: What level spell is *False Life*, and what school of magic is it?
questions.answer: *False Life* is a 1st-level necromancy spell.

questions.question: When you cast *Fear*, what’s the spell’s area of effect and saving throw, and how can an affected creature end the spell early?
questions.answer: *Fear* affects creatures in a 30-foot cone. Each creature must make a Wisdom saving throw or drop what it’s holding and become frightened for up to 1 minute. If a frightened creature ends its turn somewhere it doesn’t have line of sight to you, it can make another Wisdom saving throw; on a success, the spell ends for that creature.

questions.question: For the *Fear* spell, what material component do you need to cast it, and what happens to a creature’s held items if it fails the saving throw?
questions.answer: It requires a material component of **a white feather or the heart of a hen**. A creature that fails the Wisdom saving throw **drops whatever it is holding**.

questions.question: For the *Fear* spell, what are the casting time, range, and duration?
questions.answer: Casting Time: 1 action; Range: Self; Duration: Up to 1 minute.

questions.question: When a creature fails its saving throw against the *Fear* spell, what does it have to do on each of its turns while it remains frightened (in terms of the required action and movement)?
questions.answer: While frightened by *Fear*, the creature must take the Dash action and move away from you by the safest available route on each of its turns, unless there is nowhere to move.

questions.question: Which character classes have *Fear* on their spell list in the SRD?
questions.answer: *Fear* is available to the Bard, Sorcerer, Warlock, and Wizard.

questions.question: For the Feather Fall spell, how many falling creatures can you affect with one casting, and what descent rate do they fall at while the spell lasts?
questions.answer: You can choose up to five falling creatures within 60 feet. Each affected creature’s rate of descent becomes 60 feet per round until the spell ends (or the creature lands, taking no falling damage and landing on its feet).

questions.question: When you cast *Feather Fall*, what happens if an affected creature reaches the ground before the spell’s full duration—does it still take falling damage, how does it land, and does the spell keep affecting it afterward?
questions.answer: If a creature lands before the spell ends, it takes no falling damage, can land on its feet, and the spell ends for that creature.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast *Feather Fall*?
questions.answer: A small feather or a piece of down.

questions.question: In play, when can you cast *Feather Fall* (casting time), and how far away can you target falling creatures with it?
questions.answer: *Feather Fall* has a casting time of **1 reaction** and a **range of 60 feet**.

questions.question: Which character classes have *Feather Fall* on their spell list?
questions.answer: *Feather Fall* is on the Bard, Sorcerer, and Wizard spell lists.

questions.question: If a creature fails its save against *feeblemind*, how can it recover—does it get repeat saves, and what spells can end the effect early?
questions.answer: After failing the initial Intelligence saving throw, the creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of every 30 days; on a success, the spell ends. The effect can also be ended early by **greater restoration**, **heal**, or **wish**.

questions.question: For the spell *feeblemind*, what is its range, what damage does it deal, and what saving throw does the target make?
questions.answer: *Feeblemind* has a range of 150 feet. The target takes 4d6 psychic damage and must make an Intelligence saving throw.

questions.question: For the spell *feeblemind*, what material component is required, and does the spell require concentration or have an ongoing duration?
questions.answer: *Feeblemind* requires a material component of “a handful of clay, crystal, glass, or mineral spheres.” Its duration is **instantaneous**, so it doesn’t require concentration or an ongoing duration.

questions.question: If a target fails its Intelligence save against *feeblemind*, what specific capabilities does it lose, and what things can it still do despite the effect?
questions.answer: On a failed save, the creature’s Intelligence and Charisma scores become 1. It can’t cast spells, activate magic items, understand language, or communicate in any intelligible way. It can still identify its friends, follow them, and even protect them.

questions.question: In play, who can cast **feeblemind**, and how long does it take to cast?
questions.answer: **Feeblemind** is cast with **1 action**, and it’s available to **Bards, Druids, Warlocks, and Wizards**.

questions.question: When you cast a spell with a range of touch while you have a familiar from *find familiar*, what are the requirements for the familiar to deliver that spell (including distance and what it uses to deliver it)?
questions.answer: Your familiar can deliver a touch-range spell as if it had cast the spell, but it must be within 100 feet of you, and it must use its reaction to deliver the spell when you cast it. If the spell requires an attack roll, you use your attack modifier for that roll.

questions.question: With *find familiar*, if you use your action to see through your familiar’s eyes and hear what it hears, how long does that last and what happens to your own senses during that time?
questions.answer: It lasts until the start of your next turn, and during that time you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses (while gaining the benefits of any special senses the familiar has).

questions.question: If I temporarily dismiss my familiar from *find familiar*, what do I need to do to bring it back, and how far from me can it reappear?
questions.answer: You can temporarily dismiss your familiar as an action, sending it into a pocket dimension. While it’s temporarily dismissed, you can use your action to cause it to reappear in any unoccupied space within 30 feet of you.

questions.question: In combat, if a wizard’s familiar from *find familiar* is reduced to 0 hit points, what happens to it (does it leave a body), and how do you get it back?
questions.answer: When the familiar drops to 0 hit points, it disappears and leaves behind no physical form. It reappears after you cast *find familiar* again.

questions.question: For *find familiar*, what material components (including cost) do you need to cast the spell, and are they consumed?
questions.answer: It requires material components of **10 gp worth of charcoal, incense, and herbs**, and they **must be consumed by fire in a brass brazier** (V, S, M).

questions.question: If you’re mounted on a steed summoned by *find steed*, what special targeting benefit do you get for spells you cast that normally target only you?
questions.answer: While mounted on your steed, you can make any spell you cast that targets only you also target your steed.

questions.question: When you cast *find steed*, how far away can your bonded steed be while you still communicate with it telepathically?
questions.answer: You can communicate with your steed telepathically while it is within 1 mile of you.

questions.question: When does the Find the Path spell fail because of an invalid destination?
questions.answer: Find the Path fails if you name a destination on another plane of existence, a destination that moves (such as a mobile fortress), or a destination that isn’t specific (for example, “a green dragon’s lair”).

questions.question: While a character has **Find the Path** active, what guidance does the spell provide during travel—specifically what information do they know about the destination and what happens when they reach a choice of routes?
questions.answer: For the duration, as long as you’re on the same plane as the destination, you know how far away it is and what direction it lies. While traveling there, whenever you’re presented with a choice of paths, you automatically determine which path is the shortest and most direct route to the destination (not necessarily the safest).

questions.question: For *Find the Path*, what material components do you need to cast it (including the 100 gp requirement and any special item tied to the destination)?
questions.answer: You need a set of divinatory tools (such as bones, ivory sticks, cards, teeth, or carved runes) worth 100 gp, and an object from the location you wish to find (in addition to verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: Which classes can cast *Find the Path* in the SRD?
questions.answer: *Find the Path* is available to the Bard, Cleric, and Druid spell lists.

questions.question: In play, how long does it take to cast *Find the Path*, and how long can the spell last once cast?
questions.answer: *Find the Path* has a casting time of **1 minute** and a duration of **up to 24 hours**.

questions.question: When you cast *Find Traps*, do you learn the exact locations of the traps you detect, or only that traps are present (and what kind of danger they pose)?
questions.answer: *Find Traps* only reveals that a trap is present (within range and line of sight). You don’t learn the location of each trap, but you do learn the general nature of the danger posed by any trap you sense.

questions.question: When you cast *Find Traps*, what’s the spell’s range, and do you need line of sight to the trap for it to be detected?
questions.answer: *Find Traps* has a range of **120 feet**, and it only senses traps **within range that are within your line of sight**.

questions.question: Does the *Find Traps* spell detect natural hazards like an unstable ceiling or a hidden sinkhole, or only traps intentionally created to harm intruders?
questions.answer: *Find Traps* only senses traps that were specifically intended as harmful or undesirable by their creator (such as an area affected by *alarm*, a *glyph of warding*, or a mechanical pit trap). It does **not** reveal natural weaknesses in the floor, an unstable ceiling, or a hidden sinkhole.

questions.question: If a hallway is warded with a magical effect like *alarm* or *glyph of warding*, does casting *Find Traps* detect that as a “trap” (assuming it’s within range and line of sight)?
questions.answer: Yes. *Find Traps* senses any trap within range that is within line of sight, and it explicitly includes an area affected by the *alarm* spell or a *glyph of warding* as traps it can detect.

questions.question: When you cast *Find Traps*, what’s the casting time and what components does it require?
questions.answer: *Find Traps* has a casting time of **1 action** and requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**.

questions.question: If you cast *finger of death*, what saving throw does the target make, how much damage does it take on a failed vs. successful save, and what happens if the spell kills a humanoid?
questions.answer: The target makes a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save it takes 7d8 + 30 necrotic damage; on a successful save it takes half as much. If a humanoid is killed by the spell, it rises at the start of your next turn as a zombie permanently under your command that follows your verbal orders.

questions.question: In play, if I want to cast *finger of death*, what’s its casting time and range, and does it require any material components or concentration?
questions.answer: *Finger of Death* has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **60 feet**. Its components are **V, S** (no material components), and its duration is **instantaneous** (no concentration).

questions.question: Which classes can cast *finger of death*, and what spell level and school is it?
questions.answer: *Finger of Death* is a 7th-level necromancy spell available to Sorcerers, Warlocks, and Wizards.

questions.question: When you cast *finger of death*, do you need line of sight to the target, and what is the spell’s duration?
questions.answer: You target “a creature that you can see within range,” so you must be able to see the creature. The spell’s duration is **Instantaneous**.

questions.question: When you cast Fire Bolt at an object, under what condition does it ignite?
questions.answer: A flammable object hit by Fire Bolt ignites if it isn’t being worn or carried.

questions.question: For the Fire Bolt cantrip, what range does it have, and what damage does it deal when cast by an 11th-level character?
questions.answer: Fire Bolt has a range of 120 feet, and at 11th level it deals 3d10 fire damage on a hit (ranged spell attack).

questions.question: For the Fire Bolt cantrip, what are its casting time, components, and duration?
questions.answer: Fire Bolt has a casting time of 1 action, requires verbal and somatic components (V, S), and has an instantaneous duration.

questions.question: Which classes have the Fire Bolt cantrip on their spell list?
questions.answer: Fire Bolt is available to Sorcerers and Wizards.

questions.question: What level and school is the Fire Bolt spell, and what type of damage does it deal on a hit?
questions.answer: Fire Bolt is a cantrip of the evocation school, and it deals fire damage (1d10 on a hit).

questions.question: When you have **Fire Shield** up, what triggers its retaliatory damage, and how much damage does the attacker take?
questions.answer: While Fire Shield lasts, whenever a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, flames spring from the shield and the attacker takes **2d8** damage of the shield’s type (**fire** for the heat shield or **cold** for the cold shield).

questions.question: Does the Fire Shield spell require concentration, and how long does it last once cast?
questions.answer: No—Fire Shield doesn’t require concentration. Its duration is 10 minutes.

questions.question: When you cast **Fire Shield**, what damage resistance do you gain if you choose the heat shield versus the cold shield?
questions.answer: Choosing the **heat shield** gives you **resistance to cold damage**; choosing the **cold shield** gives you **resistance to fire damage**.

questions.question: While Fire Shield is active, what light radius does it create, and how can you dismiss the spell before its duration ends?
questions.answer: Fire Shield sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet. You can end it early by using an action to make it disappear.

questions.question: What material component is required to cast *fire shield*?
questions.answer: Casting *fire shield* requires a material component of **a little phosphorus or a firefly** (in addition to verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: For the Fire Storm spell, how is the area of effect laid out (shape and size), and what saving throw and damage does a creature in the area take?
questions.answer: Fire Storm creates an area made of up to ten 10-foot cubes you can arrange as you wish, with each cube having at least one face adjacent to another cube. Creatures in the area make a Dexterity saving throw, taking 7d10 fire damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful save.

questions.question: When you cast Fire Storm, what happens to objects and flammable materials in the affected area, and can you choose to spare plant life from the spell’s effects?
questions.answer: The fire damages objects in the area and ignites flammable objects that aren’t being worn or carried. You can choose for plant life in the area to be unaffected by the spell.

questions.question: For Fire Storm, does the spell require concentration, and what are its casting time and range?
questions.answer: Fire Storm does not require concentration (its duration is instantaneous). It has a casting time of 1 action and a range of 150 feet.

questions.question: When casting Fire Storm, do you need any material components, and what components are required overall?
questions.answer: No material components are required. Fire Storm’s components are verbal and somatic (V, S).

questions.question: Which classes can cast the Fire Storm spell (i.e., which class spell lists include it)?
questions.answer: In the SRD, Fire Storm is on the Cleric, Druid, and Sorcerer spell lists.

questions.question: When you cast *fireball*, what saving throw do creatures in the blast make, and how much fire damage do they take on a failed save versus a successful one?
questions.answer: Creatures in the 20-foot-radius sphere make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 8d6 fire damage; on a successful save, it takes half as much damage.

questions.question: When you cast *fireball*, how far away can you place the point of origin, and what size area does the explosion cover?
questions.answer: You choose a point within 150 feet, and the spell explodes in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on that point.

questions.question: When you cast *fireball*, does the blast spread around corners, and what does it do to flammable objects in the area?
questions.answer: Yes. The fire spreads around corners, and it ignites flammable objects in the area that aren’t being worn or carried.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast *fireball* (in addition to verbal and somatic components)?
questions.answer: A tiny ball of bat guano and sulfur.

questions.question: When you upcast *fireball* using a spell slot higher than 3rd level, how does its damage change?
questions.answer: If you cast *fireball* with a 4th-level or higher spell slot, its damage increases by **1d6 for each slot level above 3rd**.

questions.question: When you cast *Flame Blade*, what action do you use to make an attack with it, and how much fire damage does it deal on a hit?
questions.answer: You use your action to make a melee spell attack with the fiery blade; on a hit, the target takes 3d6 fire damage.

questions.question: When you cast *flame blade*, how much bright and dim light does the fiery blade shed?
questions.answer: The flaming blade sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.

questions.question: If I upcast *Flame Blade*, how does its damage scale with higher-level spell slots?
questions.answer: When you cast *Flame Blade* using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for every two slot levels above 2nd.

questions.question: If you cast *Flame Blade* and then let go of the fiery blade, what happens to it, and how can you bring it back?
questions.answer: If you let go of the blade, it disappears, but you can evoke the blade again as a bonus action.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast *Flame Blade*?
questions.answer: A leaf of sumac.

questions.question: For Flame Strike, what area does it affect and what saving throw does each creature in that area need to make?
questions.answer: It affects a 10-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder centered on a point within 60 feet, and each creature in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw.

questions.question: When a creature fails its saving throw against Flame Strike, what damage dice and damage types does it take, and how does the spell’s damage increase when cast with a higher-level slot?
questions.answer: On a failed save, the target takes 4d6 fire damage plus 4d6 radiant damage (half on a successful save). When cast using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, you increase either the fire damage or the radiant damage (your choice) by 1d6 for each slot level above 5th.

questions.question: Does Flame Strike require concentration, and what are its casting time and duration?
questions.answer: No—Flame Strike does not require concentration. It has a casting time of 1 action and a duration of instantaneous.

questions.question: Which classes can cast *Flame Strike*, and what material component is required to cast it?
questions.answer: *Flame Strike* is available to Clerics, Paladins, and Warlocks, and it requires a material component: a pinch of sulfur (along with V and S components).

questions.question: When you cast **Flame Strike**, how far away can you place the spell’s point of origin, and what is the spell centered on?
questions.answer: Flame Strike has a **range of 60 feet**, and its 10-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder is **centered on a point you specify within that range**.

questions.question: For the Flaming Sphere spell, what saving throw does a creature make and when does it have to make it (including if you ram the sphere into it), and what damage does it take on a failed vs. successful save?
questions.answer: A creature must make a Dexterity saving throw if it ends its turn within 5 feet of the sphere; it also must make the saving throw if you ram the sphere into it. On a failed save it takes 2d6 fire damage, or half as much damage on a successful save.

questions.question: When you cast *Flaming Sphere*, how far can you move the sphere on your turn, and what kinds of obstacles can you move it over or across?
questions.answer: As a bonus action, you can move the flaming sphere up to 30 feet. When you move it, you can direct it over barriers up to 5 feet tall and jump it across pits up to 10 feet wide.

questions.question: When you cast *Flaming Sphere*, how much bright and dim light does the sphere shed?
questions.answer: The sphere sheds **bright light in a 20-foot radius** and **dim light for an additional 20 feet** beyond that.

questions.question: When you upcast *Flaming Sphere*, how does its damage scale with higher-level spell slots?
questions.answer: If you cast *Flaming Sphere* using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the spell’s damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 2nd.

questions.question: When casting *Flaming Sphere*, what material component(s) do you need to provide?
questions.answer: It requires a material component: **a bit of tallow, a pinch of brimstone, and a dusting of powdered iron** (along with verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: For the *Flesh to Stone* spell, what saving throw does the target make, and what happens if it accumulates three failed saves versus three successful saves?
questions.answer: The target makes Constitution saving throws. On a failed initial save it becomes restrained and must repeat the Constitution save at the end of each of its turns. If it fails three saves total, it is turned to stone and is petrified for the duration (and if you maintain concentration for the full duration, it remains stone until the effect is removed). If it succeeds on three saves total, the spell ends.

questions.question: For the Flesh to Stone spell, what happens if the caster maintains concentration for the spell’s entire possible duration?
questions.answer: If you maintain your concentration on Flesh to Stone for the entire possible duration (up to 1 minute), the target is turned to stone until the effect is removed.

questions.question: If a creature is petrified by *Flesh to Stone* and its stone body gets physically broken, what happens if it later reverts to its original form?
questions.answer: If the creature is physically broken while petrified, it suffers from similar deformities if it reverts to its original state.

questions.question: What material component does a caster need for the *Flesh to Stone* spell?
questions.answer: It requires a material component: a pinch of lime, water, and earth (along with verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: For the *Flesh to Stone* spell, what are its casting time, range, and duration, and which classes can cast it?
questions.answer: *Flesh to Stone* has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **60 feet**, and a duration of **up to 1 minute**. It’s available to **Warlocks and Wizards**.

questions.question: For Floating Disk, how does the disk move in relation to you, and at what distance does the spell end if you get too far away?
questions.answer: The disk is immobile while you are within 20 feet of it; if you move more than 20 feet away, it follows you to stay within 20 feet. If you ever get more than 100 feet away from the disk (typically because it can’t move around an obstacle to follow), the spell ends.

questions.question: For Tenser’s Floating Disk, how much weight can the disk carry, and what happens if you load more than that onto it?
questions.answer: The disk can hold up to 500 pounds. If more weight is placed on it, the spell ends and everything on the disk falls to the ground.

questions.question: When using Floating Disk to haul gear through a dungeon, can the disk cross a 10-foot-deep pit or any elevation change of 10 feet or more (like a ledge or drop), and what happens in that situation?
questions.answer: No. The disk can move over uneven terrain and stairs, but it can’t cross an elevation change of 10 feet or more. For example, it can’t move across a 10-foot-deep pit, and it also can’t leave such a pit if it was created at the bottom.

questions.question: When you cast Floating Disk, what are the disk’s dimensions and how high off the ground does it hover?
questions.answer: It creates a circular, horizontal plane of force **3 feet in diameter** and **1 inch thick** that **floats 3 feet above the ground** (in an unoccupied space you can see within range).

questions.question: When you cast Floating Disk during play, what’s the spell’s range, and what material component does it require?
questions.answer: Floating Disk has a range of 30 feet, and it requires a material component of a drop of mercury (along with V and S components).

questions.question: If I upcast *fly* using a 5th-level spell slot, how many creatures can I target, and what range do I need to be within to cast it?
questions.answer: At 5th level, *fly* can target up to 3 willing creatures (one extra creature per slot level above 3rd). Its range is Touch, so you must touch each target when casting.

questions.question: When I cast *fly* on a willing creature, what flying speed does it gain, and what happens when the spell ends if it’s still in the air?
questions.answer: The target gains a flying speed of 60 feet for the spell’s duration. When the spell ends, the target falls if it is still aloft, unless it can stop the fall.

questions.question: For the *fly* spell, what components do I need to provide—including the specific material component?
questions.answer: *Fly* requires verbal, somatic, and material components (V, S, M), and the material component is **a wing feather from any bird**.

questions.question: When you cast *fly*, what’s the spell’s casting time, and how long can it last?
questions.answer: *Fly* has a casting time of **1 action** and a duration of **up to 10 minutes**.

questions.question: Can you cast *fly* on an unwilling creature, or does the target have to be willing?
questions.answer: The target has to be willing—*fly* says, “You touch a willing creature.”

questions.question: If I cast *fog cloud* with a 3rd-level spell slot, how big is the fog’s radius, and what kind of wind can disperse it early?
questions.answer: At 3rd level, the fog’s radius is 60 feet (20-foot base radius + 20 feet per slot level above 1st). It can be dispersed early by a wind of moderate or greater speed—at least 10 miles per hour.

questions.question: When I cast *fog cloud*, what are its casting time and range, and does the fog spread around corners and create a heavily obscured area?
questions.answer: *Fog cloud* has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **120 feet**. It creates a **20-foot-radius sphere of fog** centered on a point within range; the sphere **spreads around corners**, and the area is **heavily obscured**.

questions.question: For *fog cloud*, what components do I need to cast it, and which classes have it on their spell list?
questions.answer: It requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**. The spell is available to **Cleric, Druid, Ranger, Sorcerer, and Wizard**.

questions.question: If nothing disperses it, how long does the *fog cloud* spell last?
questions.answer: Its duration is **up to 1 hour**.

questions.question: What level spell is *fog cloud*, and what school of magic is it?
questions.answer: *Fog cloud* is a 1st-level Conjuration spell.

questions.question: For the Forbiddance spell, what kinds of movement does the ward prevent (teleportation/portals/planar travel), and what happens to a chosen creature type that enters the area or starts its turn there?
questions.answer: For the spell’s duration, creatures can’t teleport into the area or use portals (including gate) to enter it, and it also prevents access via planar travel (Astral Plane, Ethereal Plane, Feywild, Shadowfell, or plane shift). A creature of a type you chose when casting (celestial, elemental, fey, fiend, and/or undead) that enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there takes 5d10 radiant or necrotic damage (caster’s choice when casting).

questions.question: If a cleric wants to make *forbiddance* last indefinitely at a temple, what do they need to do, and when are the spell’s material components consumed?
questions.answer: Cast *forbiddance* every day for 30 days in the same location; after the 30th casting the spell lasts until it is dispelled, and the material components are consumed on that last casting.

questions.question: When you cast *forbiddance* to protect a temple, how large an area (floor space and height) can the ward cover, and can its area overlap another *forbiddance* spell?
questions.answer: *Forbiddance* can protect up to **40,000 square feet of floor space** to a height of **30 feet above the floor**, and **the spell’s area can’t overlap with the area of another forbiddance spell**.

questions.question: If a creature trapped inside *forcecage* tries to teleport or use interplanar travel to escape, what saving throw does it have to make, and what happens on a success vs. a failure?
questions.answer: It must first make a Charisma saving throw. On a success, it can use the teleportation or interplanar travel magic to exit the cage; on a failure, it can’t exit and the spell or effect is wasted.

questions.question: When casting *forcecage*, if you choose the solid box option instead of the barred cage, how big can the box be and what does it block (matter and spellcasting) across its boundary?
questions.answer: The box can be up to 10 feet on a side. It creates a solid barrier that prevents any matter from passing through it and blocks any spells cast into or out from the area.

questions.question: If I cast *Foresight* on an ally, what combat and roll advantages does it grant, and can the target be surprised while it lasts?
questions.answer: For 8 hours, the touched willing creature can’t be surprised, has advantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws, and other creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls against it.

questions.question: If a character is grappled or wearing manacles, how much movement does **Freedom of Movement** let them spend to automatically escape nonmagical restraints?
questions.answer: The target can spend **5 feet of movement** to automatically escape from nonmagical restraints (including manacles or a creature that has it grappled).

questions.question: Does *Freedom of Movement* require concentration, and how long does it last once cast?
questions.answer: No—*Freedom of Movement* does not require concentration, and its duration is 1 hour.

questions.question: If a creature under the **Freedom of Movement** spell is fighting underwater, do they still suffer the usual underwater penalties to movement and attacks?
questions.answer: No. While *Freedom of Movement* lasts, being underwater imposes no penalties on the target’s movement or attacks.

questions.question: If a character under *Freedom of Movement* is hit by a spell or other magical effect that would reduce their speed or inflict the paralyzed or restrained condition, what does the spell do to those effects while it lasts?
questions.answer: While *Freedom of Movement* lasts, spells and other magical effects can neither reduce the target’s speed nor cause the target to be paralyzed or restrained.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast **Freedom of Movement**, and how is it used as part of the spell?
questions.answer: The spell requires a material component: **a leather strap, bound around the arm (or a similar appendage).**

questions.question: When you cast *Freezing Sphere*, what saving throw does a creature in the blast have to make, and how much cold damage does it take on a failed save (and on a successful save)?
questions.answer: Creatures in the 60-foot-radius blast make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 10d6 cold damage; on a successful save, it takes half as much damage.

questions.question: When you cast *Freezing Sphere* but choose to hold onto the globe instead of firing it immediately, how far can you throw it (or launch it with a sling), and what happens if it hasn’t shattered after 1 minute?
questions.answer: If you don’t fire it right away, a small globe appears in your hand. You or a creature you give it to can throw it to a range of 40 feet, or hurl it with a sling to the sling’s normal range. If the globe hasn’t already shattered, it explodes after 1 minute.

questions.question: If *Freezing Sphere* hits a body of water (or a liquid that’s principally water), what exactly gets frozen (area and depth), how long does the ice last, and how can a creature trapped in the ice break free?
questions.answer: If the globe strikes a body of water or a liquid that is principally water (not including water-based creatures), it freezes the liquid to a depth of 6 inches over an area 30 feet square, and the ice lasts for 1 minute. Creatures swimming on the surface of the frozen water are trapped in the ice; a trapped creature can use an action to make a Strength check against your spell save DC to break free.

questions.question: Does *Freezing Sphere* require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: No. *Freezing Sphere* doesn’t require concentration; its duration is **instantaneous**.

questions.question: When a creature is under the Gaseous Form spell, what movement speed does it have, and can it attack or cast spells while in that form?
questions.answer: In gaseous form, the target’s only movement is a flying speed of 10 feet, and it can’t attack or cast spells while transformed.

questions.question: While a creature is affected by *Gaseous Form*, what kind of damage does it gain resistance to, and which saving throws does it have advantage on?
questions.answer: In gaseous form, the target has resistance to nonmagical damage and has advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws.

questions.question: While a creature is under *Gaseous Form*, can it squeeze through tiny openings like cracks, and how does it interact with liquids while moving?
questions.answer: Yes. In gaseous form, the target can pass through small holes, narrow openings, and even mere cracks, but it treats liquids as though they were solid surfaces.

questions.question: For the *Gaseous Form* spell, what conditions cause the spell to end early, and can it affect an incorporeal creature?
questions.answer: The spell ends early if the transformed creature drops to 0 hit points. An incorporeal creature isn’t affected by the spell.

questions.question: While a creature is affected by *Gaseous Form*, can it move into another creature’s space, and does it fall if it becomes stunned or otherwise incapacitated?
questions.answer: Yes. In gaseous form, the target can enter and occupy the space of another creature, and it can’t fall—it remains hovering in the air even when stunned or otherwise incapacitated.

questions.question: When you cast the Gate spell to bring a specific creature through, do you have to use its true name, or can you use a title or nickname—and what happens if the creature is on another plane?
questions.answer: You must speak the creature’s specific name; a pseudonym, title, or nickname doesn’t work. If the named creature is on a different plane than you, the portal opens in the creature’s immediate vicinity and draws it through to the nearest unoccupied space on your side of the portal.

questions.question: For the **Gate** spell, how large can you make the portal, and can creatures move through it from either side (or only one direction)?
questions.answer: Gate creates a **circular portal 5 to 20 feet in diameter**. The portal has a **front and a back** on each plane, and **travel through it is possible only by moving through its front** (entering the front instantly transports you to the other plane).

questions.question: When a character casts **Gate**, can a deity or planar ruler stop the portal from opening—and if so, in what locations can they block it?
questions.answer: Yes. Deities and other planar rulers can prevent portals created by **Gate** from opening **in their presence** or **anywhere within their domains**.

questions.question: During play, if a caster wants to use **Gate**, what are the spell’s casting time and range—and what expensive material component (including its minimum value) does it require?
questions.answer: Gate has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **60 feet**, and it requires **V, S, M** components with a material component of **a diamond worth at least 5,000 gp**.

questions.question: When you cast **Gate** to open a portal to another plane (not calling a creature), what are the requirements for the space you place the portal on your side—does it have to be an unoccupied space you can see?
questions.answer: Yes. Gate links "an unoccupied space you can see within range" to a precise location on a different plane of existence, so the portal’s space on your side must be unoccupied and visible to you.

questions.question: When a creature under the Geas spell acts directly against the caster’s instructions, how much damage does it take and how often can that damage occur?
questions.answer: It takes 5d10 psychic damage each time it acts directly counter to your instructions, but the damage can occur no more than once each day.

questions.question: During play, how can the Geas spell be ended early—can the caster dismiss it, and what other spells can remove it?
questions.answer: The caster can end Geas early by using an action to dismiss it. It also ends if the caster issues a suicidal command. Additionally, remove curse, greater restoration, or wish ends the spell.

questions.question: When you cast *Geas* on a creature that can understand you, what saving throw does it make, and what happens to it if it fails?
questions.answer: The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it becomes charmed by you for the spell’s duration (30 days at 5th level).

questions.question: If you upcast *Geas*, how does its duration change when cast with a 7th-, 8th-, or 9th-level spell slot?
questions.answer: At Higher Levels: If cast using a 7th- or 8th-level slot, *geas* lasts 1 year. If cast using a 9th-level slot, it lasts until ended by **remove curse**, **greater restoration**, or **wish**.

questions.question: During combat prep, I need to know: does *Geas* require concentration, and how long does it last when cast normally (5th level)?
questions.answer: No—*Geas* isn’t a concentration spell. Its normal duration is 30 days.

questions.question: If I cast *Gentle Repose* on a corpse, does it prevent the body from becoming undead and how does it interact with the time limit for spells like *raise dead*?
questions.answer: For the duration, the target is protected from decay and can't become undead. It also effectively extends the time limit on raising the target from the dead, since days spent under the spell don’t count against the time limit of spells such as *raise dead*.

questions.question: For *gentle repose*, what material components do I need, and do they have to stay on the corpse for the whole spell duration?
questions.answer: It requires material components: “a pinch of salt and one copper piece placed on each of the corpse’s eyes,” and those coins must remain there for the duration.

questions.question: During play, if I want to keep a body preserved, what are *gentle repose*’s range and duration?
questions.answer: *Gentle repose* has a range of Touch and a duration of 10 days.

questions.question: In the middle of a session, I need to know fast: is *gentle repose* a ritual spell, and what’s its normal casting time?
questions.answer: Yes. *Gentle repose* is a 2nd-level necromancy **(ritual)** spell, and its **casting time is 1 action**.

questions.question: Which classes can cast *gentle repose* in the SRD (including any special class options listed)?
questions.answer: *Gentle repose* is available to Cleric and Wizard, and it’s also listed for the Ritual Caster option.

questions.question: For the Giant Insect spell, how many of each type of insect can you transform (centipedes, spiders, wasps, or a scorpion)?
questions.answer: You can transform up to ten centipedes, three spiders, five wasps, or one scorpion within range into giant versions of their natural forms.

questions.question: When you cast *Giant Insect*, when do the transformed insects act in combat, and how can you end the effect early on one of them?
questions.answer: Each transformed creature obeys your verbal commands and, in combat, acts on your turn each round. It stays giant for the duration until it drops to 0 hit points, or until you use an action to dismiss the effect on it.

questions.question: When casting *Giant Insect*, what’s the spell’s range and how long does it last?
questions.answer: *Giant Insect* has a range of 30 feet and a duration of up to 10 minutes.

questions.question: When casting *Giant Insect*, what spell components are required?
questions.answer: *Giant Insect* requires verbal and somatic components (V, S).

questions.question: In combat, how long does it take to cast *Giant Insect* (what’s its casting time)?
questions.answer: *Giant Insect* has a casting time of **1 action**.

questions.question: While Glibness is active, what can you do to the d20 roll on a Charisma check, and how does the spell affect magic that would determine whether you’re telling the truth?
questions.answer: Until the spell ends, whenever you make a Charisma check you can replace the number you roll with a 15, and magic that would determine if you are telling the truth indicates that you are being truthful no matter what you say.

questions.question: For the spell *Glibness*, what are its casting time, range, and duration?
questions.answer: *Glibness* has a casting time of 1 action, a range of Self, and a duration of 1 hour.

questions.question: When casting *Glibness*, what spell components are required—does it need somatic or material components, or is it verbal only?
questions.answer: *Glibness* requires only a verbal component (V); it has no somatic (S) or material (M) components.

questions.question: Which classes can cast *Glibness* (i.e., which spell lists include it)?
questions.answer: *Glibness* is on the Bard and Warlock spell lists.

questions.question: If I cast *globe of invulnerability*, what spell levels does it block by default, and how does that change if I upcast it with a 7th-level slot?
questions.answer: By default, the globe blocks any spell of 5th level or lower cast from outside the barrier from affecting creatures or objects within it (even if that spell was cast using a higher-level spell slot). If you cast *globe of invulnerability* using a 7th-level slot, the barrier blocks spells of 6th level or lower (it blocks spells of one level higher for each slot level above 6th).

questions.question: For *glyph of warding* (explosive runes), what saving throw does a creature make and what damage does it take on a failed save (including the possible damage types)?
questions.answer: Each creature in the 20-foot-radius sphere makes a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save it takes 5d8 damage of a type you choose when creating the glyph: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder (half damage on a successful save).

questions.question: If you cast *glyph of warding* inside a closable object (like a chest) and someone later moves that object, how far can it be moved before the glyph breaks, and does it trigger when it breaks?
questions.answer: For a glyph inscribed within an object, the object must remain in its place; if it’s moved more than 10 feet from where the spell was cast, the glyph is broken and the spell ends without being triggered.

questions.question: If you create a *glyph of warding* as a spell glyph and store a spell that normally requires concentration, how long does the stored spell last after the glyph is triggered?
questions.answer: When the glyph is triggered, the stored spell is cast, and if that stored spell requires concentration, it lasts until the end of its full duration (no concentration required).

questions.question: If a character searches for a *glyph of warding*, what kind of check do they make to spot it, and what’s the DC based on?
questions.answer: A glyph of warding is nearly invisible and can be found only with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against the caster’s spell save DC.

questions.question: When casting *glyph of warding*, what material components do you need, what’s their minimum cost, and does the spell consume them?
questions.answer: It requires incense and powdered diamond worth at least 200 gp, and the spell consumes those materials.

questions.question: For the Goodberry spell, how long do the created berries remain potent if they aren’t eaten?
questions.answer: The berries lose their potency if they haven’t been consumed within 24 hours of casting the spell.

questions.question: When you cast Goodberry, how many berries can you create, and what does eating one berry do in terms of action economy and healing?
questions.answer: Casting Goodberry creates up to ten berries in your hand. A creature can use its action to eat one berry, which restores 1 hit point (and also provides enough nourishment to sustain the creature for one day).

questions.question: When casting Goodberry in combat, what’s its casting time and range, and does it require any material component?
questions.answer: Goodberry has a casting time of 1 action and a range of Touch. It uses components V, S, and M, with the material component being a sprig of mistletoe.

questions.question: If a character eats a berry created by the *Goodberry* spell, does it provide enough food for the day in addition to any healing, and how much healing does one berry restore?
questions.answer: Yes. Eating one goodberry restores 1 hit point, and it provides enough nourishment to sustain a creature for one day.

questions.question: Which character classes have the *Goodberry* spell on their spell list?
questions.answer: *Goodberry* is available to Druids and Rangers.

questions.question: When you cast *Grease*, what area does it cover, and when do creatures in that area have to make Dexterity saving throws to avoid falling prone?
questions.answer: *Grease* covers the ground in a 10-foot square centered on a point within 60 feet, turning it into difficult terrain for 1 minute. Each creature standing in the area when the grease appears must make a Dexterity saving throw or fall prone, and a creature must also make the save when it enters the area or ends its turn there (falling prone on a failure).

questions.question: When casting the *Grease* spell, what are its casting time and range, and what specific material component is required?
questions.answer: *Grease* has a casting time of 1 action and a range of 60 feet. Its components are V, S, M, with the material component being “a bit of pork rind or butter.”

questions.question: When you cast *Grease*, does the slick area count as difficult terrain, and how long does the spell last?
questions.answer: Yes. The grease-covered area becomes difficult terrain, and the spell’s duration is **1 minute**.

questions.question: Which class can prepare or learn the *Grease* spell from its spell list in the SRD?
questions.answer: *Grease* is on the Wizard spell list (Classes: Wizard).

questions.question: Does the *Grease* spell require concentration to maintain?
questions.answer: No. *Grease* lasts for 1 minute and does not require concentration.

questions.question: For the Greater Invisibility spell, what is its range and how long does the invisibility last?
questions.answer: Range: Touch. Duration: Up to 1 minute (the target you touch remains invisible until the spell ends).

questions.question: When you cast *greater invisibility* on a creature, do the target’s worn and carried items also become invisible, and under what condition?
questions.answer: Yes. Anything the target is wearing or carrying becomes invisible as long as it remains on the target’s person.

questions.question: When casting *greater invisibility*, what components do you need to provide?
questions.answer: It requires verbal and somatic components (V, S).

questions.question: In play, how long does it take to cast *greater invisibility*, and can you target yourself with it or only another creature?
questions.answer: It has a casting time of 1 action, and you can cast it on yourself or on a creature you touch.

questions.question: Which classes can learn or prepare the *greater invisibility* spell in the SRD?
questions.answer: Bard, Druid, Sorcerer, Warlock, and Wizard.

questions.question: When you cast Greater Restoration, what kinds of conditions or effects can it remove from the creature you touch?
questions.answer: Greater Restoration can either reduce the target’s exhaustion level by 1, or end one of these effects on the target: an effect that charmed or petrified it; one curse (including attunement to a cursed magic item); any reduction to one of its ability scores; or one effect reducing its hit point maximum.

questions.question: When casting Greater Restoration, what material component do you need, and does the spell consume it?
questions.answer: Greater Restoration requires diamond dust worth at least 100 gp as its material component, and the spell consumes the diamond dust.

questions.question: Does Greater Restoration require concentration, and how long does its effect last?
questions.answer: No—Greater Restoration does not require concentration. Its duration is instantaneous.

questions.question: Which character classes can prepare or learn the spell *Greater Restoration* in the SRD?
questions.answer: Bard, Cleric, and Druid.

questions.question: In play, how long does it take to cast *Greater Restoration*, and what range do you need to be within to use it?
questions.answer: It has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **Touch**.

questions.question: For the Guardian of Faith spell, what saving throw does a hostile creature make when it first moves within 10 feet of the guardian on a turn, and how much damage does it take on a failed vs. successful save?
questions.answer: The creature must make a Dexterity saving throw. It takes 20 radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful save.

questions.question: For the spell *Guardian of Faith*, how long does the guardian remain, and what condition makes it vanish before the duration ends?
questions.answer: It lasts for 8 hours, and it vanishes early once it has dealt a total of 60 damage.

questions.question: When you cast *Guardian of Faith*, where can you place the spectral guardian, and does it occupy that space?
questions.answer: You cause a Large spectral guardian to appear in an unoccupied space of your choice that you can see within the spell’s 30-foot range, and the guardian occupies that space.

questions.question: When casting *Guardian of Faith*, what spell components do you need (verbal, somatic, and/or material)?
questions.answer: *Guardian of Faith* requires only a verbal component (V)—no somatic or material components.

questions.question: In play, how long does it take to cast *Guardian of Faith*, and what is its casting range?
questions.answer: *Guardian of Faith* has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **30 feet**.

questions.question: When you cast *Guards and Wards*, what effect does it create in corridors, and what is the chance an intruder will think they’re going the opposite direction at an intersection?
questions.answer: In the warded area’s corridors, fog fills them, making the corridors heavily obscured. At each intersection or branching passage offering a choice of direction, there is a 50 percent chance that a creature other than you will believe it is going in the opposite direction from the one it chooses.

questions.question: When you cast *Guards and Wards* on a stronghold, what does it do to doors in the warded area, and how many doors can you disguise to look like plain walls?
questions.answer: All doors in the warded area become magically locked as if affected by *arcane lock*. In addition, you can disguise up to ten doors with an illusion (like the illusory object option of *minor illusion*) so they appear to be plain sections of wall.

questions.question: Under *Guards and Wards*, what happens to stairways in the warded area, and how long does it take for the effect to restore itself if the webs are burned or torn away?
questions.answer: All stairs in the warded area are filled with webs from top to bottom (as the *web* spell). If the strands are burned or torn away while *guards and wards* lasts, they regrow in 10 minutes.

questions.question: When casting *Guards and Wards*, how much floor space can the ward cover, and what’s the maximum height of the warded area?
questions.answer: The spell can protect up to **2,500 square feet of floor space** (e.g., a 50-foot square), and the warded area can be up to **20 feet tall** (shaped as you desire).

questions.question: If a creature casts *dispel magic* on one of the effects created by *guards and wards*, does it bring down the whole ward, or only that specific effect?
questions.answer: A *dispel magic* cast on a specific *guards and wards* effect, if successful, removes only that effect—not the entire ward.

questions.question: For the Guidance cantrip, how long does the spell last, and what bonus can the touched creature apply to an ability check before it ends?
questions.answer: Duration: up to 1 minute. Once before the spell ends, the willing creature you touch can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to one ability check of its choice (rolling the die before or after the check); the spell then ends.

questions.question: In play, what are Guidance’s casting time, range, and components?
questions.answer: Guidance has a casting time of 1 action, a range of Touch, and components V, S.

questions.question: Which classes have the Guidance cantrip on their spell list?
questions.answer: Cleric and Druid.

questions.question: When a creature has Guidance on it and makes an ability check, can it wait until after rolling the check to decide whether to add the Guidance d4?
questions.answer: Yes. The target can roll the d4 and add it to one ability check of its choice, and it can roll the die before or after making the ability check; after it adds the die, the spell ends.

questions.question: Can you cast Guidance on an unwilling or hostile creature, and how many creatures can the spell affect with one casting?
questions.answer: No—Guidance requires you to touch **one willing creature**, so it can’t be cast on an unwilling/hostile target and it affects only a single creature per casting.

questions.question: For the spell *Guiding Bolt*, what extra effect does it apply on a hit, and how long does that benefit last?
questions.answer: On a hit, the target takes 4d6 radiant damage and the next attack roll made against that target before the end of your next turn has advantage (the target glitters with dim light until then).

questions.question: If you cast *Guiding Bolt* using a 3rd-level spell slot, how many d6 of radiant damage does it deal on a hit?
questions.answer: On a hit it deals **6d6 radiant damage** (base 4d6, plus 1d6 for each slot level above 1st).

questions.question: For the spell *Guiding Bolt*, what is its range, and what components are required to cast it?
questions.answer: *Guiding Bolt* has a range of **120 feet** and requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**.

questions.question: Does *Guiding Bolt* require concentration, and what is its listed duration?
questions.answer: No—*Guiding Bolt* does not require concentration. Its duration is **1 round**.

questions.question: When you cast *Guiding Bolt*, do you make an attack roll or force a saving throw—and if it’s an attack, what kind is it?
questions.answer: You make an attack roll: *Guiding Bolt* requires a **ranged spell attack** against the target (no saving throw).

questions.question: For the *gust of wind* spell, what saving throw does a creature make at the start of its turn in the line, and what happens to it on a failed save?
questions.answer: Each creature that starts its turn in the line must make a Strength saving throw; on a failed save, it’s pushed 15 feet away from you in a direction following the line.

questions.question: While *gust of wind* is active, what movement penalty applies to a creature in the line that tries to move closer to you, and how (if at all) can you change the line’s direction during the spell?
questions.answer: Any creature in the line must spend 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves when moving closer to you. As a bonus action on each of your turns before the spell ends, you can change the direction in which the 60-foot-long, 10-foot-wide line blasts from you.

questions.question: If you cast *gust of wind*, how does the wind affect gases/vapors and flames in the spell’s area (unprotected vs. protected flames like lanterns)?
questions.answer: The gust disperses gas or vapor. It extinguishes candles, torches, and similar unprotected flames in the area, and it makes protected flames (such as lantern flames) dance wildly and gives them a 50 percent chance to be extinguished.

questions.question: When you cast *gust of wind*, what is the size of the wind’s area of effect (length and width), and how long can the spell last?
questions.answer: It creates a line of strong wind 60 feet long and 10 feet wide, and it lasts up to 1 minute.

questions.question: When casting *gust of wind*, what components are required, and what is the material component?
questions.answer: It requires verbal, somatic, and material components (V, S, M), and the material component is a legume seed.

questions.question: For the **Hallow** spell’s optional extra effect, when does a creature have to make its saving throw, what type of save is it, and what happens on a successful save?
questions.answer: A creature that would be affected makes a **Charisma saving throw** when it **enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there**. On a success, it **ignores the extra effect until it leaves the area**.

questions.question: When you cast **Hallow**, which creature types are unable to enter the affected area, and what three hostile actions are those creatures also prevented from doing to creatures inside the area?
questions.answer: Celestials, elementals, fey, fiends, and undead can’t enter the area, and those creatures also can’t charm, frighten, or possess creatures within it.

questions.question: If you cast **Hallow** and choose the **Darkness** extra effect, what kinds of light are unable to illuminate the area?
questions.answer: With the **Darkness** effect, darkness fills the area; **normal light** can’t illuminate it, and **magical light created by spells of a lower level than the slot used to cast Hallow** also can’t illuminate it.

questions.question: For the **Hallow** spell, what material component do you need, what’s its minimum gold cost, and is that material consumed by the spell?
questions.answer: It requires **herbs, oils, and incense worth at least 1,000 gp**, and **the spell consumes** those materials.

questions.question: If I cast *hallow* in an area that overlaps the radius of an existing *hallow* effect, what happens to the spell?
questions.answer: The spell fails if the radius you choose includes any area already under the effect of a *hallow* spell.

questions.question: For the spell *Hallucinatory Terrain*, what size area can you alter, and what kind of check can a creature make to disbelieve the illusion if touch doesn’t give it away?
questions.answer: You can alter natural terrain in a 150-foot cube within range. If the difference isn’t obvious by touch, a creature carefully examining the illusion can make an Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC to disbelieve it.

questions.question: When you cast *Hallucinatory Terrain*, what senses of the terrain does the illusion change, and what aspects of the area remain unchanged (including how it feels and whether structures/creatures are altered)?
questions.answer: The spell makes natural terrain in the area look, sound, and smell like other natural terrain. Its tactile characteristics are unchanged, and manufactured structures, equipment, and creatures within the area aren’t changed in appearance.

questions.question: For *Hallucinatory Terrain*, what’s the casting time, how long does the illusion last, and what material components do you need?
questions.answer: It takes **10 minutes** to cast, lasts **24 hours**, and requires **V, S, M** components—specifically **a stone, a twig, and a bit of green plant**.

questions.question: For *Hallucinatory Terrain*, what’s the spell’s range, and which classes can cast it?
questions.answer: It has a range of **300 feet**, and it’s available to **Bard, Druid, Warlock, and Wizard**.

questions.question: When you cast *Harm*, what saving throw does the target make, how much damage does it take on a failed vs successful save, and can the damage reduce it below 1 hit point?
questions.answer: The target makes a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save it takes 14d6 necrotic damage; on a successful save it takes half as much. The damage can’t reduce the target’s hit points below 1.

questions.question: When a creature fails its saving throw against *Harm*, how long is its hit point maximum reduced, by how much is it reduced, and what can end the reduction early?
questions.answer: On a failed save, the creature’s hit point maximum is reduced for 1 hour by an amount equal to the necrotic damage it took. Any effect that removes a disease lets its hit point maximum return to normal before the hour is up.

questions.question: During combat, if a cleric wants to cast *Harm*, what are the spell’s casting time and range, and what components are required (does it need any material component)?
questions.answer: *Harm* has a casting time of 1 action and a range of 60 feet. Its components are V and S only—no material component is required.

questions.question: In combat, can you cast *Harm* on a creature you can’t see (for example, one behind total cover or invisible), and does the spell have any lasting duration or concentration requirement?
questions.answer: You must target “a creature that you can see within range,” so you can’t cast *Harm* on a creature you can’t see. The spell’s duration is **instantaneous**, so it doesn’t last over time and doesn’t require concentration.

questions.question: For preparing a cleric’s spell list, what level and school is *Harm*, and which class can cast it (per the SRD)?
questions.answer: *Harm* is a 6th-level Necromancy spell, and it’s on the Cleric class spell list.

questions.question: When you cast **Haste**, what options can the target use the spell’s extra action for, and what happens to the target when the spell ends?
questions.answer: The target gains an additional action on each of its turns, but that action can be used only to take the Attack (one weapon attack only), Dash, Disengage, Hide, or Use an Object action. When the spell ends, the target can’t move or take actions until after its next turn as lethargy sweeps over it.

questions.question: When you cast **Haste**, what’s its range, and what specific material component do you need?
questions.answer: Haste has a range of **30 feet**, and it requires **a shaving of licorice root** as the material component (along with V and S components).

questions.question: When you cast **Haste**, what specific bonuses does the target gain to its speed, Armor Class, and Dexterity saving throws while the spell lasts?
questions.answer: Until the spell ends, the target’s speed is doubled, it gains a +2 bonus to AC, and it has advantage on Dexterity saving throws.

questions.question: Which classes can cast the **Haste** spell (i.e., which class spell lists include it in the SRD)?
questions.answer: In the SRD, **Haste** is available to the following classes: **Druid, Paladin, Sorcerer, and Wizard**.

questions.question: When you cast **Haste**, what are the targeting requirements—does the creature have to be willing, and do you need to be able to see it?
questions.answer: You must choose **a willing creature that you can see** within the spell’s range.

questions.question: If you cast the **Heal** spell using an 8th-level spell slot, how many hit points does the target regain?
questions.answer: 90 hit points (Heal restores 70 HP at 6th level, and upcasting adds +10 HP per slot level above 6th, so +20 at 8th level).

questions.question: When you cast **Heal**, what conditions or effects does the spell automatically end on the creature you heal?
questions.answer: Heal ends **blindness**, **deafness**, and **any diseases** affecting the target.

questions.question: If you cast **Heal** on a target, can it restore hit points to constructs or undead?
questions.answer: No. **Heal** has no effect on constructs or undead.

questions.question: When you cast the **Heal** spell, what are its casting time, range, and spell components?
questions.answer: **Casting Time:** 1 action; **Range:** 60 feet; **Components:** V, S.

questions.question: Does the **Heal** spell require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: Heal does not require concentration; its duration is **instantaneous**.

questions.question: When you cast *healing word* using a higher-level spell slot, how does the amount of healing scale with slot level?
questions.answer: If you cast *healing word* with a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the healing increases by 1d4 for each slot level above 1st.

questions.question: When casting *healing word*, do you need line of sight to the target, and can it restore hit points to undead or constructs?
questions.answer: You must be able to see the creature you’re targeting (“a creature of your choice that you can see within range”), and the spell has no effect on undead or constructs.

questions.question: In combat, can you cast *healing word* as a bonus action, and does it require any somatic or material components?
questions.answer: Yes. *Healing word* has a casting time of **1 bonus action**, and its components are **V only** (verbal), so it requires **no somatic or material components**.

questions.question: In play, how far away can you target *healing word*, and does it last/concentrate or is the healing immediate?
questions.answer: *Healing word* has a range of 60 feet, and its duration is instantaneous (the healing happens immediately; no concentration).

questions.question: Which classes can cast *healing word* (i.e., which class spell lists include it in the SRD)?
questions.answer: *Healing word* is on the Bard, Cleric, and Druid spell lists.

questions.question: With *heat metal*, what saving throw does a creature holding or wearing the heated object make to avoid dropping it, and what penalty applies if it doesn’t drop the object?
questions.answer: The creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or drop the object if it can. If it doesn’t drop it, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the start of your next turn.

questions.question: When you cast *heat metal*, what damage does it deal initially, and what action can you take on later turns to deal the damage again while the spell lasts?
questions.answer: On casting, any creature in physical contact with the chosen metal object takes 2d8 fire damage. Until the spell ends (up to 1 minute), you can use a bonus action on each of your subsequent turns to cause the damage again.

questions.question: For *Hellish Rebuke*, what saving throw does the target make, and how much damage does it take on a failed save versus a successful one?
questions.answer: The target makes a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save it takes 2d10 fire damage; on a successful save it takes half as much damage.

questions.question: When can you cast *Hellish Rebuke* (what’s the reaction trigger), and what’s the spell’s range?
questions.answer: You cast *Hellish Rebuke* as **1 reaction** in response to **being damaged by a creature within 60 feet of you that you can see**. Its **range is 60 feet**.

questions.question: Does *Hellish Rebuke* require concentration, and what components does it use?
questions.answer: No—its duration is **Instantaneous** (so it doesn’t require concentration). Its components are **V, S**.

questions.question: If you cast *Hellish Rebuke* using a higher-level spell slot, how does its damage scale with the slot level?
questions.answer: When you cast *Hellish Rebuke* with a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by **1d10** for each slot level above 1st.

questions.question: Which classes have *Hellish Rebuke* on their spell list?
questions.answer: *Hellish Rebuke* is available to Paladins and Warlocks.

questions.question: When you cast Heroes’ Feast, how many creatures can eat it, and how long do the spell’s benefits last after the feast is finished?
questions.answer: Up to twelve other creatures can partake of the feast (12 creatures besides you), and the benefits last for 24 hours (after the 1 hour meal is finished).

questions.question: For Heroes’ Feast, what material component do you need, what minimum value must it have, and is it consumed by the spell?
questions.answer: It requires a gem-encrusted bowl worth at least 1,000 gp, and the spell consumes the bowl.

questions.question: For the Heroes’ Feast spell, when do the feast’s beneficial effects actually take effect, and what saving throws (if any) does a creature make with advantage afterward?
questions.answer: The feast takes 1 hour to consume, and the spell’s beneficial effects don’t set in until that hour is over. Afterward, a creature that partook makes all Wisdom saving throws with advantage.

questions.question: After a creature finishes eating a Heroes’ Feast, what specific ailments does it cure, and what immunities does it grant?
questions.answer: A creature that partakes of Heroes’ Feast is cured of all diseases and poison, and it becomes immune to poison and to being frightened.

questions.question: When a creature finishes the Heroes’ Feast and gains the spell’s benefits, how does it affect that creature’s hit points and hit point maximum?
questions.answer: A creature that partakes of the feast has its hit point maximum increase by 2d10, and it also gains the same number of hit points.

questions.question: For the Heroism spell, how many temporary hit points does the target gain, when do they gain them, and what happens to any remaining temporary hit points when the spell ends?
questions.answer: While Heroism lasts, the willing creature you touch gains temporary hit points equal to your spellcasting ability modifier at the start of each of its turns; when the spell ends, the target loses any remaining temporary hit points from this spell.

questions.question: During combat, if I want to cast *heroism* on an ally, what’s the spell’s casting time, range, and required components (V/S/M)?
questions.answer: *Heroism* has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **Touch**, and it requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)** (no material component).

questions.question: When I cast *heroism* on an ally, how long does the effect last, and what condition is the target immune to for the duration?
questions.answer: The spell lasts up to 1 minute, and for that duration the target is immune to being frightened.

questions.question: Which character classes can cast the *heroism* spell (i.e., have it on their spell list in the SRD)?
questions.answer: Bard and Paladin.

questions.question: Can you cast *heroism* on an unwilling creature (like an enemy), or does the target have to be willing?
questions.answer: The target has to be willing: *heroism* affects “a willing creature you touch,” so you can’t cast it on an unwilling creature.

questions.question: When you cast Hideous Laughter, what saving throw does the target make, what conditions happen on a failed save, and how can the target end the spell early?
questions.answer: The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it falls prone, becomes incapacitated, and can’t stand up for the duration. The target can make another Wisdom saving throw at the end of each of its turns and each time it takes damage (with advantage on the save if it’s triggered by damage); on a successful save, the spell ends.

questions.question: For Hideous Laughter, what’s the spell’s range and what material components do you need to cast it?
questions.answer: Range: 30 feet. Material components: tiny tarts and a feather that is waved in the air.

questions.question: Hideous Laughter: what Intelligence score (or lower) makes a creature unaffected by the spell?
questions.answer: A creature with an Intelligence score of 4 or less isn’t affected.

questions.question: In the SRD version of *Hideous Laughter*, which classes can cast the spell, and what’s its casting time?
questions.answer: It’s on the Bard, Warlock, and Wizard spell lists, and it has a casting time of 1 action.

questions.question: What spell level and school is *Hideous Laughter*?
questions.answer: *Hideous Laughter* is a 1st-level Enchantment spell.

questions.question: When you cast Hold Monster, what saving throw does the target make to resist, and can it attempt the save again after the initial failure?
questions.answer: The target makes a Wisdom saving throw. If it fails and is paralyzed, it can make a new Wisdom saving throw at the end of each round; on a success, the spell ends for that creature.

questions.question: If you cast *Hold Monster* using a higher-level spell slot, how does the number of targets change, and what positioning restriction is there between the targets?
questions.answer: When you cast *Hold Monster* with a 6th-level or higher spell slot, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 5th. The creatures must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them.

questions.question: When you cast *Hold Monster*, what’s its range, and what material component do you need?
questions.answer: *Hold Monster* has a range of **90 feet** and requires a material component of **a small piece of iron** (components: V, S, M).

questions.question: If a creature fails its initial saving throw against *Hold Monster*, what condition does the spell impose on it (and for how long, assuming it keeps failing subsequent saves)?
questions.answer: On a failed Wisdom saving throw, the target is **paralyzed** for the spell’s duration—**up to 1 minute** (ending early if it later succeeds on a Wisdom save at the end of a round).

questions.question: Does *Hold Monster* work on undead targets, or is there any creature type it has no effect against?
questions.answer: *Hold Monster* has no effect against the undead.

questions.question: When a humanoid fails its initial saving throw against *hold person*, when does it get additional chances to break free, and what kind of saving throw are they?
questions.answer: After failing the initial Wisdom saving throw, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw at the end of each of its turns; on a success, the spell ends on that target.

questions.question: If you upcast *hold person* using a 5th-level spell slot, how many humanoids can you target, and what positioning restriction applies to those targets?
questions.answer: At 5th level, you can target 4 humanoids total (one additional humanoid per slot level above 2nd). All the humanoids must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them.

questions.question: What components do you need to cast *hold person*, and what is the spell’s specific material component?
questions.answer: *Hold person* has V, S, and M components; its material component is a small, straight piece of iron.

questions.question: When you cast *hold person*, how far away can the target be, and what kind of creature do you have to be able to see to target it?
questions.answer: *Hold person* has a range of 60 feet, and you choose a humanoid that you can see within that range.

questions.question: When *hold person* lands (the target fails its initial save), what condition does it inflict and what’s the maximum duration it can last?
questions.answer: On a failed initial Wisdom saving throw, the target is paralyzed for the duration; the spell’s duration is up to 1 minute.

questions.question: While Holy Aura is active, what happens when a fiend or undead hits an affected creature with a melee attack—what saving throw does the attacker make, and what’s the consequence on a failure?
