questions.answer: When a fiend or undead hits an affected creature with a melee attack, the aura flashes; the attacker must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the attacker is blinded until the spell ends.

questions.question: When you cast **Holy Aura**, what’s the size of the aura around you, and what effects do the creatures you choose in that area gain (including any light they shed and how attacks/saving throws are affected)?
questions.answer: Holy Aura creates a **30-foot radius** aura centered on you. Creatures of your choice in that radius when you cast the spell **shed dim light in a 5-foot radius**, have **advantage on all saving throws**, and **other creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls against them** until the spell ends (up to 1 minute).

questions.question: What material component (including its minimum value) is required to cast **Holy Aura**?
questions.answer: Holy Aura requires a material component: a tiny reliquary worth at least 1,000 gp containing a sacred relic (for example, a scrap of cloth from a saint’s robe or a piece of parchment from a religious text).

questions.question: During play, if someone wants to cast **Holy Aura**, what are the spell’s casting time, range, and duration?
questions.answer: Holy Aura has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **Self**, and a duration of **up to 1 minute**.

questions.question: For **Holy Aura**, do creatures gain the spell’s benefits if they enter your 30-foot aura later, or only if they’re in the area when you cast it—and can you choose which creatures are affected?
questions.answer: Only creatures of your choice that are within the 30-foot radius **when you cast the spell** are affected; the spell specifies “Creatures of your choice in that radius when you cast this spell…”.

questions.question: When a creature affected by *hunter’s mark* drops to 0 hit points before the spell ends, can you move the mark to another creature, and what kind of action does that take?
questions.answer: Yes. If the marked target drops to 0 hit points before the spell ends, you can use a **bonus action on a subsequent turn** to mark a new creature.

questions.question: When you cast *Hypnotic Pattern*, what saving throw do creatures make, and what can end the spell’s effect on an affected creature before the duration expires?
questions.answer: Creatures who see the pattern in the area must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save they’re charmed for the duration (incapacitated and speed 0), but the effect ends early for a creature if it takes any damage or if another creature uses an action to shake it out of its stupor.

questions.question: When you cast *Hypnotic Pattern*, what’s the spell’s range, and what size/shape area does the pattern fill?
questions.answer: The spell has a range of 120 feet, and it creates the pattern inside a 30-foot cube within that range.

questions.question: When you cast *ice storm*, what saving throw do creatures in the area make, and what damage do they take on a failed save versus a successful one?
questions.answer: Creatures in the cylinder make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 2d8 bludgeoning damage plus 4d6 cold damage; on a successful save, it takes half as much damage.

questions.question: When you cast *ice storm*, what is the spell’s area of effect (shape and dimensions), and how long does that area remain difficult terrain?
questions.answer: It creates a 20-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder centered on a point within 300 feet. The hailstones make the spell’s area difficult terrain until the end of your next turn.

questions.question: When you upcast *ice storm* using a 5th-level slot or higher, how does the spell’s damage scale—what damage type increases, and by how much per slot level above 4th?
questions.answer: Only the bludgeoning damage increases: it goes up by 1d8 for each spell slot level above 4th (starting when cast with a 5th-level slot or higher).

questions.question: For the *identify* spell, what’s the casting time and what material components (including any minimum value) do you need to provide?
questions.answer: Identify has a casting time of **1 minute** and requires material components of **a pearl worth at least 100 gp and an owl feather** (along with verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: When you cast *identify* on a magic item, what specific information can the spell reveal about the item (including attunement and charges)?
questions.answer: You must touch the object throughout the casting. If it’s a magic item or other magic-imbued object, you learn its properties and how to use them, whether it requires attunement, and how many charges it has (if any). You also learn whether any spells are affecting it and what they are, and if it was created by a spell, you learn which spell created it.

questions.question: If you cast *identify* while touching a creature for the full casting time, what information do you learn about that creature?
questions.answer: You learn what spells, if any, are currently affecting the creature.

questions.question: Which classes can cast the *identify* spell?
questions.answer: *Identify* is available to the Bard, Cleric, Ritual Caster, and Wizard.

questions.question: For the **Illusory Script** spell, what material component do you need, and does the spell consume it?
questions.answer: It requires **lead-based ink worth at least 10 gp**, and the spell **consumes** the ink.

questions.question: For the Illusory Script spell, who can read the hidden message, and what happens to the writing if the spell is dispelled?
questions.answer: Only you and any creatures you designate when you cast the spell can read the writing normally; a creature with truesight can also read the hidden message. If the spell is dispelled, both the original script and the illusion disappear.

questions.question: When you cast *Illusory Script* to make the writing look like a completely different message, what limitation is there on the language you can have it appear in?
questions.answer: The illusory writing can be in a different hand and language, but the language must be one you know.

questions.question: During play, if I want to use *Illusory Script* to ward a note, how long does the illusion last, and what’s the spell’s casting time?
questions.answer: *Illusory Script* has a casting time of 1 minute, and the illusion lasts for 10 days.

questions.question: In play, if I want to cast *Illusory Script* quietly, does the spell have a verbal component, and what range do I need to be at to cast it?
questions.answer: *Illusory Script* has no verbal component (its components are S, M), and its range is Touch.

questions.question: If someone tries to free a creature trapped by the *imprisonment* spell using *dispel magic*, what level does *dispel magic* have to be cast at, and what does it need to target?
questions.answer: *Dispel magic* can end *imprisonment* only if it is cast as a 9th-level spell, and it must target either the prison itself or the special component used to create it.

questions.question: When you cast *imprisonment* on a creature, what saving throw does it make, and what happens if it succeeds on that save?
questions.answer: The target makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a successful save, it isn’t bound by the spell and becomes immune to *imprisonment* if you cast it again.

questions.question: If a wizard casts *imprisonment* a second time using the same special component (mithral orb, jade miniature, gemstone, etc.), what happens to the creature that was trapped by the first casting?
questions.answer: A particular special component can create only one prison at a time. If you cast *imprisonment* again using the same component, the target of the first casting is immediately freed from its binding.

questions.question: With *imprisonment* (Minimus Containment version), what can pass through the gemstone prison, and can the gemstone be cut or broken while the spell is in effect?
questions.answer: In Minimus Containment, light can pass through the gemstone normally (so the target can see out and others can see in), but nothing else can pass through it—even via teleportation or planar travel—and the gemstone can’t be cut or broken while the spell remains in effect.

questions.question: While a creature is bound by the *imprisonment* spell, can divination magic locate or perceive it, and does the creature need to breathe, eat, or drink (or age) during the imprisonment?
questions.answer: No—divination spells can’t locate or perceive the target. While affected, the creature doesn’t need to breathe, eat, or drink, and it doesn’t age.

questions.question: When does a creature have to make the Dexterity saving throw against the Incendiary Cloud spell?
questions.answer: A creature makes the Dexterity saving throw when the cloud appears (if it’s in the area), and again whenever it enters the spell’s area for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there.

questions.question: What wind conditions can end (disperse) an Incendiary Cloud early, and what minimum wind speed does the spell specify?
questions.answer: Incendiary Cloud ends early if a wind of moderate or greater speed disperses it; the spell specifies this as at least 10 miles per hour.

questions.question: For the Incendiary Cloud spell, how far does the cloud move each round, and when do you choose the direction it moves?
questions.answer: At the start of each of your turns, you choose a direction, and the cloud moves 10 feet directly away from you in that direction.

questions.question: For Incendiary Cloud, does the cloud spread around corners, and what visibility condition does it impose in its area?
questions.answer: Yes—Incendiary Cloud spreads around corners, and its area is heavily obscured.

questions.question: When a creature fails or succeeds on the saving throw against **Incendiary Cloud**, how much damage does it take?
questions.answer: A creature takes **10d8 fire damage** on a failed Dexterity saving throw, or **half as much damage** on a successful save.

questions.question: If a cleric casts *Inflict Wounds* using a 3rd-level spell slot, what damage does it deal on a hit?
questions.answer: You make a melee spell attack; on a hit the target takes 5d10 necrotic damage (3d10 base, plus 1d10 per slot level above 1st).

questions.question: When you cast *Inflict Wounds*, do you make an attack roll or does the target make a saving throw—and what kind of roll is it?
questions.answer: You make a **melee spell attack** against a creature you can reach; on a hit it takes **3d10 necrotic damage** (no saving throw is listed).

questions.question: When casting *Inflict Wounds*, do you need to maintain concentration—and what is the spell’s duration?
questions.answer: No. *Inflict Wounds* does not require concentration; its duration is instantaneous.

questions.question: What components do you need to cast *Inflict Wounds* (verbal, somatic, and/or material)?
questions.answer: *Inflict Wounds* requires verbal and somatic components only (V, S); it has no material component.

questions.question: In combat, how long does it take to cast *Inflict Wounds*, and what range do you need to be at to use it?
questions.answer: *Inflict Wounds* has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **Touch**.

questions.question: For the Insect Plague spell, what saving throw does a creature make and when is it required to roll it?
questions.answer: A creature makes a Constitution saving throw when the area appears (if it’s in the area), and again whenever it enters the spell’s area for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there.

questions.question: For Insect Plague, what size/shape is the affected area, and what effects does the spell create within that area (including whether it spreads around corners)?
questions.answer: It creates a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point within range; the sphere spreads around corners, the area is lightly obscured, and it becomes difficult terrain for the duration.

questions.question: If you upcast **Insect Plague** using a 6th-level or higher spell slot, how does the spell’s damage scale with the slot level?
questions.answer: When cast with a spell slot of 6th level or higher, **Insect Plague** increases its damage by **1d10** for each slot level above 5th.

questions.question: What material components do you need to cast **Insect Plague**?
questions.answer: Insect Plague requires material components of a few grains of sugar, some kernels of grain, and a smear of fat (in addition to verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: Which classes can cast the spell *Insect Plague*?
questions.answer: *Insect Plague* is available to Clerics, Druids, and Sorcerers.

questions.question: With the *Instant Summons* spell, what happens when you crush the sapphire to summon the marked object, but another creature is currently holding or carrying that object?
questions.answer: Crushing the sapphire does **not** transport the item to you. Instead, you learn who has the object and roughly where that creature is located at that moment.

questions.question: For *Instant Summons*, what size and weight limits must the object meet to be eligible as the spell’s target?
questions.answer: You must touch an object that weighs 10 pounds or less and whose longest dimension is 6 feet or less.

questions.question: If you want to cancel or shut down an *Instant Summons* that’s still active, what can end the spell besides crushing the sapphire to summon the item?
questions.answer: Successfully applying *dispel magic* (or a similar effect) to the sapphire ends *instant summons*’s effect.

questions.question: If I cast *Instant Summons* more than once, can I reuse the same sapphire material component, and what happens to the sapphire when I mark an object?
questions.answer: No. Each time you cast *Instant Summons*, you must use a different sapphire. When you cast it, the spell invisibly inscribes the name of the touched object on the sapphire you used as the material component (and leaves an invisible mark on the object).

questions.question: Is *Instant Summons* a ritual, and what’s its casting time?
questions.answer: Yes. *Instant Summons* is a 6th-level conjuration spell with the ritual tag, and it has a casting time of 1 minute.

questions.question: If I cast *Invisibility* with a higher-level spell slot, how many additional creatures can I target, and starting at what slot level does this scaling kick in?
questions.answer: When you cast *Invisibility* using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 2nd.

questions.question: If I cast *Invisibility* on someone, what actions will cause the spell to end early on that target?
questions.answer: The spell ends early for a target if it attacks or casts a spell.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast the *Invisibility* spell?
questions.answer: The material component is **an eyelash encased in gum arabic**.

questions.question: When I cast **Invisibility**, what are the spell’s casting time and range?
questions.answer: **Casting Time:** 1 action. **Range:** Touch.

questions.question: When you cast *Invisibility* on a creature, do the target’s worn or carried items also become invisible, and what’s the maximum duration the spell can last if it isn’t broken early?
questions.answer: Yes. Anything the target is wearing or carrying becomes invisible as long as it remains on the target’s person. The spell’s duration is up to 1 hour.

questions.question: For Irresistible Dance, what kind of saving throw can the affected creature use to end the spell early, and what action does it take to attempt it?
questions.answer: The affected creature can use its action to make a Wisdom saving throw to regain control of itself; on a successful save, the spell ends.

questions.question: When a creature is affected by *Irresistible Dance*, what combat advantages/disadvantages apply (to the target’s rolls and to other creatures’ attacks against it)?
questions.answer: The dancing creature has disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws and on attack rolls, and other creatures have advantage on attack rolls against it while the spell lasts.

questions.question: Does *Irresistible Dance* require concentration, and what’s its duration?
questions.answer: It does **not** require concentration (the duration line doesn’t list concentration); it lasts **up to 1 minute**.

questions.question: If a creature is immune to being charmed, is it affected by *Irresistible Dance* at all?
questions.answer: No. Creatures that can’t be charmed are immune to *Irresistible Dance*.

questions.question: For *Irresistible Dance*, what components do you need to cast the spell—does it require any material components?
questions.answer: *Irresistible Dance* has only a verbal (V) component and requires no somatic or material components.

questions.question: For the Jump spell, what’s the range, how long does it last, and what effect does it have on the target’s jumping distance?
questions.answer: Range: Touch. Duration: 1 minute. Effect: You touch a creature, and its jump distance is tripled until the spell ends.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast the *jump* spell?
questions.answer: The *jump* spell requires a material component: a grasshopper’s hind leg.

questions.question: If you want to cast the *jump* spell in play, which classes can learn/cast it, and what’s its casting time?
questions.answer: *Jump* is available to Druids, Rangers, Sorcerers, and Wizards, and it has a casting time of 1 action.

questions.question: When you cast *Knock* on a door sealed with *Arcane Lock*, what happens to the *Arcane Lock* effect, and how loud is the spell’s knock?
questions.answer: If the target is held shut with *Arcane Lock*, that spell is suppressed for 10 minutes, during which time the target can be opened and shut normally. Casting *Knock* also produces a loud knock audible from as far away as 300 feet.

questions.question: If I cast *Knock* on a door or chest that has multiple locks, how many of those locks does the spell unlock?
questions.answer: If the object has multiple locks, *Knock* unlocks only one of them (your choice of a target object within range).

questions.question: During a session, I need to know the basics for *Knock*: what’s its casting time, range, and components?
questions.answer: *Knock* has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **60 feet**, and it requires only a **verbal (V)** component.

questions.question: Can the *Knock* spell be used on things like manacles or a barred/stuck door, and what exactly happens to a target that’s stuck or barred?
questions.answer: Yes. *Knock* targets an object you can see within range (such as a door, box, chest, set of manacles, padlock, or another object that has a mundane or magical means that prevents access). If the object is held shut by a mundane lock, or if it is stuck or barred, it becomes unlocked, unstuck, or unbarred.

questions.question: What level and school is the *Knock* spell, and which classes can cast it?
questions.answer: *Knock* is a 2nd-level Transmutation spell. It’s on the Bard, Sorcerer, and Wizard spell lists.

questions.question: For the *legend lore* spell, what material components (including their gp values) are required, and which of them are consumed by the casting?
questions.answer: It requires V, S, and M components: "Incense worth 250 inches that fate consumes and four sticks of ivory worth 50 gp each." The incense is consumed by the casting ("fate consumes" it).

questions.question: When you cast *Legend Lore*, what do you have to name or describe, and what happens if the subject you choose isn’t of legendary importance?
questions.answer: You name or describe a person, place, or object; the spell brings to your mind a brief summary of significant lore about it. If the thing you named isn’t of legendary importance, you gain no information.

questions.question: During play, if I want to use *legend lore*, how long does it take to cast, what’s the spell’s range, and how long does the effect last?
questions.answer: *Legend lore* has a **casting time of 10 minutes**, a **range of Self**, and a **duration of Instantaneous**.

questions.question: When you cast *legend lore*, how does having more information about the person/place/object beforehand affect the lore you receive, and in what form is the information typically presented?
questions.answer: The more information you already have about the thing, the more precise and detailed the information you receive. The information is accurate, but it might be couched in figurative language.

questions.question: Which classes can cast the *legend lore* spell (i.e., which spell lists include it)?
questions.answer: *Legend lore* is available to the Bard, Cleric, and Wizard spell lists.

questions.question: If I cast *Lesser Restoration*, what conditions or ailments can it remove from the target?
questions.answer: You touch a creature and end either one disease or one condition affecting it. The condition can be blinded, deafened, paralyzed, or poisoned.

questions.question: When you cast *Lesser Restoration*, what’s its range and what components does it require?
questions.answer: *Lesser Restoration* has a range of **Touch** and requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**.

questions.question: When I cast *Lesser Restoration*, what’s its casting time and duration (is it instantaneous or does it last/concentrate)?
questions.answer: *Lesser Restoration* has a casting time of **1 action** and a duration of **Instantaneous** (no concentration).

questions.question: Which classes have *Lesser Restoration* on their spell list?
questions.answer: *Lesser Restoration* is available to Bard, Cleric, Druid, Paladin, and Ranger.

questions.question: When you cast *Lesser Restoration*, can you cure both a disease and a condition on the same target in one casting, or is it limited to only one effect?
questions.answer: It’s limited to one effect per casting: you touch a creature and end **either** one disease **or** one condition affecting it (blinded, deafened, paralyzed, or poisoned).

questions.question: When you cast *Levitate* on an unwilling creature, what saving throw does it make to resist the spell, and what happens on a successful save?
questions.answer: The target makes a Constitution saving throw; if it succeeds, it is unaffected by the spell.

questions.question: When a creature is affected by *Levitate*, how can it move horizontally, and what do you need to do (action-wise) to change its altitude or move it if it isn’t you?
questions.answer: A levitated target can move only by pushing or pulling against a fixed object or surface within reach (like a wall or ceiling), moving as if it were climbing. You can change the target’s altitude by up to 20 feet up or down on your turn. If you are the target, you can move up or down as part of your movement; otherwise, you must use your action to move the target, and it must stay within the spell’s 60-foot range.

questions.question: When you cast *Levitate*, what’s the maximum weight of a creature or object you can affect, and how far does the target rise vertically when the spell takes effect?
questions.answer: The spell can levitate a target that weighs up to 500 pounds, and the target rises vertically up to 20 feet and then remains suspended for the duration.

questions.question: If a creature is still in the air when the *Levitate* spell ends, what happens to it?
questions.answer: When the spell ends, the target floats gently to the ground if it is still aloft.

questions.question: If you cast *light* on an object a hostile creature is holding or wearing, what kind of saving throw does the creature make to avoid the spell?
questions.answer: The hostile creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw to avoid the spell.

questions.question: When you cast the *light* cantrip on an object, what are the radii of bright light and dim light it produces?
questions.answer: The affected object sheds bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet beyond that.

questions.question: For the *light* cantrip, how can the light be blocked, and what are the ways the spell can end early?
questions.answer: Completely covering the affected object with something opaque blocks the light. The spell ends early if you cast *light* again or if you dismiss it as an action.

questions.question: When you cast the *light* cantrip, how large can the object you touch be for it to be a valid target?
questions.answer: You can target one object that is no larger than 10 feet in any dimension.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast the *light* cantrip?
questions.answer: The *light* cantrip requires a material component of either a firefly or phosphorescent moss (along with verbal components).

questions.question: For the Lightning Bolt spell, what is the line’s size, and what saving throw and damage does it deal on a hit?
questions.answer: Lightning Bolt shoots out in a line 100 feet long and 5 feet wide. Each creature in the line makes a Dexterity saving throw, taking 8d6 lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

questions.question: When you cast *Lightning Bolt* using a higher-level spell slot, how does its damage scale per slot level above 3rd?
questions.answer: If you cast *Lightning Bolt* with a 4th-level or higher spell slot, the damage increases by **1d6** for each slot level above 3rd.

questions.question: When you cast *Lightning Bolt*, what happens to flammable objects in the spell’s area that aren’t being worn or carried?
questions.answer: The lightning ignites flammable objects in the area that aren’t being worn or carried.

questions.question: What material components do you need to cast *Lightning Bolt*?
questions.answer: It requires V, S, and M components; the material component is a bit of fur and a rod of amber, crystal, or glass.

questions.question: Does *Lightning Bolt* require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: No—*Lightning Bolt* does not require concentration. Its duration is **instantaneous**.

questions.question: When you cast *Locate Animals or Plants*, how far away can it detect the nearest named beast or plant, and what information do you learn about it?
questions.answer: You learn the **direction and distance** to the closest creature or plant of the named kind **within 5 miles**, if any are present.

questions.question: For *Locate Animals or Plants*, what are the casting time, range, duration, and required material component?
questions.answer: Casting time is **1 action**, range is **Self**, duration is **Instantaneous**, and the material component is **a bit of fur from a bloodhound** (components V, S, M).

questions.question: Is *Locate Animals or Plants* a ritual spell, and which classes can cast it?
questions.answer: Yes—*Locate Animals or Plants* is a 2nd-level divination spell that can be cast as a ritual. It’s available to Bards, Druids, Rangers, and Ritual Casters.

questions.question: Does *Locate Animals or Plants* require concentration to keep detecting the target, or does it resolve immediately when you cast it?
questions.answer: It resolves immediately: the spell’s duration is **Instantaneous**, so it doesn’t require concentration to maintain an ongoing effect.

questions.question: What spell level and school is *Locate Animals or Plants*?
questions.answer: *Locate Animals or Plants* is a 2nd-level divination spell.

questions.question: For the Locate Creature spell, what conditions can prevent you from sensing the target’s direction even if it’s within 1,000 feet?
questions.answer: Locate Creature fails to find the creature if it’s in a different form (for example, polymorphed), or if running water at least 10 feet wide blocks a direct path between you and the creature.

questions.question: When you cast *Locate Creature* to find the nearest creature of a specific kind (rather than a specific individual), what familiarity requirement must you have met for that kind of creature?
questions.answer: You can locate the nearest creature of that kind only if you have seen such a creature up close—within 30 feet—at least once.

questions.question: Can *Locate Creature* track a creature that’s currently in a different form (for example, transformed by *polymorph*)?
questions.answer: No. If the creature you described or named is in a different form—such as being under the effects of a *polymorph* spell—*locate creature* doesn’t locate it.

questions.question: When casting *Locate Creature*, what specific material component do you need to provide?
questions.answer: The spell requires a material component: a bit of fur from a bloodhound.

questions.question: When you cast *Locate Creature*, what’s the maximum distance the creature can be for you to sense its direction, and what additional information do you get if the creature is moving?
questions.answer: You sense the direction to the creature as long as it’s within 1,000 feet of you; if it’s moving, you also know the direction of its movement.

questions.question: For the *Locate Object* spell, how close do you need to have been to a specific object at least once in order to be able to locate that exact object later?
questions.answer: You must have seen the object up close—within 30 feet—at least once to locate that specific object.

questions.question: If the target item is inside a lead-lined container (or behind a sheet of lead), can the *locate object* spell still point you to it?
questions.answer: No. *Locate object* can’t locate an object if any thickness of lead—even a thin sheet—blocks a direct path between you and the object.

questions.question: When you cast *locate object* on an item that's currently moving, what extra information do you get beyond its direction/location?
questions.answer: If the object is in motion, you know the direction of its movement (in addition to sensing the direction to its location as long as it’s within 1,000 feet of you).

questions.question: If I haven’t seen a specific item before, can I cast *locate object* to find the nearest object of a particular kind (like a certain weapon or piece of jewelry), and what does the spell return?
questions.answer: Yes. Instead of locating a specific object you know, *locate object* can locate the nearest object of a particular kind (such as apparel, jewelry, furniture, a tool, or a weapon). When you cast it, you sense the direction to that object’s location (provided it’s within 1,000 feet of you and not blocked by lead).

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast *Locate Object*?
questions.answer: *Locate Object* requires a material component: a forked twig (along with verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: If I upcast *Longstrider* using a 3rd-level spell slot, how many creatures can I target, and how much does each target’s speed increase?
questions.answer: With a 3rd-level slot, you can target 3 creatures total (one plus one additional creature for each slot level above 1st). Each target’s speed increases by 10 feet for 1 hour.

questions.question: For the *Longstrider* spell, what’s its range and what material component do you need to cast it?
questions.answer: Range: Touch. Material component: a pinch of dirt.

questions.question: Does *Longstrider* require concentration, and how long does the effect last once cast?
questions.answer: *Longstrider* does not require concentration, and its duration is 1 hour.

questions.question: In play, how long does it take to cast *Longstrider*, and which classes can prepare or learn it?
questions.answer: *Longstrider* has a casting time of **1 action**, and it’s available to **Bard, Druid, Ranger, and Wizard**.

questions.question: For the Mage Armor spell, what does it set the target’s base AC to, and what ends the spell early?
questions.answer: Mage Armor sets the target’s base AC to 13 + its Dexterity modifier. The spell ends early if the target dons armor, or if you dismiss the spell as an action.

questions.question: During combat, if I want to cast *mage armor* on an unarmored ally, what’s the spell’s casting time, range, and material component?
questions.answer: Casting time: 1 action. Range: Touch. Material component: a piece of cured leather (components are V, S, M).

questions.question: In play, if I cast *mage armor* and then want to keep concentrating on another spell, does *mage armor* require concentration, and how long does it last if it isn’t ended early?
questions.answer: *Mage armor* does **not** require concentration (its duration is listed as simply “8 hours”). If it isn’t ended early, it lasts **8 hours**.

questions.question: Which classes have access to the *mage armor* spell, and what level and school of magic is it?
questions.answer: *Mage armor* is a 1st-level abjuration spell, and it’s available to Sorcerers and Wizards.

questions.question: For the *mage hand* cantrip, how far can you move the hand each time you control it, and what’s the maximum weight it can carry?
questions.answer: Each time you use your action to control it, you can move the hand up to 30 feet, and it can’t carry more than 10 pounds.

questions.question: For the Mage Hand cantrip, under what conditions does the spectral hand disappear before the full 1-minute duration ends, and how do you dismiss it intentionally?
questions.answer: The hand lasts for 1 minute unless you dismiss it as an action. It also vanishes early if it is ever more than 30 feet away from you, or if you cast Mage Hand again.

questions.question: Can the *mage hand* cantrip open a locked door or container, or only an unlocked one?
questions.answer: It can open **an unlocked** door or container (it doesn’t let you open locked ones).

questions.question: Can the *mage hand* cantrip be used to attack or activate magic items (like pulling a potion’s cork with a magic opener), or is it limited to nonmagical manipulation?
questions.answer: It can’t attack and it can’t activate magic items. Mage Hand is limited to simple object manipulation (e.g., manipulating objects, opening an unlocked door/container, stowing/retrieving an item from an open container, or pouring out a vial).

questions.question: During play, what are the casting time, range, and duration of the *mage hand* cantrip?
questions.answer: Casting time: 1 action. Range: 30 feet. Duration: 1 minute.

questions.question: When a creature targeted by *Magic Circle* tries to enter the circle using teleportation or interplanar travel, what saving throw does it have to make to get in?
questions.answer: It must succeed on a Charisma saving throw before it can enter the cylinder via teleportation or interplanar travel.

questions.question: For the *Magic Circle* spell, what are the cylinder’s dimensions (radius and height), and does it require concentration?
questions.answer: Magic Circle creates a **10-foot-radius**, **20-foot-tall** cylinder of magical energy centered on a point on the ground you can see within 10 feet. Its duration is **1 hour** and it is **not a concentration** spell (the duration line does not list Concentration).

questions.question: For *Magic Circle*, what material component do you need to cast the spell, what’s its minimum value, and is it consumed?
questions.answer: The material component is holy water or powdered silver and iron worth at least 100 gp, and the spell consumes it.

questions.question: When you cast *Magic Circle* and choose to have it operate in reverse, what does the circle prevent the chosen creature type from doing, and who does it protect?
questions.answer: In reverse, the circle prevents a creature of the specified type from leaving the cylinder, and it protects targets outside the cylinder.

questions.question: When you cast *Magic Circle* against a chosen creature type, what penalty does the affected creature take on its attack rolls against targets inside the circle?
questions.answer: The affected creature has disadvantage on attack rolls against targets within the cylinder.

questions.question: When you use *Magic Jar* to try to possess a humanoid, what type of saving throw does the target make, and what happens if it succeeds?
questions.answer: The target makes a Charisma saving throw. On a success, it resists the possession attempt, and you can’t try to possess it again for 24 hours.

questions.question: With *Magic Jar*, if the host body you’re possessing dies while your soul is inside it, what saving throw do you have to make and what happens on a success or failure?
questions.answer: If the host body dies while you’re possessing it, you must make a Charisma saving throw against your own spellcasting DC. On a success, you return to the container if it is within 100 feet of you; otherwise, you die.

questions.question: When you cast *magic missile*, how many darts do you create at 1st level, what damage does each dart deal, and how does the spell scale when you upcast it?
questions.answer: At 1st level, you create three glowing darts. Each dart automatically hits a creature you can see within range and deals 1d4 + 1 force damage. When cast using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, it creates one additional dart for each slot level above 1st.

questions.question: When casting *magic missile*, do you have to be able to see your targets, and can you split the darts between multiple creatures or do they all have to hit the same one?
questions.answer: Each dart hits a creature of your choice **that you can see within range**. The darts all strike simultaneously, and **you can direct them to hit one creature or several**.

questions.question: For *magic missile*, is the effect instantaneous or does it require concentration, and what are the spell’s range and components?
questions.answer: *Magic missile* has a **duration of Instantaneous** (so it does **not** require concentration). Its **range is 120 feet**, and its **components are V, S**.

questions.question: During play, if a character wants to cast *magic missile*, what’s the spell’s casting time, and which classes have it on their spell list in the SRD?
questions.answer: *Magic missile* has a casting time of **1 action**, and it’s available to **Sorcerers and Wizards**.

questions.question: When a caster uses *magic missile*, do they need to make an attack roll for the darts, or do they automatically hit—and what type of damage does each dart deal?
questions.answer: No attack roll is required—the spell says each dart hits a creature of your choice that you can see within range. Each dart deals 1d4 + 1 force damage.

questions.question: For the Magic Mouth spell, what kind of conditions can you set as the trigger, and how close to the object do those conditions have to occur?
questions.answer: The trigger can be as general or detailed as you like, but it must be based on visual or audible conditions that occur within 30 feet of the object.

questions.question: When you cast *Magic Mouth*, what material component do you need (including cost), does the spell consume it, and what’s the maximum message length you can record?
questions.answer: The spell requires a small bit of honeycomb and jade dust worth at least 10 gp, and it consumes the materials. The implanted message must be 25 words or less (though it can be spoken over as long as 10 minutes).

questions.question: When you cast *Magic Mouth*, can you make the message repeat every time the trigger happens, and how long does the spell last if it isn’t dispelled?
questions.answer: Yes. When you cast *Magic Mouth*, you can choose for the spell to end after it delivers its message once, or to remain in place and repeat the message whenever the trigger occurs. Its duration is **until dispelled**.

questions.question: For *Magic Mouth*, can you cast it on an item a creature is wearing or carrying, and when it triggers does the message come out in your voice and at what volume?
questions.answer: You must choose an object you can see that **isn't being worn or carried** by another creature. When the trigger occurs, a magical mouth appears on the object and recites the message **in your voice and at the same volume you spoke** when you recorded it.

questions.question: During play, you’re trying to set up an alarm with *Magic Mouth*—what’s the spell’s casting time and its range?
questions.answer: *Magic Mouth* has a casting time of **1 minute** and a range of **30 feet**.

questions.question: When you upcast **Magic Weapon**, what spell slot levels increase its bonus to attack and damage rolls, and what does the bonus become at each threshold?
questions.answer: Magic Weapon gives a +1 bonus normally. If cast using a spell slot of **4th level or higher**, the bonus becomes **+2**. If cast using a spell slot of **6th level or higher**, the bonus becomes **+3**.

questions.question: For the **Magic Weapon** spell, what kind of weapon can you target, and what benefit does the weapon gain for the spell’s duration?
questions.answer: You must touch a **nonmagical weapon**. Until the spell ends, it becomes a **magic weapon** and gains a **+1 bonus to attack rolls and damage rolls**.

questions.question: Does the *magic weapon* spell require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: No—*magic weapon* does not require concentration. Its duration is up to 1 hour.

questions.question: For the *magic weapon* spell, what’s the casting time and range?
questions.answer: Casting Time: 1 bonus action. Range: Touch.

questions.question: Which classes have **magic weapon** on their spell list in the SRD?
questions.answer: Cleric, Paladin, and Wizard.

questions.question: For Magnificent Mansion, how close do you have to be to the entrance to open or close the portal, and what happens to creatures still inside when the spell ends?
questions.answer: You can open or close the portal if you are within 30 feet of it. When the spell ends, any creatures inside the extradimensional space are expelled into the open spaces nearest to the entrance.

questions.question: When you cast *Magnificent Mansion*, what’s the maximum size/volume of the extradimensional dwelling you can create (how is it measured)?
questions.answer: You can create any floor plan you like, but the mansion’s space “can’t exceed 50 cubes, each cube being 10 feet on each side.”

questions.question: When you cast *Magnificent Mansion*, what are the conjured servants allowed to do—and what are they explicitly unable to do in terms of harming creatures?
questions.answer: The mansion includes a staff of 100 near-transparent servants that are completely obedient. Each can perform any task a normal human servant could, but they can’t attack or take any action that would directly harm another creature (so they can fetch things, clean, mend, serve food, etc.).

questions.question: If someone tries to carry furnishings or other objects created by *Magnificent Mansion* out through the portal, what happens to those items?
questions.answer: Any furnishings and other objects created by the spell dissipate into smoke if removed from the mansion.

questions.question: When you cast *Magnificent Mansion*, how large is the portal/entrance, and who is allowed to enter the extradimensional dwelling?
questions.answer: The spell’s one entrance is 5 feet wide and 10 feet tall. You and any creature you designate when you cast the spell can enter the extradimensional dwelling, as long as the portal remains open.

questions.question: For Major Image, what check does a creature make to determine the illusion is fake if it uses its action to examine it, and what is the DC based on?
questions.answer: A creature that uses its action to examine the image can determine it is an illusion with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC.

questions.question: When you cast Mass Cure Wounds, how many creatures can you heal at once, what area does it affect, and how much does each target heal for?
questions.answer: You choose up to six creatures in a 30-foot-radius sphere centered on a point you choose within 60 feet. Each target regains hit points equal to 3d8 + your spellcasting ability modifier.

questions.question: If you cast Mass Cure Wounds using a 7th-level spell slot, how much additional healing does each target regain compared to casting it at 5th level?
questions.answer: Each target heals an additional 2d8 hit points (the healing increases by 1d8 per slot level above 5th).

questions.question: Can Mass Cure Wounds restore hit points to undead or constructs (for example, a vampire or a golem), or does it have any effect on them?
questions.answer: It has no effect on undead or constructs—Mass Cure Wounds can’t restore hit points to them.

questions.question: In combat, if you want to use Mass Cure Wounds, what’s its casting time and range, and does it require concentration (i.e., what’s the spell’s duration)?
questions.answer: Mass Cure Wounds has a casting time of 1 action and a range of 60 feet. Its duration is instantaneous, so it doesn’t require concentration.

questions.question: For Mass Cure Wounds, what spell components are required (does it need any material components), and which classes can cast it?
questions.answer: Mass Cure Wounds requires only verbal and somatic components (V, S)—no material component. It’s available to Bards, Clerics, and Druids.

questions.question: When you cast *Mass Heal*, how many total hit points can you restore, and what additional conditions does it remove from creatures you heal?
questions.answer: *Mass Heal* restores up to 700 hit points total, divided as you choose among any number of creatures you can see within 60 feet. Creatures healed are also cured of all diseases and any effect making them blinded or deafened (and the spell has no effect on undead or constructs).

questions.question: When you cast *Mass Heal*, what’s its range, and does it have any effect on undead or constructs?
questions.answer: *Mass Heal* has a range of 60 feet and can heal any number of creatures you can see within that range, but it has no effect on undead or constructs.

questions.question: For the *Mass Heal* spell, what’s the casting time and what components does it require?
questions.answer: *Mass Heal* has a casting time of **1 action** and requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**.

questions.question: For the *Mass Heal* spell, is the healing effect instantaneous or does it last for a duration?
questions.answer: It’s instantaneous (Duration: Instantaneous).

questions.question: When casting *Mass Heal*, do you have to be able to see the creatures you’re healing, and can you split the healing among any number of visible targets?
questions.answer: Yes. You can divide up to 700 hit points as you choose among any number of creatures **that you can see** within the spell’s 60-foot range.

questions.question: If a cleric casts **Mass Healing Word** using a 5th-level spell slot, what hit points does each affected creature regain?
questions.answer: Each affected creature regains **3d4 + your spellcasting ability modifier** hit points (base 1d4 + modifier, plus +1d4 per slot level above 3rd; a 5th-level slot adds 2d4).

questions.question: When you cast **Mass Healing Word**, how many creatures can you choose to heal, and which creature types are unaffected by the spell?
questions.answer: You can choose **up to six creatures of your choice that you can see within range** to regain hit points, and the spell **has no effect on undead or constructs**.

questions.question: When a cleric casts **Mass Healing Word**, do they need to be able to see the creatures they’re healing, and what’s the spell’s range?
questions.answer: Yes. You choose up to six creatures of your choice **that you can see** within range, and the spell’s range is **60 feet**.

questions.question: When casting **Mass Healing Word**, what’s the spell’s casting time, and what components (verbal, somatic, material) does it require?
questions.answer: Mass Healing Word has a casting time of **1 bonus action** and requires **only a verbal component (V)**—no somatic or material components.

questions.question: Does **Mass Healing Word** require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: No. **Mass Healing Word** does not require concentration; its **duration is instantaneous**.

questions.question: For the Mass Suggestion spell, what saving throw do the targets make, and how many creatures can you affect with a single casting?
questions.answer: Each target makes a Wisdom saving throw, and you can influence up to twelve creatures of your choice within range that can hear and understand you.

questions.question: For the Mass Suggestion spell, what happens to the effect on a target if you or one of your companions damages that creature during the spell’s duration?
questions.answer: If you or any of your companions damage a creature affected by Mass Suggestion, the spell ends for that creature.

questions.question: If I upcast *mass suggestion*, how does its duration change when cast with a 7th-, 8th-, or 9th-level spell slot?
questions.answer: At Higher Levels: using a 7th-level slot increases the duration to 10 days; an 8th-level slot increases it to 30 days; a 9th-level slot increases it to a year and a day.

questions.question: If I cast *Maze* on a creature, what does it have to do to escape the demiplane, and what check/DC is required?
questions.answer: On its turn, the banished target can use its action to attempt to escape; it makes a DC 20 Intelligence check. On a success it escapes and the spell ends (a minotaur or goristro demon automatically succeeds).

questions.question: When the *Maze* spell ends, where does the banished creature reappear if the space it left is currently occupied?
questions.answer: It reappears in the space it left; if that space is occupied, it appears in the nearest unoccupied space.

questions.question: In play, how long does it take to cast *Maze*, and what’s its range?
questions.answer: *Maze* has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **60 feet**.

questions.question: When you cast *Maze*, does it require any material component, and how long can the spell last?
questions.answer: *Maze* has no material component (components are V, S only), and its duration is up to 10 minutes.

questions.question: When casting *Maze*, do you have to be able to see the creature you’re targeting, or can you banish a creature you can’t see?
questions.answer: You must target “a creature that you can see within range,” so you can’t cast *Maze* on a creature you can’t see.

questions.question: If I cast *Meld into Stone* and the stone I’m hiding in gets partially destroyed or reshaped so I no longer fit, what happens to me and how much damage do I take?
questions.answer: You’re expelled from the stone and take 6d6 bludgeoning damage. If expelled, you fall prone in an unoccupied space closest to where you first entered.

questions.question: While I’m merged inside stone with *Meld into Stone*, can I see or hear what’s happening outside, and can I cast spells while I’m inside it?
questions.answer: While merged with the stone, you can’t see what occurs outside it, and any Wisdom (Perception) checks you make to hear sounds outside it are made with disadvantage. You remain aware of the passage of time and can cast spells on yourself while merged in the stone.

questions.question: When you use *Meld into Stone*, what does it take to enter the stone, and can you exit from a different spot or only where you went in?
questions.answer: You enter the stone by using your movement to step into it at a point you can touch. While merged you otherwise can’t move, and you can use your movement to leave the stone only where you entered; leaving that way ends the spell.

questions.question: For *Meld into Stone*, is it a ritual spell, and how long does the effect last once cast?
questions.answer: Yes—*Meld into Stone* is a 3rd-level transmutation **(ritual)**, and its duration is **8 hours**.

questions.question: When you cast *Meld into Stone*, does your worn and carried gear merge into the stone with you, or is it left outside?
questions.answer: Your gear goes with you: you meld yourself **and all the equipment you carry** with the stone for the spell’s duration.

questions.question: When you cast *Mending*, how large can the break or tear be that you can repair, and can the spell restore a magic item’s lost magical properties?
questions.answer: *Mending* repairs a single break or tear in an object you touch as long as the break/tear is no longer than 1 foot in any dimension, leaving no trace. It can physically repair a magic item or construct, but it can’t restore magic to that object.

questions.question: When you cast *Mending*, does it require a material component, and if so what material do you need?
questions.answer: Yes. *Mending* has components V, S, M, and its material component is **two lodestones**.

questions.question: In combat or during downtime, what are *Mending*’s casting time, range, and duration?
questions.answer: *Mending* has a casting time of 1 minute, a range of Touch, and a duration of Instantaneous.

questions.question: Which character classes have access to the *Mending* cantrip?
questions.answer: *Mending* is available to Clerics, Bards, Druids, Sorcerers, and Wizards.

questions.question: For the Message cantrip, what kinds of barriers (including thickness) block the spell from reaching its target?
questions.answer: Magical silence blocks it, as do physical barriers of 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood.

questions.question: When you cast the Message cantrip on a creature, can the target respond, and who (if anyone) can hear that response?
questions.answer: Yes. The target can reply in a whisper, and only you can hear the reply (the target—and only the target—hears your message).

questions.question: When casting the Message cantrip, does the whispered message have to travel in a straight line, or can it move around corners and through openings?
questions.answer: It doesn’t have to follow a straight line—the message can travel freely around corners or through openings.

questions.question: During play, what are the range and duration of the Message cantrip?
questions.answer: Message has a range of 120 feet and a duration of 1 round.

questions.question: When a character casts the Message cantrip during play, what components does it require, and what specific material component is needed?
questions.answer: Message requires verbal and somatic components, plus a material component: a short piece of copper wire.

questions.question: When you cast **Meteor Swarm**, what is the size of each blast area, what saving throw do creatures make, and what damage do they take on a failed save (including damage types)?
questions.answer: Each meteor creates a **40-foot-radius sphere**. Creatures in the sphere make a **Dexterity saving throw**. On a failed save, a creature takes **20d6 fire damage and 20d6 bludgeoning damage** (half on a successful save).

questions.question: With **Meteor Swarm**, if a creature is caught in the area of effect of more than one of the four bursts, does it take the spell’s damage multiple times or only once?
questions.answer: A creature in the area of more than one fiery burst is affected only once (it doesn’t take the damage multiple times).

questions.question: When you cast **Meteor Swarm**, does it damage objects and ignite unattended flammable items in the blast areas, and are worn or carried flammable objects affected?
questions.answer: Yes. Meteor Swarm damages objects in the area and ignites flammable objects there—except flammable objects that are being worn or carried, which aren’t ignited.

questions.question: For **Meteor Swarm**, what are the spell’s casting time and range, and what components are required?
questions.answer: Meteor Swarm has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **1 mile**, and requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**.

questions.question: When you cast Meteor Swarm, do you have to be able to see the four impact points you choose, and do the blast spheres go around corners?
questions.answer: Yes. You choose four different points you can see within range, and each 40-foot-radius sphere centered on a chosen point spreads around corners.

questions.question: If I cast *Mind Blank* on an ally, what protections does it grant against mental effects and information-gathering magic (including divination and wish)?
questions.answer: Until the spell ends, the willing creature you touch is immune to psychic damage; immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts; protected from divination spells; and immune to the charmed condition. The spell even foils wish spells and other spells or effects of similar power used to affect the target’s mind or to gain information about the target.

questions.question: Does *Mind Blank* require concentration, and how long does it last once cast?
questions.answer: No. *Mind Blank* does not require concentration, and its duration is 24 hours.

questions.question: Which classes can cast *Mind Blank*, and what are its casting time and range?
questions.answer: *Mind Blank* is available to Bards and Wizards. It has a casting time of 1 action and a range of Touch.

questions.question: What spell components do you need to cast *Mind Blank* (verbal, somatic, and/or material)?
questions.answer: *Mind Blank* requires verbal and somatic components (V, S) and has no material component.

questions.question: Can you cast *Mind Blank* on an unwilling creature (for example, to shut down an enemy’s divination or psychic attacks), or does the target have to consent?
questions.answer: The target has to be willing. *Mind Blank* affects “one willing creature you touch,” so you can’t cast it on an unwilling creature.

questions.question: For the Minor Illusion cantrip, how can a creature determine the sound or image is an illusion, and what check does it make?
questions.answer: A creature can use its action to examine the sound or image; it determines it’s an illusion with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC.

questions.question: When you cast **Minor Illusion** to create an image (not a sound), what’s the maximum size the image can be, and what sensory effects is it unable to create?
questions.answer: The image must be no larger than a 5-foot cube, and it can’t create sound, light, smell, or any other sensory effect.

questions.question: How can you end the **Minor Illusion** cantrip before its 1-minute duration is up?
questions.answer: The illusion ends early if you dismiss it as an action, or if you cast Minor Illusion again.

questions.question: When you use **Minor Illusion** to create a sound, can it be intermittent (separate noises at different times), or does it have to be a continuous sound for the full duration—and how loud can it be?
questions.answer: The sound can either "continue unabated throughout the duration" or you can "make discrete sounds at different times before the spell ends." Its volume can range "from a whisper to a scream."

questions.question: If a creature has truesight, what effect does Mirage Arcane have on it—can it see through the illusion, and can it still physically interact with the illusory terrain?
questions.answer: A creature with truesight can see through Mirage Arcane to the terrain’s true form; however, the other elements of the illusion remain, so while it’s aware the illusion is present, it can still physically interact with the illusion.

questions.question: When you cast *Mirage Arcane*, how large an area of terrain can you affect, and what happens if someone removes a piece of the illusory terrain (like a rock or stick) from the spell’s area?
questions.answer: It affects terrain in an area up to **1 mile square**. Any piece of the illusory terrain removed from the spell’s area **disappears immediately**.

questions.question: When you cast *Mirage Arcane*, how long does it take to cast, and how long does the illusion last?
questions.answer: *Mirage Arcane* has a casting time of **10 minutes** and a duration of **10 days**.

questions.question: When casting *Mirage Arcane*, can you use it to hide, disguise, or create creatures within the affected area?
questions.answer: No. *Mirage Arcane* can alter terrain and structures, but it “doesn’t disguise, conceal, or add creatures.”

questions.question: When you’re under *Mirror Image* and a creature makes an attack against you, what d20 roll is needed to make the attack target a duplicate (with 3, 2, or 1 duplicate left), and what AC does a duplicate have?
questions.answer: When a creature targets you with an attack, you roll 1d20 to see if it targets a duplicate instead. With three duplicates, the roll must be 6 or higher; with two duplicates, 8 or higher; with one duplicate, 11 or higher. A duplicate’s AC is 10 + your Dexterity modifier.

questions.question: Does *Mirror Image* protect you from attackers using blindsight or truesight (or who otherwise can’t see the illusions), and who is unaffected by the spell’s duplicates?
questions.answer: A creature is unaffected by *mirror image* if it can’t see, if it relies on a sense other than sight (such as blindsight), or if it can perceive illusions as false (such as with truesight/“clear vision”).

questions.question: During combat, if you cast *Mirror Image* but want to drop it early, how can you end the spell yourself—and when does the spell end automatically?
questions.answer: You can use your action to dispel the illusory duplicates. The spell ends automatically if all three duplicates are destroyed (a duplicate is destroyed when an attack hits it).

questions.question: Does *Mirror Image* require concentration, and how long does the spell last once cast?
questions.answer: It does **not** require concentration (the duration is listed simply as **1 minute**), so it lasts for **1 minute** unless ended earlier (such as by dispelling it or losing all duplicates).

questions.question: If you have *Mirror Image* up and get hit by a fireball or other non-attack damage/effect, do the duplicates get destroyed, or are they only removed when an attack hits them?
questions.answer: The duplicates are destroyed only when an attack hits a duplicate. They ignore other damage and effects (such as area damage), and the spell ends early only if all three duplicates are destroyed (or you use your action to dispel them).

questions.question: When you cast *Mislead*, what causes the spell’s invisibility to end?
questions.answer: The invisibility ends if you attack or cast a spell.

questions.question: When you cast *Mislead*, what action economy does it take to move the illusory double, and how far can you move it on that action?
questions.answer: You use your action to move the illusory double, and you can move it up to twice your speed (and have it gesture, speak, and behave as you choose).

questions.question: When you use *Mislead* to see and hear through your illusory double’s senses, what happens to your awareness of your own surroundings?
questions.answer: While you’re using the double’s senses, you are blinded and deafened with regard to your own surroundings.

questions.question: When casting *Mislead*, what are the spell’s range, components, and duration?
questions.answer: *Mislead* has a range of Self, requires only somatic components (S), and lasts up to 1 hour.

questions.question: Which classes can cast the *Mislead* spell?
questions.answer: *Mislead* is on the Bard and Wizard spell lists.

questions.question: For the spell Misty Step, how far can you teleport, and does the destination space need to be one you can see?
questions.answer: You teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space that you can see.

questions.question: For Misty Step, what’s the casting time, and what components does it require?
questions.answer: Misty Step has a casting time of 1 bonus action and requires only a verbal (V) component.

questions.question: Which classes have Misty Step on their spell list in the SRD?
questions.answer: Misty Step is available to Druids, Paladins, Sorcerers, Warlocks, and Wizards.

questions.question: Does casting Misty Step require concentration, and what is the spell’s duration?
questions.answer: Misty Step does not require concentration; its duration is **Instantaneous**.

questions.question: When you upcast Modify Memory, how far back in the target’s past can you alter an event at 6th-, 7th-, 8th-, and 9th-level slots?
questions.answer: At higher levels, you can alter memories of an event up to 7 days ago with a 6th-level slot, 30 days ago with a 7th-level slot, 1 year ago with an 8th-level slot, or any time in the creature’s past with a 9th-level slot.

questions.question: When you cast Modify Memory on a creature you’re currently fighting, what saving throw does it make, and does it get any advantage on that save?
questions.answer: The target makes a Wisdom saving throw, and if you are fighting it, it has advantage on the saving throw.

questions.question: For the *moonbeam* spell, what is the size of the beam’s area, and what saving throw and damage does a creature take when it first enters the area on a turn or starts its turn there?
questions.answer: Moonbeam creates a 5-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder. A creature that enters it for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a Constitution saving throw, taking 2d10 radiant damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one.

questions.question: When you maintain *moonbeam*, what action do you use on later turns to reposition it, and how far can you move the beam each turn?
questions.answer: On each of your turns after you cast *moonbeam*, you can use an **action** to move the beam **up to 60 feet in any direction**.

questions.question: When you hit a shapechanger with *moonbeam*, how does the spell change its saving throw and what happens if it fails the save?
questions.answer: A shapechanger makes the Constitution saving throw with disadvantage. If it fails, it instantly reverts to its original form and can’t assume a different form until it leaves the spell’s light.

questions.question: For the Move Earth spell, how long does it take for the terrain reshaping to complete, and how often can you switch to a new area while maintaining the spell?
questions.answer: The terrain changes take 10 minutes to complete. At the end of every 10 minutes you spend concentrating on the spell, you can choose a new area of terrain to affect.

questions.question: With *move earth*, can you reshape natural stone or stone construction, and what happens to existing rocks and structures in the affected area?
questions.answer: No. *Move earth* can reshape only dirt, sand, or clay; it "can't manipulate natural stone or stone construction." Existing rocks and structures shift to accommodate the new terrain, but if the reshaping would make a structure unstable, it might collapse.

questions.question: When you cast *move earth*, what’s the maximum height/depth you can raise, lower, or dig within the chosen area (for example, if you target a 40-foot square)?
questions.answer: The amount you can reshape can’t exceed half the area’s largest dimension. So if you affect a 40‑foot square, you can raise or lower the elevation by up to 20 feet, create a pillar up to 20 feet high, or dig a trench up to 20 feet deep (and similarly for other area sizes).

questions.question: If you cast *move earth* on an area with vegetation, does the spell directly affect plant growth—and what happens to the plants when the soil is reshaped?
questions.answer: No. *Move earth* doesn’t directly affect plant growth; the moved earth carries any plants along with it.

questions.question: If creatures are standing in the area you’re reshaping with *move earth*, can the shifting ground trap or injure them?
questions.answer: Usually no—because the terrain’s transformation happens slowly, creatures in the area can’t usually be trapped or injured by the ground’s movement.

questions.question: When you cast *Nondetection*, can the warded target still be perceived through magical scrying sensors, and what’s the maximum size of a place or object you can protect with the spell?
questions.answer: No—while *Nondetection* lasts, the target can’t be targeted by divination magic or perceived through magical scrying sensors. The target can be a place or object no larger than 10 feet in any dimension (or a willing creature).

questions.question: When casting *Nondetection*, what material component is required, what’s its gp value, and is it consumed by the spell?
questions.answer: It requires a pinch of diamond dust worth 25 gp sprinkled over the target, and the spell consumes the diamond dust.

questions.question: If I cast *Nondetection* in combat, what’s its casting time, range, and how long does the protection last?
questions.answer: *Nondetection* has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **Touch**, and it lasts for **8 hours**.

questions.question: Which character classes can cast *Nondetection* (i.e., which spell lists include it)?
questions.answer: *Nondetection* is available to the Bard, Cleric, Ranger, and Wizard spell lists.

questions.question: Can you cast *Nondetection* on an unwilling creature, and what kinds of targets are eligible for the spell?
questions.answer: No. *Nondetection* can only affect a willing creature you touch, or a place or object you touch that is no larger than 10 feet in any dimension.

questions.question: When you cast Pass without Trace, what bonus does it give to creatures’ Dexterity (Stealth) checks, how far from you can you choose affected creatures, and can they be tracked by nonmagical means while the spell lasts?
questions.answer: For the duration, each creature you choose within 30 feet of you (including you) gets a +10 bonus to Dexterity (Stealth) checks, and they can’t be tracked except by magical means (they leave no tracks or other traces).

questions.question: When the *passwall* spell ends, what happens to any creatures or objects that are still inside the passage it created?
questions.answer: When the opening disappears, any creatures or objects still in the passage are safely ejected to the nearest unoccupied space closest to the surface where you cast the spell.

questions.question: For the *passwall* spell, what kind of surface can you target, and what are the maximum dimensions of the passage you can create?
questions.answer: You can create the passage in a wooden, plaster, or stone surface (such as a wall, ceiling, or floor) that you can see within 30 feet. The opening can be up to 5 feet wide, 8 feet tall, and 20 feet deep.

questions.question: Does the *passwall* spell require concentration, and how long does the passage last?
questions.answer: It doesn’t require concentration; its duration is **1 hour**, so the passage lasts for 1 hour.

questions.question: When casting *passwall*, what material component do you need to provide?
questions.answer: A pinch of sesame seeds.

questions.question: When you create a tunnel with *passwall*, does it make the surrounding wall/structure unstable or prone to collapse?
questions.answer: No. The passage created by *passwall* "creates no instability in a structure surrounding it."

questions.question: For the *phantom steed* spell, what causes the spell to end early, and how long does the rider have to dismount when it ends?
questions.answer: The spell ends early if you use an action to dismiss the steed or if the steed takes any damage. When the spell ends, the steed fades and the rider has 1 minute to dismount.

questions.question: When you cast **Planar Ally**, what’s the rule-of-thumb payment you need to offer for a service that takes minutes, hours, or days?
questions.answer: As a rule of thumb: **100 gp per minute** for tasks measured in minutes, **1,000 gp per hour** for tasks measured in hours, and **10,000 gp per day** for tasks measured in days (up to 10 days).

questions.question: When you cast **Planar Ally**, what happens if you and the summoned creature can’t agree on a price for its service?
questions.answer: If you’re unable to agree on a price for the creature’s service, the creature immediately returns to its home plane.

questions.question: When you cast Planar Ally, is the creature that appears compelled to follow your orders, and what condition must you meet to bargain for its service?
questions.answer: No. When the creature appears, it is under no compulsion to behave in any particular way and isn’t obliged to perform a service; you can only ask. You must be able to communicate with the creature in order to bargain for its services.

questions.question: If a creature called by **Planar Ally** agrees to join the party for an adventure, does it count as a party member for XP awards, and how much XP does it receive?
questions.answer: Yes. A creature enlisted to join your group counts as a member of it and receives a full share of any experience points awarded.

questions.question: When you cast **Planar Ally**, what kinds of creatures can the entity send to help you, and where does that creature appear?
questions.answer: The entity sends **a celestial, an elemental, or a fiend** loyal to it, and the creature **appears in an unoccupied space within the spell’s range (60 feet)**.

questions.question: When you cast Planar Binding, what saving throw does the target make to resist being bound, and how long does the binding last if you upcast it with a 7th-level spell slot?
questions.answer: The target makes a Charisma saving throw. If you cast Planar Binding using a 7th-level spell slot, the binding lasts 30 days.

questions.question: If you cast Planar Binding on a creature that was summoned or created by another spell, what happens to the duration of that original spell?
questions.answer: If the creature was summoned or created by another spell, that spell’s duration is extended to match the duration of Planar Binding.

questions.question: For the spell *Planar Binding*, what’s the spell’s range, and what material component do you need—does that component get consumed?
questions.answer: *Planar Binding* has a range of **60 feet**. It requires **a jewel worth at least 1,000 gp** as its material component, and **the spell consumes the jewel**.

questions.question: For *Planar Binding*, does the target have to stay within range for the whole 1-hour casting time, and what happens if the bound creature finishes your instructions while you’re on a different plane of existence?
questions.answer: Yes. The creature must be within the spell’s range for the entire casting. If it completes your instructions before the spell ends and you’re on a different plane, it returns to the place where you bound it and remains there until the spell ends.

questions.question: For the spell *Planar Binding*, what types of creatures can you target and attempt to bind to your service?
questions.answer: You can attempt to bind a **celestial, elemental, fey, or fiend**.

questions.question: When you use *Plane Shift* offensively to banish an unwilling creature, what kind of attack do you make and what saving throw does the target roll if you hit?
questions.answer: You make a **melee spell attack** against a creature within your reach. On a hit, the target must make a **Charisma saving throw**; on a failed save it’s transported to a random location on the plane you specify.

questions.question: With *Plane Shift*, if you know the sigil sequence of a teleportation circle on another plane, can you use the spell to arrive at that circle—and what happens if the circle can’t physically fit everyone you transported?
questions.answer: Yes. If you know the sigil sequence of a teleportation circle on another plane of existence, *plane shift* can take you to that circle. If the circle is too small to hold all the creatures you transported, the extra creatures appear in the closest unoccupied spaces next to the circle.

questions.question: When casting *Plane Shift* for group travel, how many willing creatures can you take with you, and what do they need to do during casting?
questions.answer: You can transport yourself and up to eight willing creatures, and the creatures must link hands in a circle.

questions.question: For *Plane Shift*, what material component do you need, what minimum value must it have, and what must it be attuned to?
questions.answer: A forked, metal rod worth at least 250 gp, attuned to a particular plane of existence.

questions.question: Does the *Plane Shift* spell require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: Plane Shift does not require concentration; its duration is **Instantaneous**.

questions.question: If I cast **Plant Growth** as an action in combat, what area does it affect, and how does it change a creature’s movement through that area?
questions.answer: When cast with 1 action, you choose a point within 150 feet; all normal plants in a **100-foot radius** centered on that point become thick and overgrown, and a creature moving through the area must spend **4 feet of movement for every 1 foot** it moves.

questions.question: If I cast **Plant Growth** using the 8-hour casting option, what size area does it affect, how long does the effect last, and what benefit do the plants gain?
questions.answer: With the 8-hour casting option, Plant Growth enriches all plants in a **half-mile radius** centered on a point within range. The enrichment lasts for **1 year**, and the plants **yield twice the normal amount of food when harvested**.

questions.question: When I cast **Plant Growth** in its 1-action mode, can I leave specific patches inside the spell’s area unaffected (for example, to keep a clear path through the overgrowth)?
questions.answer: Yes. In the 1-action version of *Plant Growth*, you “can exclude one or more areas of any size within the spell’s area from being affected.”

questions.question: Does the **Plant Growth** spell require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: Plant Growth does **not** require concentration (it isn’t listed as Concentration), and its duration is **instantaneous**.

questions.question: For the **Plant Growth** spell, what is its range, and does it require any material components?
questions.answer: Plant Growth has a range of **150 feet** and requires **no material components** (components are **V, S** only).

questions.question: How does the Poison Spray cantrip’s damage scale as you gain levels (including the damage dice at 1st, 5th, 11th, and 17th level)?
questions.answer: Poison Spray deals 1d12 poison damage on a failed Constitution save, and its damage increases by 1d12 at 5th level (2d12), 11th level (3d12), and 17th level (4d12).

questions.question: For the Poison Spray cantrip, what is its range and what type of saving throw does the target have to make to avoid the damage?
questions.answer: Poison Spray has a range of 10 feet, and the target must make a Constitution saving throw (on a success it takes no damage).

questions.question: For the Poison Spray cantrip, what components does it require, and what are its casting time and duration?
questions.answer: Poison Spray requires verbal and somatic components (V, S). It has a casting time of 1 action and a duration of instantaneous.

questions.question: Which classes can learn or cast the Poison Spray cantrip?
questions.answer: Poison Spray is available to Druids, Sorcerers, Warlocks, and Wizards.
