questions.question: When you cast *Polymorph* on an unwilling target, what saving throw does it make to resist the spell, and how do shapechangers handle that save?
questions.answer: An unwilling creature makes a Wisdom saving throw to avoid the effect, and a shapechanger automatically succeeds on this saving throw.

questions.question: If you cast *Polymorph* on a player character (a creature with no challenge rating), what’s the highest challenge rating beast you’re allowed to turn them into?
questions.answer: The new form can be any beast whose challenge rating is equal to or less than the target’s level (for a target that doesn’t have a challenge rating).

questions.question: In combat, if a creature affected by *Polymorph* is reduced to 0 hit points in its beast form, what happens when it reverts—does any excess damage carry over to its normal form, and can it be knocked unconscious from that carryover?
questions.answer: When the polymorphed creature drops to 0 hit points, it reverts to its normal form and returns to the number of hit points it had before it transformed. If it reverts because it hit 0, any excess damage carries over to its normal form; however, as long as that excess damage doesn’t reduce the creature’s normal form to 0 hit points, it isn’t knocked unconscious.

questions.question: When a creature is affected by *Polymorph*, what happens to its worn and carried gear—does it stay accessible, and can the creature activate or benefit from its equipment while in beast form?
questions.answer: The target’s gear melds into the new form. While polymorphed, the creature can’t activate, use, wield, or otherwise benefit from any of its equipment.

questions.question: While a creature is under the effects of *Polymorph*, can it speak or cast spells, and what kinds of actions are explicitly restricted by the spell?
questions.answer: No. While polymorphed, the creature “can’t speak, cast spells, or take any other action that requires hands or speech.”

questions.question: For the spell *Power Word Kill*, what’s the maximum hit point total a target can have for the spell to kill it instantly (and what happens if it has more than that)?
questions.answer: If the target has 100 hit points or fewer, it dies instantly; if it has more than 100 hit points, the spell has no effect.

questions.question: For *Power Word Kill*, do you need line of sight to the target, and what is the spell’s range?
questions.answer: Yes. You choose **one creature you can see** within range, and the range is **60 feet**.

questions.question: For the spell *Power Word Kill*, what components are required to cast it, and which classes have it on their spell list?
questions.answer: *Power Word Kill* requires only a verbal component (V). It’s on the spell lists of Bard, Sorcerer, Warlock, and Wizard.

questions.question: In combat, how long does it take to cast *Power Word Kill*, and does the spell have any ongoing duration or is it instantaneous?
questions.answer: *Power Word Kill* has a casting time of **1 action**, and its duration is **instantaneous** (no ongoing effect).

questions.question: When you cast *Power Word Kill*, can you affect more than one creature, or is it limited to a single target?
questions.answer: It’s limited to a single target: you compel **one creature you can see within range** to die instantly (if it has 100 hit points or fewer).

questions.question: When you cast Power Word Stun, what’s the hit point threshold for it to take effect, and how does the target end the stunned condition?
questions.answer: Power Word Stun only affects a target with 150 hit points or fewer; that creature is stunned. The stunned target then makes a Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, and the effect ends on a successful save.

questions.question: When you cast **Power Word Stun**, what’s its casting time, range, components, and duration?
questions.answer: **Power Word Stun** has a **casting time** of **1 action**, a **range** of **60 feet**, **components** of **V** only, and a **duration** of **instantaneous**.

questions.question: Which classes can cast *Power Word Stun* (i.e., which spell lists include it)?
questions.answer: *Power Word Stun* is on the Bard, Sorcerer, Warlock, and Wizard spell lists.

questions.question: For *Power Word Stun*, what are the targeting requirements—how many creatures can you affect, and do you need to be able to see the target?
questions.answer: It targets **one creature** you can **see** within range.

questions.question: For the cleric spell *Prayer of Healing*, how many creatures can you heal with one casting, and what types of creatures are unaffected by the spell?
questions.answer: One casting can heal up to six creatures you can see within 30 feet, and it has no effect on undead or constructs.

questions.question: When you upcast *Prayer of Healing*, how does the healing scale with higher-level spell slots (e.g., what’s the total healing dice if cast using a 4th-level slot)?
questions.answer: At Higher Levels: the healing increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 2nd. So with a 4th-level slot, it heals 4d8 + your spellcasting ability modifier to each target (instead of 2d8 + modifier).

questions.question: In a session, if a cleric wants to use *Prayer of Healing* to patch up the party after a fight, what are the spell’s casting time and range?
questions.answer: *Prayer of Healing* has a **casting time of 10 minutes** and a **range of 30 feet**.

questions.question: For *Prayer of Healing*, what components do you need to cast it, and what is the spell’s duration?
questions.answer: It requires only a verbal component (V), and its duration is instantaneous.

questions.question: If I cast *prestidigitation* multiple times, how many of its non-instantaneous effects can I keep active at once, and how do I end one early?
questions.answer: You can have up to three of *prestidigitation*’s non-instantaneous effects active at a time, and you can dismiss one of those effects as an action.

questions.question: When you use *prestidigitation* to create a nonmagical trinket or an illusory image that fits in your hand, how long does that created item/image last?
questions.answer: It lasts until the end of your next turn.

questions.question: With *prestidigitation*, what’s the largest object you can clean or soil, and does that effect happen instantly or over the spell’s 1-hour duration?
questions.answer: You can instantaneously clean or soil an object no larger than 1 cubic foot.

questions.question: If I cast *prestidigitation* to snuff out a fire, what kinds of flames can it affect, what’s the spell’s range, and does that extinguishing happen instantly?
questions.answer: *Prestidigitation* can instantaneously light or snuff out **a candle, a torch, or a small campfire**. The spell’s **range is 10 feet**, and the lighting/snuffing effect happens **instantaneously**.

questions.question: Does *prestidigitation* require any material components, and what are its components and casting time?
questions.answer: No—*prestidigitation* has no material components. Its components are V and S, and its casting time is 1 action.

questions.question: For Prismatic Spray, what happens to a creature that fails its save against the indigo ray, and what saves does it make afterward to end or worsen the effect?
questions.answer: On a failed save against the indigo ray, the target is restrained. It then makes a Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns: after three successful saves the spell ends on it, and after three failed saves it permanently turns to stone (petrified). The successes and failures don’t have to be consecutive; track them until it gets three of one kind.

questions.question: In Prismatic Spray, if a creature is affected by the violet ray, what condition does it suffer, what follow-up saving throw does it make (and when), and what happens on a success vs. a failure of that follow-up save?
questions.answer: On a failed save against the violet ray, the target is blinded. It must then make a Wisdom saving throw at the start of your next turn. On a successful Wisdom save, the blindness ends; on a failed Wisdom save, the creature is transported to another plane of existence of the DM’s choosing and is no longer blinded.

questions.question: When you cast *Prismatic Spray*, what area does it affect, what saving throw do creatures in the area make, and how do you determine which color ray hits each creature?
questions.answer: *Prismatic Spray* affects each creature in a **60-foot cone** originating from you. Each creature in the cone must make a **Dexterity saving throw**. For each target, you **roll a d8** to determine which colored ray affects it.

questions.question: When resolving *Prismatic Spray* for a creature, what happens if your d8 roll comes up as the “Special” result (8)?
questions.answer: If you roll an 8 (“Special”), the target is struck by two rays: roll twice more to determine the colors, rerolling any additional 8s.

questions.question: For *Prismatic Spray*, what damage type and damage dice do the red, orange, yellow, green, and blue rays deal, and what happens on a successful saving throw?
questions.answer:
- **Red ray:** 10d6 **fire** damage on a failed save, or **half** as much on a successful save.
- **Orange ray:** 10d6 **acid** damage on a failed save, or **half** as much on a successful save.
- **Yellow ray:** 10d6 **lightning** damage on a failed save, or **half** as much on a successful save.
- **Green ray:** 10d6 **poison** damage on a failed save, or **half** as much on a successful save.
- **Blue ray:** 10d6 **cold** damage on a failed save, or **half** as much on a successful save.

questions.question: For *prismatic wall*, what saving throw does a creature make if it can see the wall and starts its turn within 20 feet of it, and what happens on a failed save?
questions.answer: It must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature becomes blinded for 1 minute.

questions.question: With *prismatic wall* up, which color layer prevents spells from being cast through the wall, and what can be used to destroy that layer?
questions.answer: The **indigo** layer blocks spellcasting through the wall (“spells can’t be cast through the wall”). That indigo layer is destroyed by **bright light shed by a *daylight* spell**, or a similar spell of **equal or higher level**.

questions.question: If I cast *prismatic wall* and position it so the wall would pass through a space occupied by a creature, what happens to the spell and my action/slot?
questions.answer: If you position the wall so that it passes through a space occupied by a creature, the spell fails, and your action and the spell slot are wasted.

questions.question: If a prismatic wall intersects an antimagic field, is the wall suppressed, and is there a way to destroy the entire wall at once instead of removing layers one by one?
questions.answer: An antimagic field has no effect on a prismatic wall. A rod of cancellation destroys the prismatic wall outright (otherwise it can be destroyed one layer at a time from red to violet using the specific method for each layer).

questions.question: If you upcast *Private Sanctum* using a 6th-level spell slot, what’s the maximum size (length of one side) of the cube you can ward?
questions.answer: A maximum cube **300 feet on a side** (base 100 feet, plus 100 feet per slot level above 4th).

questions.question: When *Private Sanctum* is up, how does it interact with divination magic—can divination sensors appear or pass into the warded area, and can creatures inside be targeted by divination spells?
questions.answer: Divination sensors created by divination spells can’t appear inside the protected area or pass through the barrier at its perimeter, and creatures in the area can’t be targeted by divination spells.

questions.question: If you include the teleportation-related protections when casting *Private Sanctum*, what movement magic does it stop—can creatures teleport into/out of the warded cube, and does it block planar travel inside it?
questions.answer: Yes. With those options chosen, nothing can teleport into or out of the warded area, and planar travel is blocked within the warded area.

questions.question: During play, if a wizard casts *Private Sanctum*, does it require concentration, how long does it last, and can the caster end it early?
questions.answer: *Private Sanctum* does not require concentration. Its duration is 24 hours, and it also ends early if the caster uses an action to dismiss it.

questions.question: For *Mordenkainen’s Private Sanctum*, what do you have to do to make the ward permanent?
questions.answer: Cast *Private Sanctum* on the same spot every day for a year; doing so makes the effect permanent.

questions.question: When you use Produce Flame to attack, what’s the attack’s range, what kind of roll do you make, and what damage does it deal on a hit?
questions.answer: You can hurl the flame at a creature within 30 feet, making a ranged spell attack; on a hit it deals 1d8 fire damage.

questions.question: For the Produce Flame cantrip, how much light does the flame shed, and what causes the spell to end early besides its normal duration?
questions.answer: The flame sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet. The spell ends early if you dismiss it as an action, if you cast it again, or if you attack with the flame (hurling it ends the spell).

questions.question: How does the Produce Flame cantrip’s damage scale as you gain levels (what damage dice does it deal at 1st, 5th, 11th, and 17th level)?
questions.answer: It deals 1d8 fire damage at 1st level, and the damage increases by 1d8 at 5th (2d8), 11th (3d8), and 17th level (4d8).

questions.question: Does the Produce Flame cantrip require concentration, and what’s its duration?
questions.answer: No—Produce Flame doesn’t require concentration. Its duration is 10 minutes.

questions.question: For the Produce Flame cantrip, what’s the casting time and what components does it require?
questions.answer: Produce Flame has a casting time of 1 action and requires verbal and somatic components (V, S).

questions.question: For the Programmed Illusion spell, what ability check can a creature use to determine the image is an illusion, and what is it checked against?
questions.answer: A creature can use its action to examine the image and make an Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC to determine it’s an illusion.

questions.question: For the Programmed Illusion spell, what’s the maximum size the illusion can be, and how long can its scripted performance last once it triggers?
questions.answer: The illusion can be no larger than a 30-foot cube, and its scripted performance can last up to 5 minutes once it triggers.

questions.question: After a Programmed Illusion triggers and finishes its performance, how long does it remain dormant before it can activate again?
questions.answer: Once it finishes performing, the illusion disappears and remains dormant for 10 minutes; after that time it can be activated again.

questions.question: For Programmed Illusion, what restrictions are there on the triggering condition—what kind of cue can it be based on, and how close to the illusion’s area must that cue occur?
questions.answer: The triggering condition can be as general or detailed as you like, but it must be based on visual or audible conditions that occur within 30 feet of the illusion’s area.

questions.question: For the *Programmed Illusion* spell, what components does it require, and what material component (including any minimum cost) is needed?
questions.answer: It requires verbal and somatic components, plus a material component: a bit of fleece and jade dust worth at least 25 gp.

questions.question: If an enemy interacts with your **Project Image** illusion, what can they do to prove it’s an illusion, and what check do they make?
questions.answer: Physical interaction reveals it’s an illusion because things can pass through it. Also, a creature can use its action to examine the image and determine it’s an illusion with a successful Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC.

questions.question: When you’re perceiving through a **Project Image** duplicate’s eyes and ears, what happens to your awareness of your own surroundings, and what action does it take to switch back to your own senses?
questions.answer: While you are using the duplicate’s senses, you are **blinded and deafened** with respect to your own surroundings. On your turn, you can switch from its senses to your own (or back again) as a **bonus action**.

questions.question: In play, if a creature hits your **Project Image** duplicate with an attack or otherwise deals it damage, what happens to the duplicate and the spell?
questions.answer: If the illusory copy takes any damage, it disappears, and the spell ends.

questions.question: When casting **Project Image**, how far away can you create the illusory duplicate, and what restriction is there on where it can appear?
questions.answer: The spell has a range of **500 miles**. The duplicate can appear at any location within that range **that you have seen before**, regardless of intervening obstacles.

questions.question: When casting *Project Image*, what material component is required, and what minimum value must it be worth?
questions.answer: It requires a small replica of you made from materials worth at least 5 gp.

questions.question: When you cast *Protection from Energy*, what damage types can you choose to grant resistance against, and how long does the resistance last?
questions.answer: You choose one of these damage types: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder. The target has resistance for up to 1 hour.

questions.question: When you cast *Protection from Energy*, what are its casting time, range, and components?
questions.answer: *Protection from Energy* has a casting time of 1 action, a range of Touch, and components V, S.

questions.question: Which character classes have *Protection from Energy* on their spell lists?
questions.answer: Cleric, Druid, Paladin, Ranger, Sorcerer, and Wizard.

questions.question: What spell level and school is *Protection from Energy*?
questions.answer: *Protection from Energy* is a 3rd-level abjuration spell.

questions.question: Can you cast *Protection from Energy* on an unwilling creature (like an enemy), or does the target have to be willing?
questions.answer: The spell only affects “the willing creature you touch,” so the target must be willing (you can’t cast it on an unwilling creature).

questions.question: In 5e, what creature types does *Protection from Evil and Good* ward a touched willing creature against, and what conditions can those creatures no longer inflict on the target while the spell lasts?
questions.answer: It protects the target from aberrations, celestials, elementals, fey, fiends, and undead. While it lasts, creatures of those types can’t charm, frighten, or possess the target.

questions.question: When you cast *Protection from Evil and Good*, what material component do you need, and does the spell consume it?
questions.answer: The spell requires a material component of either holy water or powdered silver and iron, and the spell consumes that material component.

questions.question: When you cast Protection from Poison on a creature, what benefits does it grant for the spell’s duration (including how it interacts with an existing poison), and how long do those benefits last?
questions.answer: You touch a creature; if it is poisoned, you neutralize the poison (if multiple poisons affect it, you neutralize one you know is present or one at random). For 1 hour, the target has advantage on saving throws against being poisoned and has resistance to poison damage.

questions.question: During combat, what are the casting time, range, and components required to cast Protection from Poison?
questions.answer: Protection from Poison has a casting time of 1 action, a range of Touch, and requires verbal and somatic components (V, S).

questions.question: When you cast *Purify Food and Drink*, how large is the area it affects and what kinds of food or drink does it work on?
questions.answer: It purifies all **nonmagical** food and drink in a **5-foot-radius sphere** centered on a point you choose within range.

questions.question: Does *Purify Food and Drink* require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: It does not require concentration; its duration is **instantaneous**.

questions.question: Is *Purify Food and Drink* cast as a ritual, and which classes can cast it?
questions.answer: Yes—*Purify Food and Drink* is a 1st-level transmutation spell that can be cast as a ritual. It’s available to Cleric, Druid, Paladin, and Ritual Caster.

questions.question: What are the casting time and components required to cast *Purify Food and Drink*?
questions.answer: It has a casting time of **1 action** and requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**.

questions.question: If the party’s rations or ale might be contaminated, what exactly does *Purify Food and Drink* cleanse the food and drink of?
questions.answer: It purifies all **nonmagical** food and drink in the area, rendering it free of **poison and disease**.

questions.question: After a creature is brought back with Raise Dead, what temporary penalty does it suffer, and how does that penalty wear off over time?
questions.answer: The revived creature takes a −4 penalty to all attack rolls, saving throws, and ability checks. Each time it finishes a long rest, the penalty is reduced by 1 until it disappears.

questions.question: When you cast **Raise Dead** on a creature that died while poisoned or diseased, what does the spell cure/neutralize, and what kinds of lingering effects does it *not* remove (and will still take effect after the creature is revived) if they aren’t dealt with first?
questions.answer: Raise Dead neutralizes any poisons and cures **nonmagical diseases** that affected the creature at the time it died. It does **not** remove **magical diseases, curses, or similar effects**; if those aren’t removed before casting, they take effect when the creature returns to life.

questions.question: If you cast **Raise Dead** on a creature whose body is missing vital parts (like its head), will the spell restore those parts or bring the creature back anyway?
questions.answer: Raise Dead doesn’t restore missing body parts. If the creature is missing body parts or organs integral for its survival (its head, for example), the spell automatically fails.

questions.question: When you cast **Raise Dead**, how long can the creature have been dead, and how many hit points does it return with if its soul is willing and free to rejoin the body?
questions.answer: The creature must have been dead no longer than **10 days**, and it returns to life with **1 hit point** (assuming its soul is willing and at liberty to rejoin the body).

questions.question: When casting **Raise Dead**, what material component do you need, what minimum value must it have, and is it consumed by the spell?
questions.answer: Raise Dead requires a material component of **a diamond worth at least 500 gp**, and **the spell consumes the diamond**.

questions.question: For Ray of Enfeeblement, what kind of saving throw can the target make to end the spell early, and when do they get to attempt it?
questions.answer: At the end of each of the target’s turns, it can make a Constitution saving throw; on a success, the spell ends.

questions.question: When you cast Ray of Enfeeblement, what type of attack roll do you make, and what effect does a hit have on the target’s Strength-based weapon damage?
questions.answer: You make a ranged spell attack against a creature within 60 feet. On a hit, the target deals only half damage with weapon attacks that use Strength until the spell ends.

questions.question: In play, what are the casting time, range, and components required to cast Ray of Enfeeblement?
questions.answer: Casting Time: 1 action; Range: 60 feet; Components: V, S.

questions.question: If a creature hit by Ray of Enfeeblement never succeeds on its saving throw to end the spell, what’s the spell’s maximum duration?
questions.answer: Up to 1 minute.

questions.question: What level spell is Ray of Enfeeblement, and what school of magic is it?
questions.answer: Ray of Enfeeblement is a 2nd-level Necromancy spell.

questions.question: When you hit a creature with Ray of Frost, how much cold damage does it deal and how long does the target’s speed penalty last?
questions.answer: On a hit, Ray of Frost deals 1d8 cold damage, and the target’s speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of your next turn.

questions.question: For the Ray of Frost cantrip, what’s its casting time and range?
questions.answer: Ray of Frost has a casting time of 1 action and a range of 60 feet.

questions.question: Which classes can cast the Ray of Frost cantrip, and what components does it require?
questions.answer: Ray of Frost is available to Sorcerers and Wizards, and it requires verbal and somatic components (V, S).

questions.question: When does the Ray of Frost cantrip’s damage scale up, and what damage dice does it deal at 1st, 5th, 11th, and 17th level?
questions.answer: Ray of Frost deals 1d8 cold damage at 1st level. Its damage increases by 1d8 at 5th level (2d8), 11th level (3d8), and 17th level (4d8).

questions.question: For Ray of Frost, do you make an attack roll or force a saving throw—and what kind is it?
questions.answer: You make a **ranged spell attack** against a creature within range (it doesn’t call for a saving throw).

questions.question: If I cast *Regenerate* on a creature missing a limb, how long does it take for the severed body part to grow back, and what happens if I’m holding the severed part to the stump when I cast it?
questions.answer: The target’s severed body members are restored after 2 minutes. If you have the severed part and hold it to the stump, the spell instantaneously causes the limb to knit to the stump.

questions.question: When you cast *Regenerate*, how many hit points does the target regain immediately, and how much additional healing does it get at the start of each of its turns while the spell lasts?
questions.answer: The target regains **4d8 + 15 hit points immediately**, and for the spell’s duration it regains **1 hit point at the start of each of its turns** (noted as **10 hit points each minute**).

questions.question: When you cast *Regenerate*, what is its casting time, and what material components do you need?
questions.answer: *Regenerate* has a casting time of **1 minute**, and it requires material components of **a prayer wheel and holy water** (along with verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: Does *Regenerate* require concentration, and how long does the spell last once cast?
questions.answer: *Regenerate* does **not** require concentration, and its duration is **1 hour**.

questions.question: What level spell is *Regenerate*, and which classes can cast it?
questions.answer: *Regenerate* is a **7th-level transmutation** spell, and it’s available to **Bards, Clerics, and Druids**.

questions.question: For the Reincarnate spell, what material components are required, what is their minimum cost, and are they consumed by the casting?
questions.answer: Reincarnate requires rare oils and unguents worth at least 1,000 gp, and the spell consumes them.

questions.question: For the *reincarnate* spell, what kind of creature can you target, and how long can it have been dead for the spell to work?
questions.answer: You must touch a dead humanoid (or a piece of a dead humanoid), and it must have been dead no longer than 10 days for the spell to work.

questions.question: When you cast *reincarnate*, what happens if the dead creature’s soul isn’t free or isn’t willing to return?
questions.answer: If the target’s soul isn’t free or willing to enter the new body, the spell fails.

questions.question: When a dead character is brought back with *reincarnate*, do they keep their memories and class/other capabilities, and what specifically changes about them?
questions.answer: The reincarnated creature recalls its former life and experiences and retains the capabilities it had in its original form, except it exchanges its original race for the new one rolled/selected and changes its racial traits accordingly.

questions.question: In play, how long does it take to cast *reincarnate*, and what range do you need to be at to use it?
questions.answer: *Reincarnate* has a casting time of **1 hour** and a range of **Touch**.

questions.question: If I cast **Remove Curse** on a character who’s attuned to a **cursed magic item**, does the spell actually remove the item’s curse, and what happens to the attunement?
questions.answer: Remove Curse ends all curses affecting one touched creature or object, but if the target is a *cursed magic item* the item’s curse remains. Instead, the spell breaks the owner’s attunement to the item so it can be removed or discarded.

questions.question: During play, I need the basics for **Remove Curse**—what are its casting time, range, and duration?
questions.answer: **Remove Curse** has a **casting time of 1 action**, a **range of Touch**, and a **duration of Instantaneous**.

questions.question: In the middle of a session, we need to know if a **warlock** can cast **Remove Curse**—which classes get it, and what level/school is the spell?
questions.answer: **Remove Curse** is a *3rd-level abjuration* spell. The classes that can cast it are **Cleric, Paladin, Warlock,** and **Wizard**.

questions.question: If a creature is suffering from multiple curses at the same time, does casting **Remove Curse** end just one curse or all of them on that target?
questions.answer: Remove Curse ends **all curses affecting one creature or object**—so if the target has multiple curses, they all end when you cast it on that target.

questions.question: In combat, does **Remove Curse** require concentration, and what spell components does it use?
questions.answer: No—Remove Curse has an instantaneous duration, so it doesn’t require concentration. Its components are **V, S** (verbal and somatic only; no material component).

questions.question: When you cast Resilient Sphere on an unwilling creature, what saving throw does it make, and what (if anything) can pass through the sphere’s barrier?
questions.answer: An unwilling creature must make a Dexterity saving throw; on a failed save it is enclosed for the duration. Nothing—physical objects, energy, or other spell effects—can pass through the barrier in or out (though the creature inside can breathe).

questions.question: If a creature is trapped inside **Resilient Sphere**, how can it move the sphere on its turn, and what’s the maximum speed it can roll it?
questions.answer: An enclosed creature can use its **action** to push against the sphere’s walls and **roll the sphere at up to half the creature’s speed** (and other creatures can also pick up and move the globe).

questions.question: If a creature is trapped inside **Resilient Sphere** and you need to end it early, what spell can destroy the globe, and does that harm the creature or object inside?
questions.answer: A **disintegrate** spell targeting the globe destroys the sphere **without harming anything inside it**.

questions.question: When you cast **Resilient Sphere**, what’s the largest size creature or object it can enclose, and what’s the spell’s range?
questions.answer: It can enclose a **creature or object of Large size or smaller**, and the spell’s **range is 30 feet**.

questions.question: What material components do you need to cast **Resilient Sphere**?
questions.answer: It requires a hemispherical piece of clear crystal and a matching hemispherical piece of gum arabic (in addition to verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: When you cast Resistance, how long does the spell last, and what bonus does the target get to a saving throw?
questions.answer: Resistance lasts up to 1 minute. Once before the spell ends, the target can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to one saving throw of its choice (before or after the roll), then the spell ends.

questions.question: When a creature is under the effects of the Resistance cantrip, can it choose to roll the d4 after it makes the saving throw, and what happens to the spell once that d4 is used?
questions.answer: Yes. The target can roll the d4 before or after making the saving throw. After it uses the d4 on one saving throw, the spell ends.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast the Resistance cantrip?
questions.answer: Resistance requires V, S, and M components; the material component is a miniature cloak.

questions.question: If I want to cast the Resistance cantrip on an ally, what’s its casting time and range?
questions.answer: Resistance has a casting time of 1 action and a range of Touch.

questions.question: Which classes can cast the Resistance cantrip?
questions.answer: Resistance is available to Clerics and Druids.

questions.question: When you cast Resurrection, what material component is required, does the spell consume it, and what is the minimum value?
questions.answer: Resurrection requires a diamond worth at least 1,000 gp as a material component, and the spell consumes the diamond.

questions.question: After you cast **Resurrection**, what penalty does the revived creature suffer, and how does that penalty go away over time?
questions.answer: The resurrected creature takes a **−4 penalty to all attack rolls, saving throws, and ability checks**. Each time it finishes a **long rest**, the penalty is **reduced by 1** until it disappears.

questions.question: If you use Resurrection on a creature that’s been dead for one year or longer, what drawbacks does the spell impose on the caster afterward, and how long do they last?
questions.answer: Casting Resurrection on a creature dead for one year or longer taxes the caster: until the caster finishes a long rest, they can’t cast spells again, and they have disadvantage on all attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

questions.question: When you cast **Resurrection**, which conditions does it automatically remove from the dead creature (like poisons or diseases), and what harmful effects can still remain on the target after it returns to life?
questions.answer: Resurrection neutralizes any poisons and cures normal (nonmagical) diseases that were afflicting the creature when it died. It does not remove magical diseases, curses, and similar effects—if those aren’t removed before the spell is cast, they still afflict the creature when it returns to life.

questions.question: What are the restrictions on what kind of creature you can target with the **Resurrection** spell—specifically, how long it can have been dead and whether it can have died of old age or be undead?
questions.answer: Resurrection can target a dead creature that has been dead for no more than a century, that didn’t die of old age, and that isn’t undead (and its soul must be free and willing).

questions.question: When you cast Reverse Gravity, what is the size/shape of the affected area, and what kind of saving throw can a creature make to avoid being flung upward?
questions.answer: Reverse Gravity affects a 50-foot-radius, 100-foot-high cylinder centered on a point within 100 feet. A creature can make a Dexterity saving throw to grab onto a fixed object it can reach, avoiding the upward fall.

questions.question: If you cast Reverse Gravity in an area with a solid ceiling above, what happens when creatures or objects fall upward and hit that ceiling?
questions.answer: If a solid object such as a ceiling is encountered during the upward fall, the falling creatures and objects strike it just as they would during a normal downward fall.

questions.question: For the Reverse Gravity spell, what material components do you need to cast it?
questions.answer: It requires a lodestone and iron filings (as the material component, in addition to verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: When Reverse Gravity ends, what happens to the creatures and objects that were affected by the spell?
questions.answer: At the end of the spell’s duration, the affected objects and creatures fall back down.

questions.question: In combat, if you want to cast **Reverse Gravity**, what are the spell’s casting time and range?
questions.answer: Reverse Gravity has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **100 feet**.

questions.question: For the spell *Revivify*, what’s the time limit after a creature dies for it to work, and how many hit points does the creature return with?
questions.answer: You can target a creature that has died within the last minute, and it returns to life with 1 hit point.

questions.question: For the spell *Revivify*, what material component is required, what’s its value, and does the spell consume it?
questions.answer: *Revivify* requires diamonds worth 300 gp as its material component, and the spell consumes the diamonds.

questions.question: Can the spell Revivify bring back a creature that died of old age, or restore any missing body parts when it returns them to life?
questions.answer: No. Revivify can’t return to life a creature that has died of old age, and it can’t restore any missing body parts.

questions.question: For *Revivify* in 5e, what’s its casting time and range?
questions.answer: *Revivify* has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **Touch**.

questions.question: In 5e, what level spell is *Revivify*, what school is it, and which classes can cast it?
questions.answer: *Revivify* is a 3rd-level Conjuration spell. It’s available to Clerics and Paladins.

questions.question: When you cast Rope Trick, how many creatures can fit inside the extradimensional space, and can attacks or spells pass through the entrance?
questions.answer: The extradimensional space can hold up to eight Medium or smaller creatures, and attacks and spells can’t cross through the entrance into or out of the space.

questions.question: If you’re still inside a Rope Trick extradimensional space when the spell’s duration ends, what happens to you and any objects in there?
questions.answer: Anything inside the extradimensional space drops out when the spell ends.

questions.question: What material components do you need to cast Rope Trick?
questions.answer: Rope Trick requires powdered corn extract and a twisted loop of parchment (in addition to verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: When you cast Rope Trick and pull the rope up into the extradimensional space, what happens to the rope from the outside, and how (if at all) can creatures inside still see what’s happening outside?
questions.answer: Pulling the rope into the extradimensional space makes the rope disappear from view outside the space. Creatures inside can still see out as if through a 3-foot-by-5-foot window centered on the rope.

questions.question: During play, what are Rope Trick’s casting time, range, and duration?
questions.answer: Rope Trick has a casting time of 1 action, a range of Touch, and a duration of 1 hour.

questions.question: When you cast *Sacred Flame*, what saving throw does the target make, what damage type and die does it take on a failed save, and does cover help against it?
questions.answer: The target makes a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save it takes 1d8 radiant damage, and the target gains no benefit from cover for this saving throw.

questions.question: When you cast *Sacred Flame*, how does the spell’s damage scale as you gain levels (what damage dice does it deal at 1st, 5th, 11th, and 17th level)?
questions.answer: It deals 1d8 radiant damage at 1st level, increasing to 2d8 at 5th level, 3d8 at 11th level, and 4d8 at 17th level.

questions.question: When casting *Sacred Flame*, what’s its casting time, range, and components, and how long does the spell last?
questions.answer: *Sacred Flame* has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **60 feet**, components **V, S**, and a duration of **instantaneous**.

questions.question: For the spell *Sacred Flame*, what level of spell is it and what school of magic does it belong to?
questions.answer: *Sacred Flame* is an **evocation cantrip** (a 0-level spell in the school of Evocation).

questions.question: When you cast *Sacred Flame*, do you need line of sight—i.e., must the target be a creature you can see to be affected?
questions.answer: Yes. *Sacred Flame* targets “a creature that you can see within range,” so you must be able to see the target.

questions.question: For the *sanctuary* spell, what saving throw does a creature have to make before it can attack or target the warded creature with a harmful spell, and what happens if it fails?
questions.answer: Before it can target the warded creature with an attack or a harmful spell, it must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it must choose a new target or lose the attack or spell.

questions.question: What actions by the warded creature will cause the *sanctuary* spell to end early?
questions.answer: *Sanctuary* ends early if the warded creature makes an attack or casts a spell that affects an enemy creature (otherwise it lasts up to 1 minute).

questions.question: If you cast *sanctuary* on an ally, does it protect them from being harmed by area effects (for example, a *fireball* explosion that includes them)?
questions.answer: No. *Sanctuary* doesn’t protect the warded creature from area effects, such as the explosion of a *fireball*.

questions.question: When you cast *sanctuary*, what’s its casting time and range?
questions.answer: *Sanctuary* has a casting time of **1 bonus action** and a range of **30 feet**.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast the *sanctuary* spell?
questions.answer: *Sanctuary* requires a material component: **a small silver mirror** (along with verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: When you cast *Scorching Ray* using a higher-level spell slot, how does the spell scale—how many extra rays do you get per slot level above 2nd?
questions.answer: If you cast *Scorching Ray* with a 3rd-level or higher slot, you create **one additional ray for each slot level above 2nd**.

questions.question: When you cast *Scorching Ray*, how many separate attack rolls do you make, and how much damage does each ray deal on a hit?
questions.answer: You create three rays and make a separate ranged spell attack for each ray. On a hit, a ray deals 2d6 fire damage.

questions.question: When casting *Scorching Ray*, can you split the rays among multiple targets, and what’s the spell’s range?
questions.answer: Yes. You create three rays and can hurl them at one target or several (making a separate ranged spell attack for each ray). The spell’s range is 120 feet.

questions.question: What components are required to cast *Scorching Ray* (verbal, somatic, and/or material)?
questions.answer: *Scorching Ray* requires **verbal and somatic** components (**V, S**) and has **no material component**.

questions.question: Does *Scorching Ray* require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: No—*Scorching Ray* doesn’t require concentration. Its duration is instantaneous.

questions.question: When you cast *Scrying* on a creature and it fails its saving throw, where does the spell’s sensor appear relative to the target, and does it move with them?
questions.answer: On a failed save, *Scrying* creates an invisible sensor within 10 feet of the target, and the sensor moves with the target, remaining within 10 feet of it for the duration.

questions.question: If a creature succeeds on its saving throw against *Scrying*, how long do you have to wait before you can try to scry on that same creature again?
questions.answer: On a successful save, the target isn’t affected, and you can’t use *Scrying* against it again for 24 hours.

questions.question: When casting *Scrying*, how is the target’s Wisdom saving throw modified based on how well you know them and what kind of physical connection you have (e.g., secondhand knowledge, a picture, or a body part)?
questions.answer:
The target makes a Wisdom saving throw modified by both your familiarity and your physical connection:

**Knowledge & Save Modifier**
- Secondhand (you have heard of the target): **+5**
- Firsthand (you have met the target): **+0**
- Familiar (you know the target well): **−5**

**Connection & Save Modifier**
- Likeness or picture: **−2**
- Possession or garment: **−4**
- Body part, lock of hair, bit of nail, or the like: **−10**

questions.question: Can you cast *Scrying* to observe a creature on another plane of existence, or must the target be on the same plane as you?
questions.answer: The creature you choose must be on the same plane of existence as you; *Scrying* doesn’t let you observe a target on another plane.

questions.question: If the target of *Scrying* realizes you’re casting it on them, can they choose to fail the saving throw on purpose so you can observe them?
questions.answer: Yes. If the target knows you’re casting *scrying*, it can voluntarily fail its Wisdom saving throw if it wants to be observed.

questions.question: When you use *Secret Chest* to recall the hidden chest, what do you have to do, and where does the chest appear?
questions.answer: While the chest is on the Ethereal Plane, you use an action and touch the miniature replica to recall it; the chest then appears in an unoccupied space on the ground within 5 feet of you.

questions.question: With *secret chest*, when does the spell start having a chance to end on its own, what is that chance, and what happens if the effect ends while the larger chest is still on the Ethereal Plane?
questions.answer: After 60 days, there is a cumulative 5 percent chance per day that the spell’s effect ends. If the spell ends while the larger chest is on the Ethereal Plane, it is irretrievably lost.

questions.question: For the *Secret Chest* spell, what’s the maximum amount of stuff you can store in the chest, and can it include living creatures?
questions.answer: The chest can hold up to 12 cubic feet of **nonliving** material (a 3-foot by 2-foot by 2-foot chest), so it can’t be used to store living creatures.

questions.question: For the *Secret Chest* spell, what material components do you need, including the chest sizes and minimum gp values?
questions.answer: You need two material components: an exquisite full-size chest about 3 ft. by 2 ft. by 2 ft. made from rare materials worth at least 5,000 gp, and a Tiny replica made from the same materials worth at least 50 gp.

questions.question: Does the *Secret Chest* spell require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: No—*Secret Chest* doesn’t require concentration. Its duration is **Instantaneous**.

questions.question: When you cast **See Invisibility**, does it let you see into the Ethereal Plane, and how do creatures and objects there appear to you?
questions.answer: Yes. For the spell’s duration, you can see through the Ethereal, and ethereal creatures and objects appear ghostly translucent.

questions.question: For **See Invisibility**, how long does the spell last, and do you need to maintain concentration on it?
questions.answer: See Invisibility lasts **1 hour** and **does not require concentration** (it’s listed with Duration: 1 hour, with no concentration requirement).

questions.question: When casting **See Invisibility**, what components do you need, including the specific material component?
questions.answer: It requires verbal, somatic, and material components (V, S, M): a dash of talc and a small amount of silver powder.

questions.question: When you cast **See Invisibility**, what’s the spell’s casting time and range?
questions.answer: **Casting Time:** 1 action; **Range:** Self.

questions.question: Which classes can prepare or learn the **See Invisibility** spell?
questions.answer: Bard, Sorcerer, and Wizard.

questions.question: If a creature suspects someone is under the Seeming spell, what can it do on its turn to try to see through the disguise, and what check does it make against what DC?
questions.answer: It can use its action to inspect a target and make an Intelligence (Investigation) check against the caster’s spell save DC; on a success it becomes aware the target is disguised.

questions.question: When you cast *Seeming*, how many creatures can you disguise, what range do you need to be within to target them, and what save (if any) can an unwilling creature make to resist the spell?
questions.answer: *Seeming* lets you change the appearance of **any number of creatures you can see within 30 feet**. An unwilling target can resist by making a **Charisma saving throw**; on a success, it’s unaffected.

questions.question: With *Seeming*, can you make a target appear as a creature with a different body shape—like giving them extra limbs or changing their basic body type—and what specific limitation does the spell place on the disguise?
questions.answer: No. *Seeming* can make a creature look up to 1 foot shorter or taller and appear thin, fat, or in between, but you can’t change a target’s body type—you must choose a form with the same basic arrangement of limbs.

questions.question: If you cast *Seeming* and want to drop the disguises before the 8-hour duration ends, can you end the spell early—and what action does it take to do so?
questions.answer: Yes. *Seeming* lasts for its duration unless you use your action to dismiss it sooner, ending the disguises early.

questions.question: When you cast **Sending** to a creature on a different plane, what’s the chance the message won’t arrive, and how long can the message be?
questions.answer: If the target is on a different plane than you, there is a **5 percent** chance the message doesn’t arrive, and the message can be **twenty-five words or less**.

questions.question: When you cast **Sending**, can the target creature respond, and when does it get to do so?
questions.answer: Yes. The target can answer in a like manner immediately after it hears your message.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast the Sending spell?
questions.answer: Sending requires V, S, and M components; the material component is a short piece of fine copper wire.

questions.question: When you cast **Sending**, what minimum Intelligence score must a creature have to understand the meaning of your message?
questions.answer: The spell enables creatures with an Intelligence score of **at least 1** to understand the meaning of your message.

questions.question: In play, if you want to use **Sending** during combat, what are the spell’s casting time and duration?
questions.answer: Sending has a casting time of **1 action** and a duration of **1 round**.

questions.question: For the Sequester spell, what can cause the spell to end early besides being dispelled?
questions.answer: You can set a condition for it to end early, but that condition must occur or be visible within 1 mile of the target; additionally, the spell ends if the target takes any damage.

questions.question: When you cast **Sequester**, what material component do you need, and is it consumed (and for how much gp at minimum)?
questions.answer: It requires V, S, M with **a powder of diamond, emerald, ruby, and sapphire dust worth at least 5,000 gp**, and **the spell consumes the powder**.

questions.question: While Sequester is in effect, can the hidden target be found with divination magic (including scrying sensors), and what happens to a creature target in terms of time and aging?
questions.answer: The target becomes invisible and can’t be targeted by divination spells or perceived through scrying sensors created by divination spells. If the target is a creature, it enters suspended animation—time ceases to flow for it and it doesn’t grow older.

questions.question: When you cast **Sequester**, what’s the spell’s casting time and range, and what kind of target can you affect?
questions.answer: Sequester has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **Touch**. When you cast it and touch the target, you can affect **a willing creature or an object**.

questions.question: When you use Shapechange, what happens if your new form drops to 0 hit points—do you revert, and does any excess damage carry over to your normal form?
questions.answer: If you revert as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, you revert to your normal form and any excess damage carries over to your normal form. As long as the excess damage doesn’t reduce your normal form to 0 hit points, you aren’t knocked unconscious.

questions.question: When you cast Shapechange, what options do you have for your equipment when you transform, and does worn equipment still function normally?
questions.answer: When you transform with Shapechange, you choose whether your equipment falls to the ground, merges into the new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal (though the DM decides whether it’s practical for the new form to wear a given item); equipment that merges has no effect while merged.

questions.question: While Shapechange is active, can you use your action to switch into a different form mid-spell, and what happens to your current hit points if the new form’s max hp is higher than the form you’re in?
questions.answer: Yes. During the spell’s duration, you can use your action to assume a different form under the same restrictions; however, if the new form has more hit points than your current form, your hit points remain at their current value (they don’t increase to match the new form).

questions.question: When you cast **shapechange**, what limits does the spell place on what creature you can turn into (challenge rating and prohibited creature types/traits)?
questions.answer: You can assume the form of any creature you’ve seen before with a **challenge rating equal to your level or lower**, but the form **can’t be a construct or an undead**, and you transform into an average example of that creature **without any class levels or the Spellcasting trait**.

questions.question: For the **shapechange** spell, what material component do you need, what’s its minimum value, and what must you do with it before casting?
questions.answer: Shapechange requires a **jade circlet worth at least 1,500 gp**, and you **must place it on your head before you cast the spell**.

questions.question: When you cast **Shatter**, what size area does it affect, what saving throw does it require, and what damage does a creature take on a failed vs. successful save?
questions.answer: Shatter affects a **10-foot-radius sphere** centered on a point you choose within range. Creatures in the area make a **Constitution saving throw**. On a failed save, a creature takes **3d8 thunder damage**; on a successful save, it takes **half as much** damage.

questions.question: When you cast **Shatter**, do nonmagical objects in the area take damage, and which objects are excluded?
questions.answer: Yes. Any **nonmagical object** in the spell’s area **takes the damage** as well—**but only if it isn’t being worn or carried** (objects being worn or carried are excluded).

questions.question: When casting **Shatter**, what kinds of creatures roll the Constitution saving throw with disadvantage?
questions.answer: Any creature made of inorganic material—such as stone, crystal, or metal—has disadvantage on the Constitution saving throw against *Shatter*.

questions.question: For the Shield of Faith spell, what AC bonus does it grant the target, and what is the spell’s duration?
questions.answer: Shield of Faith grants the chosen creature a +2 bonus to AC for up to 10 minutes.

questions.question: For the Shield of Faith spell, what material component do you need to cast it?
questions.answer: It requires a material component of “a small parchment with a bit of holy text written on it.”

questions.question: When you cast Shield of Faith in combat, what’s its casting time and how far away can you target the creature?
questions.answer: Shield of Faith has a casting time of 1 bonus action, and you can target a creature within 60 feet.

questions.question: Which classes can cast the Shield of Faith spell (i.e., which spell lists include it)?
questions.answer: Shield of Faith is available to Clerics and Paladins.

questions.question: When you cast *Shield of Faith*, what visible magical effect appears around the creature you target?
questions.answer: A shimmering field appears and surrounds the chosen creature within range.

questions.question: When you cast *Shield* as a reaction, how long does the AC bonus last and what exact benefits does it give you against the triggering attack and *magic missile*?
questions.answer: Until the start of your next turn (1 round), you gain a +5 bonus to AC, including against the triggering attack, and you take no damage from *magic missile*.

questions.question: What components are required to cast the *shield* spell, and which classes have it on their spell list?
questions.answer: *Shield* has verbal and somatic components (V, S), and it’s on the Sorcerer and Wizard spell lists.

questions.question: Can you cast *shield* to protect an ally, or is it a self-only spell?
questions.answer: *Shield* has a range of **Self** and creates a barrier that protects **you**—it can’t be cast on another creature at range.

questions.question: Does the *shield* spell require concentration to maintain its effect?
questions.answer: No. *Shield* has a duration of 1 round and does not list concentration, so it doesn’t require concentration.

questions.question: What level and school of magic is the *shield* spell?
questions.answer: *Shield* is a 1st-level abjuration spell.

questions.question: When you cast **Shillelagh**, what melee weapon types can you target, and under what conditions does the spell end early before the 1-minute duration expires?
questions.answer: You can target a **club or quarterstaff** you are holding. The spell ends early if **you cast Shillelagh again** or if **you let go of the weapon**.

questions.question: When you cast **Shillelagh** on a club or quarterstaff you’re holding, what ability score can you use for the weapon’s melee attack and damage rolls, and what does the weapon’s damage die become for the duration?
questions.answer: For the duration, you can use your spellcasting ability instead of Strength for the melee attack and damage rolls with that weapon, and the weapon’s damage die becomes a d8.

questions.question: When casting **Shillelagh**, what is the casting time and what components (including the specific material components) are required?
questions.answer: **Casting Time:** 1 bonus action. **Components:** V, S, M (mistletoe, a shamrock leaf, and a club or quarterstaff).

questions.question: When you cast **Shillelagh**, does the affected club or quarterstaff become a magical weapon, and how long does that benefit last?
questions.answer: Yes. The club or quarterstaff you are holding becomes magical (if it isn’t already) for the spell’s duration of **1 minute** (until the spell ends).

questions.question: Does **Shillelagh** require concentration to keep the spell active?
questions.answer: No. Shillelagh’s duration is **1 minute** and it does **not** list concentration.

questions.question: When you hit a creature with *Shocking Grasp*, what happens to the target’s ability to take reactions, and how long does that effect last?
questions.answer: On a hit, the target can’t take reactions until the start of its next turn.

questions.question: With *Shocking Grasp*, when do you have advantage on the melee spell attack roll?
questions.answer: You have advantage on the attack roll if the target is wearing armor made of metal.

questions.question: How does *Shocking Grasp*’s damage scale as you level up (at 5th, 11th, and 17th level)?
questions.answer: The damage increases by 1d8 at higher levels: 2d8 at 5th level, 3d8 at 11th level, and 4d8 at 17th level (base damage is 1d8 lightning).

questions.question: What are *Shocking Grasp*’s casting time, range, components, and duration?
questions.answer: Casting Time: 1 action; Range: Touch; Components: V, S; Duration: Instantaneous.

questions.question: For *Shocking Grasp*, do you make an attack roll or force a saving throw, and what damage does it deal on a hit?
questions.answer: You make a **melee spell attack** against the target (no saving throw). On a hit, the target takes **1d8 lightning damage**.

questions.question: If I cast **Silence**, what’s the size of the area it affects, and what happens to creatures entirely inside it regarding thunder damage, hearing, and casting spells with verbal components?
questions.answer: Silence creates a **20-foot-radius sphere** centered on a point within range. Any creature or object entirely inside the sphere is **immune to thunder damage**, creatures are **deafened** while entirely inside it, and **casting a spell with a verbal component is impossible** there.

questions.question: Is **Silence** a ritual spell, and which classes can cast it?
questions.answer: Yes. *Silence* is a 2nd-level Illusion spell with the ritual tag, and it’s available to Bard, Cleric, Druid, Ranger, and Ritual Caster.

questions.question: In combat, if I want to drop **Silence** on an enemy caster, what are the spell’s casting time, range, and duration?
questions.answer: Silence has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **120 feet**, and a duration of **up to 10 minutes**.

questions.question: If an enemy suspects your **silent image**, what does it take for them to determine it’s an illusion—what kind of check do they make and what happens if they succeed?
questions.answer: A creature can use its **action** to examine the image and make an **Intelligence (Investigation) check** against your **spell save DC**. On a success, it determines the image is an illusion and can **see through** it (and physical interaction also reveals it because things pass through the image).

questions.question: For the *silent image* spell, what’s the maximum size of the illusion you can create, and does it include sound or other sensory effects?
questions.answer: You can create an image no larger than a 15-foot cube. The image is purely visual and isn’t accompanied by sound, smell, or other sensory effects.

questions.question: After casting *silent image*, can you move the illusion on later turns—what action does it take, and how far away can you move it?
questions.answer: Yes. You can use your action to cause the image to move to any spot within range (60 feet).

questions.question: When you cast **silent image**, what components do you need—does it require a material component, and if so what is it?
questions.answer: Silent image has components **V, S, M**, and its material component is **a bit of fleece**.

questions.question: When you cast *simulacrum*, what limitations does the duplicate have regarding leveling up and regaining spell slots?
questions.answer: The simulacrum can’t learn or become more powerful (it never increases its level or other abilities) and it can’t regain expended spell slots.

questions.question: If a simulacrum you created gets damaged, how can you repair it, and what does it cost per hit point restored?
questions.answer: You can repair a damaged simulacrum in an alchemical laboratory, using rare herbs and minerals worth 100 gp per hit point it regains.

questions.question: If I already have a simulacrum active and I cast *simulacrum* again, what happens to any existing duplicates I previously created with the spell?
questions.answer: If you cast *simulacrum* again, any currently active duplicates you created with this spell are instantly destroyed.

questions.question: When you cast *simulacrum*, does the duplicate take its turns on its own initiative, or does it act on your turn—and how do you command it?
questions.answer: The simulacrum is friendly to you and creatures you designate, and it obeys your spoken commands. In combat, it moves and acts in accordance with your wishes, acting on your turn.

questions.question: When casting *simulacrum*, what kinds of creatures can you duplicate, and how do the duplicate’s hit points and starting equipment compare to the original?
questions.answer: You can duplicate one beast or humanoid that stays within touch range for the entire 12-hour casting time. The simulacrum looks like the original but has half the creature’s hit point maximum and is created without any equipment (otherwise it uses the original’s statistics).

questions.question: If I cast **sleep** using a 3rd-level spell slot, how many d8 do I roll to determine the total hit points of creatures it can affect?
questions.answer: You roll **9d8** total (the base **5d8**, plus **2d8** for each slot level above 1st—so +4d8 at 3rd level).

questions.question: When you cast **Sleep**, how does the spell choose which creatures in the area are affected, and what events can end the unconsciousness early?
questions.answer: You roll 5d8 to get a pool of hit points the spell can affect. Creatures within 20 feet of a point you choose within 90 feet are affected in ascending order of their current hit points (ignoring unconscious creatures): starting with the lowest current HP, each creature is affected only if its current hit points are equal to or less than the remaining total, and you subtract each affected creature’s hit points from the total before moving to the next. Affected creatures fall unconscious until the spell ends, the sleeper takes damage, or someone uses an action to shake or slap the sleeper awake.

questions.question: When casting **Sleep**, what creatures are completely unaffected by the spell (regardless of their hit points)?
questions.answer: Undead and creatures that are immune to being charmed aren’t affected by Sleep.

questions.question: When casting **Sleep**, what’s the spell’s range, and how large is the area where creatures can be affected?
questions.answer: Sleep has a range of **90 feet**, and it can affect creatures **within 20 feet of a point you choose within range**.

questions.question: Does the **Sleep** spell require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: No—**Sleep** does not require concentration. Its duration is **1 minute**.

questions.question: For the Sleet Storm spell, what is the spell’s area (shape and dimensions), and what saving throws might a creature in the area have to make and for what effects?
questions.answer: Sleet Storm creates freezing rain and sleet in a 20‑foot‑tall cylinder with a 40‑foot radius, centered on a point you choose within 150 feet. A creature that enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a Dexterity saving throw; on a failed save it falls prone. In addition, any creature concentrating while in the area must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC or lose concentration.

questions.question: During combat, what effects does **Sleet Storm** have on visibility and movement in its area, and what happens to exposed flames there?
questions.answer: The spell’s area is **heavily obscured**, the ground is covered with slick ice that counts as **difficult terrain**, and **exposed flames in the area are doused**.

questions.question: In play, if I want to cast **Sleet Storm**, what are its casting time, range, and required components (including the material component)?
questions.answer: Sleet Storm has a **casting time of 1 action**, a **range of 150 feet**, and components **V, S, M**, with the material component being **a pinch of dust and a few drops of water**.

questions.question: In combat, when exactly does a creature affected by **Sleet Storm** have to roll its Dexterity saving throw, and what happens if it fails?
questions.answer: A creature must make the Dexterity saving throw when it enters the spell’s area for the first time on a turn or when it starts its turn there. On a failed save, it falls prone.

questions.question: If I’m picking spells for my character, which classes have **Sleet Storm** on their spell list, and what level is the spell?
questions.answer: **Sleet Storm** is a **3rd-level conjuration** spell. It’s available to **Cleric, Druid, Sorcerer, and Wizard**.

questions.question: When a creature affected by the *Slow* spell tries to cast a spell with a casting time of 1 action, what roll is required and what happens on a successful roll?
questions.answer: If an affected creature attempts to cast a spell with a casting time of 1 action, you roll a d20. On an 11 or higher, the spell doesn’t take effect until the creature’s next turn, and it must use its action on that turn to complete the spell; if it can’t, the spell is wasted.

questions.question: For the *slow* spell, how many creatures can you target, what’s the size/shape of the affected area, and what saving throw do affected creatures make to resist or end the spell?
questions.answer: *Slow* affects up to six creatures of your choice in a 40-foot cube within 120 feet. Each target makes a Wisdom saving throw to resist initially, and an affected creature repeats the Wisdom saving throw at the end of its turn, ending the spell’s effect on itself on a success.

questions.question: When a creature fails its save against *slow*, what combat restrictions and penalties does it suffer (speed, AC/saves, reactions, actions, and number of attacks)?
questions.answer: An affected creature’s speed is halved; it takes a −2 penalty to AC and to Dexterity saving throws; it can’t use reactions; on its turn it can use either an action or a bonus action (not both); and it can’t make more than one melee or ranged attack on its turn (regardless of abilities or magic items).

questions.question: In play, if you cast *Spare the Dying* on an ally at 0 hit points, what range do you need and what effect does the spell have on that creature?
questions.answer: Its range is **Touch**. You touch a living creature at 0 hit points, and it **becomes stable** (the spell has no effect on undead or constructs).

questions.question: If a PC tries to cast *Spare the Dying* on an undead creature or a construct at 0 hit points, does the spell stabilize it or have any effect?
questions.answer: No. *Spare the Dying* only works on a living creature at 0 hit points; it has no effect on undead or constructs.

questions.question: During combat, how long does it take to cast *Spare the Dying*, what components does it require, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: *Spare the Dying* has a casting time of 1 action, requires verbal and somatic components (V, S), and has an instantaneous duration.

questions.question: If a cleric player asks whether *Spare the Dying* is on their spell list, what class can cast it, and what level/school of spell is it?
questions.answer: *Spare the Dying* is a **cleric** spell. It’s a **necromancy cantrip**.

questions.question: For the Speak with Animals spell, is it a ritual, and what is its duration when cast?
questions.answer: Yes—Speak with Animals is a 1st-level divination spell that can be cast as a ritual, and it lasts for 10 minutes.

questions.question: When I cast *Speak with Animals*, what’s the spell’s casting time and range?
questions.answer: *Speak with Animals* has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **Self**.

questions.question: When you cast *Speak with Animals*, how far back can a beast describe things it has perceived to you (i.e., what’s the lookback window for its information)?
questions.answer: A beast can tell you about whatever it can perceive or has perceived **within the past day** (at minimum, information about nearby locations and monsters).

questions.question: When you cast *Speak with Dead*, how many questions can you ask the corpse before the spell ends, and what cooldown prevents you from targeting the same corpse again?
questions.answer: You can ask the corpse up to five questions. The spell fails if that corpse was the target of *Speak with Dead* within the last 10 days.

questions.question: When you cast *Speak with Dead*, is the corpse compelled to answer your questions truthfully, and when might it give false or unhelpful answers?
questions.answer: No. The corpse is under no compulsion to offer a truthful answer if you are hostile to it or it recognizes you as an enemy; its replies are usually brief, cryptic, or repetitive.

questions.question: When you cast *Speak with Dead*, does the spell bring the creature’s soul back—and can the corpse learn new information or understand anything that happened after it died?
questions.answer: No. *Speak with Dead* doesn’t return the creature’s soul to its body—only its animating spirit. Because of that, the corpse can’t learn new information, doesn’t comprehend anything that has happened since it died, and can’t speculate about future events.

questions.question: When casting *Speak with Dead*, can you target an undead creature, and what physical feature must the corpse still have for the spell to work?
questions.answer: No. The target must be a corpse (not undead), and it must still have a mouth.

questions.question: In combat, if you want to cast *Speak with Dead*, what are its casting time, range, and duration?
questions.answer: *Speak with Dead* has a casting time of **1 action**, a range of **10 feet**, and a duration of **10 minutes**.

questions.question: If a creature is restrained by the plants created by the *entangle* spell, can *speak with plants* make those plants release it?
questions.answer: Yes. *Speak with plants* “can cause the plants created by the *entangle* spell to release a restrained creature.”

questions.question: When you cast *speak with plants*, how far from you can the affected plants be, and how far back can you question them about events?
questions.answer: The spell affects plants within 30 feet of you, and you can question them about events in the area that happened within the past day.

questions.question: When you cast *speak with plants*, can you use it to change the terrain (make it difficult or remove difficult terrain), and how long does that terrain change last?
questions.answer: Yes. You can turn difficult terrain caused by plant growth into ordinary terrain, or turn ordinary terrain (where plants are present) into difficult terrain; the terrain change lasts for the spell’s duration (10 minutes).

questions.question: If you cast *speak with plants* in an area that includes a plant creature (like a shambling mound), does the spell let you magically influence/control it, or only communicate with it?
questions.answer: You can communicate with a plant creature in the area as if you shared a common language, but you gain no magical ability to influence it.

questions.question: With *speak with plants*, can you command plants to uproot themselves and physically move around, or are they limited to moving parts like branches and vines?
questions.answer: The spell doesn’t enable plants to uproot themselves and move about, but they can freely move branches, tendrils, and stalks.

questions.question: When you cast *Spider Climb* on a willing creature, can it climb walls/ceilings without using its hands, and what climbing speed does it gain?
questions.answer: Yes. Until the spell ends, the target can move up, down, and across vertical surfaces and upside down along ceilings while leaving its hands free, and it gains a climbing speed equal to its walking speed.

questions.question: For the *Spider Climb* spell, what are the casting time and range, and what material component do you need?
questions.answer: *Spider Climb* has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **Touch**. Its components are **V, S, M**, and the material component is **a drop of bitumen and a spider**.

questions.question: During play, if someone wants to cast *Spider Climb*, which character classes have it on their spell list?
questions.answer: In the SRD, *Spider Climb* is available to the Druid, Sorcerer, Warlock, and Wizard classes.

questions.question: Can you cast *Spider Climb* on an enemy, or does the target have to be willing?
questions.answer: The spell can only affect “one **willing** creature you touch,” so you can’t cast it on an unwilling target.

questions.question: In the middle of combat, how long does *Spider Climb* last once you cast it?
questions.answer: Its duration is **up to 1 hour**.

questions.question: For the Spike Growth spell, what area does it cover, and how much damage does a creature take for moving through it?
questions.answer: Spike Growth affects the ground in a 20-foot radius centered on a point within 150 feet. The area is difficult terrain, and a creature takes 2d4 piercing damage for every 5 feet it moves into or within the area.

questions.question: If a creature didn’t see *spike growth* being cast, how can it recognize the area as dangerous before entering, and what roll does it make?
questions.answer: The spiked ground is camouflaged to look natural. Any creature that doesn’t see the area when the spell is cast must make a Wisdom (Perception) check against your spell save DC to recognize the terrain as hazardous before entering it.

questions.question: For the *spirit guardians* spell, what saving throw does an affected creature make when it enters the area or starts its turn there, and what damage does it take on a failed vs. successful save?
questions.answer: The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save it takes 3d8 radiant damage if you are good or neutral, or 3d8 necrotic damage if you are evil; on a successful save it takes half as much damage.

questions.question: If you cast *spirit guardians* using a higher-level spell slot, how does its damage scale with the slot level?
questions.answer: When cast with a spell slot of 4th level or higher, *spirit guardians*’ damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 3rd.

questions.question: When you cast *spirit guardians*, how large is the area around you that the spirits affect, and what happens to a creature’s speed while it’s in that area?
questions.answer: The spirits flit around you out to 15 feet for the duration, and an affected creature’s speed is halved while it’s in the area.

questions.question: When you cast *spirit guardians*, can you keep certain creatures (like your allies) from being affected, and what’s the restriction on which creatures you can exclude?
questions.answer: Yes. When you cast the spell, you can designate any number of creatures you can see to be unaffected by *spirit guardians*.

questions.question: For the *spirit guardians* spell, what material component is required, and how do the spirits’ forms differ if the caster is good/neutral versus evil?
questions.answer: It requires a material component of **a holy symbol**. If the caster is **good or neutral**, the spirits appear **angelic or fey** (caster’s choice); if the caster is **evil**, they appear **fiendish**.

questions.question: When you cast *spiritual weapon*, what damage does the attack deal on a hit, and how does that damage scale if you upcast the spell?
questions.answer: On a hit, the weapon deals force damage equal to **1d8 + your spellcasting ability modifier**. If you cast *spiritual weapon* using a spell slot of **3rd level or higher**, the damage **increases by 1d8 for every two slot levels above 2nd**.

questions.question: After you cast *spiritual weapon*, what can you do with it on subsequent turns using your bonus action (including how far it can move and how close a target must be to attack)?
