questions.answer: On each of your turns, you can use a bonus action to move the spectral weapon up to 20 feet and repeat its melee spell attack against a creature within 5 feet of the weapon.

questions.question: Does *spiritual weapon* require concentration, and how long does the weapon last (including what ends it early)?
questions.answer: *Spiritual weapon* does not require concentration. Its duration is 1 minute; the spectral weapon lasts for the duration or until you cast *spiritual weapon* again (which ends the previous one).

questions.question: If I want to cast *spiritual weapon* in combat, how far away can I create it, what components does it require, and what’s the casting time?
questions.answer: *Spiritual weapon* has a range of **60 feet**, requires **verbal and somatic components (V, S)**, and has a casting time of **1 bonus action**.

questions.question: When you cast *spiritual weapon*, how do you resolve the hit—does it require an attack roll or a saving throw, and what kind of attack is it?
questions.answer: Casting *spiritual weapon* lets you make a **melee spell attack** against a creature within 5 feet of the weapon (it’s resolved with an attack roll, not a saving throw).

questions.question: For the Stinking Cloud spell, what saving throw does a creature make, when does it have to make it, and what happens on a failed save?
questions.answer: Each creature completely within the cloud at the start of its turn must make a Constitution saving throw against poison. On a failed save, the creature spends its action that turn retching and reeling.

questions.question: If Stinking Cloud is active, how quickly does wind disperse the cloud, and what wind speeds count as moderate vs. strong for this purpose?
questions.answer: A moderate wind (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses the cloud after 4 rounds, and a strong wind (at least 20 miles per hour) disperses it after 1 round.

questions.question: When you cast **Stinking Cloud**, what size and shape is the cloud’s area of effect, and what visibility condition does it impose inside that area?
questions.answer: Stinking Cloud creates a **20-foot-radius sphere** of gas centered on a point within range; the cloud **spreads around corners** and its area is **heavily obscured**.

questions.question: When you cast **Stinking Cloud**, can you place the cloud somewhere you can’t see around a corner—i.e., does the gas spread around corners—and what’s the spell’s range for choosing the point?
questions.answer: Yes. The cloud “spreads around corners,” and you center it on a point within **90 feet**.

questions.question: For **Stinking Cloud**, what kinds of creatures automatically succeed on the Constitution saving throw against the cloud’s poison effect?
questions.answer: Creatures that don’t need to breathe or that are immune to poison automatically succeed on the Constitution saving throw.

questions.question: When you cast **Stone Shape**, what’s the maximum size/thickness of stone you can reshape (including using it to cut a passage through a wall)?
questions.answer: You can affect a stone object of Medium size or smaller, or a section of stone no more than 5 feet in any dimension—so you can make a passage through a wall only if the wall is less than 5 feet thick.

questions.question: When you use **Stone Shape** to form a stone door or similar object, what’s the limit on the mechanical features you can create (like hinges and a latch)?
questions.answer: The shaped object can include **up to two hinges and a latch**, but **finer mechanical detail isn’t possible**.

questions.question: When casting **Stone Shape**, what material component do you need to provide (and what is it used for)?
questions.answer: Stone Shape requires a material component of **soft clay**, which must be **crudely worked into the desired shape for the stone object**.

questions.question: When you cast **Stone Shape**, what are its casting time and range?
questions.answer: Stone Shape has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **Touch**.

questions.question: Does the **Stone Shape** spell require concentration, and how long does its effect last once you cast it?
questions.answer: No—Stone Shape doesn’t require concentration. Its duration is **instantaneous**, so the stone is reshaped immediately and the change remains.

questions.question: When you cast *Stoneskin*, what types of damage does the target gain resistance to, and does it apply to magical weapons or only nonmagical attacks?
questions.answer: For the duration, the willing creature you touch has resistance to **nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage**—it does **not** apply to magical bludgeoning/piercing/slashing damage.

questions.question: When casting *Stoneskin*, what specific material component do you need, and is it consumed by the spell?
questions.answer: It requires diamond dust worth 100 gp as the material component, and the spell consumes the diamond dust.

questions.question: When you cast *Stoneskin*, what are its casting time and range?
questions.answer: *Stoneskin* has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **Touch**.

questions.question: Which classes have access to the *Stoneskin* spell?
questions.answer: *Stoneskin* is available to the Cleric, Druid, Paladin, Ranger, Sorcerer, and Wizard classes.

questions.question: Can you cast *Stoneskin* on an unwilling creature (like an enemy), or does the target have to be willing?
questions.answer: The target must be a willing creature you touch; you can’t cast *Stoneskin* on an unwilling target.

questions.question: For the druid spell *Storm of Vengeance*, what exactly happens on Round 3 (number of bolts/targets, saving throw, and damage)?
questions.answer: On Round 3, you call **six** bolts of lightning from the cloud to strike **six creatures or objects** of your choice beneath it (a creature or object can’t be struck by more than one bolt). Each struck creature makes a **Dexterity saving throw**, taking **10d6 lightning damage** on a failed save, or **half as much** on a successful one.

questions.question: In play, what circumstances can cause the *Suggestion* spell to end before its full duration?
questions.answer: Suggestion can end early if the suggested activity is completed sooner than the duration (it ends when the subject finishes what it was asked to do), if you or any of your companions damage the target, or if the suggestion is an obviously harmful act (e.g., telling it to stab itself), which ends the spell.

questions.question: When a caster uses the *Suggestion* spell on a creature, what kind of saving throw does the target make, and what happens on a failed save?
questions.answer: The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it pursues the suggested course of action to the best of its ability (potentially for the spell’s duration).

questions.question: What material components do you need to cast the *Suggestion* spell?
questions.answer: It requires a material component: a snake’s tongue and either a bit of honeycomb or a drop of sweet oil (in addition to verbal components).

questions.question: When casting *Suggestion*, what requirements must the target creature meet, and what kind of creatures are automatically immune?
questions.answer: The target must be a creature you can see within range that can hear and understand you. Creatures that can’t be charmed are immune to the spell’s effect.

questions.question: During a session, how far away can you target a creature with the *Suggestion* spell, and how long can the spell last if it isn’t ended early?
questions.answer: *Suggestion* has a range of 30 feet, and its duration is up to 8 hours.

questions.question: For the Sunbeam spell, what is the line’s size, what saving throw does it require, and what happens on a failed save?
questions.answer: Sunbeam fires a 5-foot-wide, 60-foot-long line. Each creature in the line makes a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 6d8 radiant damage and is blinded until your next turn.

questions.question: While you’re concentrating on *sunbeam*, what light does the mote in your hand shed (bright/dim radii), and does that light count as sunlight?
questions.answer: For the duration, a mote of brilliant radiance shines in your hand that sheds bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet, and this light is sunlight.

questions.question: When you cast **Sunbeam**, can you fire additional beams on later turns without recasting it—and if so, what action does it take, and which creature types have disadvantage on the saving throw?
questions.answer: Yes. Until the spell ends, you can create a new line of radiance **as your action on any turn**. **Undead and oozes** have disadvantage on the Constitution saving throw against the beam.

questions.question: For the **Sunbeam** spell, what material component do you need to provide?
questions.answer: Sunbeam requires a material component: **a magnifying glass** (along with verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: If a creature succeeds on its Constitution saving throw against **Sunbeam**, what effect does it suffer (damage and any blinding)?
questions.answer: On a successful save, the creature takes half of the spell’s radiant damage (half of 6d8) and isn’t blinded by the spell.

questions.question: For the spell *Sunburst*, what is the size of the area affected, what saving throw does it require, and what happens on a failed vs. successful save (damage and conditions)?
questions.answer: Sunburst creates brilliant sunlight in a 60-foot radius centered on a point within 150 feet. Each creature in the light must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 12d6 radiant damage and is blinded for 1 minute; on a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn’t blinded.

questions.question: When the Symbol spell is triggered, what size area does its effect cover, and which creatures are affected as the glyph activates and afterward?
questions.answer: Once triggered, the glyph fills a 60-foot-radius sphere (dim light) for 10 minutes. Each creature in the sphere when it activates is targeted, and so is any creature that enters the sphere for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there.

questions.question: If you cast **Symbol** inside a movable object like a book or treasure chest, what happens if that object gets carried away—how far can it be moved before the glyph breaks, and does it trigger when it breaks?
questions.answer: For a Symbol inscribed within an object, the object must remain in its place. If it is moved more than 10 feet from where you cast the spell, the glyph is broken and the spell ends without being triggered.

questions.question: If a party is searching an area for a **Symbol** glyph before it triggers, what kind of check is needed to spot the glyph, and what DC do you compare it against?
questions.answer: The glyph is nearly invisible; finding it requires an **Intelligence (Investigation) check** against the caster’s **spell save DC**.

questions.question: For the **Symbol** spell’s **Sleep** effect, what saving throw does each target make, how long are they unconscious on a failed save, and what can wake them up early?
questions.answer: Sleep: Each target makes a **Wisdom saving throw**. On a failed save it **falls unconscious for 10 minutes**. A creature wakes up early if it **takes damage** or if someone uses an **action to shake or slap it awake**.

questions.question: If you set a **Symbol** glyph to the **Death** option, what saving throw do affected creatures make, and how much necrotic damage do they take on a failed save versus a successful save?
questions.answer: With the **Death** option, each target makes a **Constitution saving throw**. On a failed save it takes **10d10 necrotic damage**; on a successful save it takes **half as much damage**.

questions.question: When you use the Telekinesis spell on a creature, what kind of check do you make to move it, how far can you move it on a success, and what condition does it suffer (and for how long)?
questions.answer: To move a creature with Telekinesis, you make an ability check using your spellcasting ability contested by the creature’s Strength check. If you win, you can move a Huge or smaller creature up to 30 feet in any direction (including upward, but not beyond the spell’s range), and the creature is restrained in your telekinetic grip until the end of your next turn.

questions.question: With the Telekinesis spell, what’s the maximum weight of an object you can move, and how does moving it differ if the object is unattended versus being worn or carried by a creature (including what check is used)?
questions.answer: Telekinesis lets you try to move an object weighing up to 1,000 pounds. If the object isn’t being worn or carried, you automatically move it up to 30 feet in any direction (not beyond the spell’s range). If it is worn or carried, you must make an ability check with your spellcasting ability contested by that creature’s Strength check; on a success, you pull the object away and can move it up to 30 feet (not beyond the spell’s range).

questions.question: While Telekinesis is active, can you use it to do fine object manipulation (like opening a door or retrieving an item), and what action does it take to do so?
questions.answer: Yes. Telekinesis lets you exert fine control on objects in your telekinetic grip—such as manipulating a simple tool, opening a door or container, stowing or retrieving an item from an open container, or pouring the contents from a vial—and you do this when you cast the spell and as your action each round for the duration.

questions.question: For the Telekinesis spell, what components do you need to cast it (verbal, somatic, and/or material)?
questions.answer: Telekinesis requires verbal and somatic components only (V, S).

questions.question: For the *telekinesis* spell, what’s its range and how long does it last?
questions.answer: *Telekinesis* has a range of 60 feet and lasts up to 10 minutes.

questions.question: For the Telepathic Bond spell, how far apart can the bonded creatures communicate telepathically, and can the link work across different planes of existence?
questions.answer: The bonded creatures can communicate telepathically over any distance, but the communication can’t extend to other planes of existence.

questions.question: When you cast Telepathic Bond, how many creatures can you include in the link, and what Intelligence score makes a creature unaffected by the spell?
questions.answer: You can link up to eight willing creatures within range, and creatures with an Intelligence score of 2 or less aren’t affected.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast Telepathic Bond?
questions.answer: Telepathic Bond requires a material component of pieces of eggshell from two different kinds of creatures.

questions.question: When you need to set up Telepathic Bond quickly in play, can you cast it as a ritual, and what’s its casting time?
questions.answer: Yes. Telepathic Bond is a ritual spell, and its casting time is 1 action.

questions.question: When you cast Telepathic Bond during combat, do you need to maintain concentration on it, and how long does the link last?
questions.answer: Telepathic Bond does not require concentration (it’s not listed as concentration); its duration is 1 hour.

questions.question: When using the Teleport spell to target an object instead of creatures, what size limit does the object have to meet, and can it be held or carried by an unwilling creature?
questions.answer: The object must be able to fit entirely inside a 10-foot cube, and it can’t be held or carried by an unwilling creature.

questions.question: When casting **Teleport**, if the d100 result is a **Mishap**, what damage does it deal and what does the DM do next to determine where you end up?
questions.answer: On a Mishap, the spell’s unpredictable magic causes each teleporting creature (or the target object) to take **3d10 force damage**, and the DM **rerolls on the table** to see where you wind up; multiple mishaps can occur, dealing damage each time.

questions.question: When you cast **Teleport** and the d100 result is **Off Target**, how do you determine how far from the destination you arrive and what direction you end up in?
questions.answer: On an **Off Target** result, you appear a random distance away from the destination in a random direction. The distance off target is **1d10 × 1d10 percent** of the distance that was to be traveled. The DM determines direction randomly by **rolling a d8** and designating **1 as north, 2 as northeast, 3 as east**, and so on around the compass.

questions.question: When using the Teleport spell, what qualifies as an “associated object” for the destination, and how recent does it need to be?
questions.answer: An “associated object” is an object you possess that was taken from the desired destination within the last six months (for example, a book from a wizard’s library, bed linen from a royal suite, or a chunk of marble from a lich’s secret tomb).

questions.question: When you cast **Teleport**, how many other creatures can you bring with you, and what are the requirements for selecting them (willingness, sight, and distance)?
questions.answer: You can teleport yourself and up to **eight willing creatures** of your choice that you **can see within range**—i.e., within **10 feet** of you.

questions.question: When you cast *Teleportation Circle*, how long does the portal stay open, and where does a creature arrive relative to the destination circle?
questions.answer: The portal remains open until the end of your next turn (the spell’s duration is 1 round). Any creature that enters it appears within 5 feet of the destination teleportation circle, or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied.

questions.question: When casting *Teleportation Circle*, what material component do you need, what’s its gp value, and is it consumed by the spell?
questions.answer: It requires rare chalks and inks infused with precious gems worth 50 gp, and the spell consumes them.

questions.question: If you want to create a permanent teleportation circle at a location, what do you have to do with the *Teleportation Circle* spell to make it permanent?
questions.answer: You can create a permanent teleportation circle by casting *Teleportation Circle* in the same location every day for one year (you don’t need to actually use the circle to teleport when casting it this way).

questions.question: With *Teleportation Circle*, how long do you need to study a teleportation circle’s sigil sequence to memorize it for future castings?
questions.answer: You can commit a new sigil sequence to memory after studying it for **1 minute**.

questions.question: When you cast *Teleportation Circle*, can you open a portal to a permanent teleportation circle on a different plane of existence, or does the destination have to be on the same plane as you?
questions.answer: The destination circle must be on the same plane of existence as you; you choose a permanent teleportation circle whose sigil sequence you know and that is on the same plane.

questions.question: If I cast **Thaumaturgy** multiple times, how many of its 1-minute effects can I have active at once, and how can I end one early?
questions.answer: You can have up to three of Thaumaturgy’s 1-minute effects active at a time if you cast it multiple times, and you can dismiss an active effect as an action.

questions.question: Can the **Thaumaturgy** cantrip force a **locked** door or window to open or slam shut, or does it only work on unlocked ones?
questions.answer: Thaumaturgy can only affect an **unlocked** door or window—you can instantaneously cause an **unlocked** door or window to fly open or slam shut.

questions.question: When I cast **Thaumaturgy** to create the “instantaneous sound” effect, can I choose where the sound originates, and does the sound persist for the spell’s 1-minute duration?
questions.answer: Yes—you can create an instantaneous sound that originates from a point of your choice within the spell’s range (30 feet). That sound is instantaneous and doesn’t last for the full 1-minute duration (the 1 minute applies to the other listed 1-minute effects).

questions.question: When I cast *Thaumaturgy* at the table, is it a verbal-only cantrip (no somatic/material components), and what’s its casting time?
questions.answer: *Thaumaturgy* has **components: V only** (no somatic or material components) and a **casting time of 1 action**.

questions.question: If I use **Thaumaturgy** to amplify my voice for an intimidation speech, how much louder does it get and how long does that effect last?
questions.answer: One Thaumaturgy option makes your voice boom up to three times as loud as normal, and it lasts for 1 minute.

questions.question: When you cast *thunderwave*, what area does it affect, what saving throw do creatures make, and what happens on a successful vs. failed save?
questions.answer: Thunderwave affects each creature in a 15-foot cube originating from you. Each creature in the area must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 2d8 thunder damage and is pushed 10 feet away from you; on a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn’t pushed.

questions.question: When you cast *thunderwave*, how far away can the spell’s thunderous boom be heard, and what happens to unsecured objects fully within the area?
questions.answer: The spell’s thunderous boom is audible out to 300 feet. Unsecured objects that are completely within the area of effect are automatically pushed 10 feet away from you.

questions.question: If you cast *thunderwave* using a 3rd-level spell slot, what damage dice does it deal on a failed save?
questions.answer: Thunderwave deals 2d8 thunder damage at 1st level, and it increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st. Using a 3rd-level slot, it deals **4d8 thunder damage** on a failed save.

questions.question: Does *thunderwave* require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: No—*thunderwave* does not require concentration. Its duration is **instantaneous**.

questions.question: Which classes have access to the *thunderwave* spell?
questions.answer: *Thunderwave* is available to the Bard, Cleric, Druid, Sorcerer, and Wizard classes.

questions.question: For the Time Stop spell, what causes the spell to end early before you finish your extra turns?
questions.answer: Time Stop ends early if any action you take during it (or any effect you create) affects a creature other than you or an object being worn or carried by someone else; it also ends if you move more than 1,000 feet from where you cast the spell.

questions.question: When you cast *time stop*, how many turns do you get to act before normal time resumes, and can you move and take actions normally during those turns?
questions.answer: You take **1d4 + 1 turns in a row**, and during those turns you **can use actions and move as normal**.

questions.question: For the *time stop* spell, what’s its casting time, what components are required, and what’s its duration?
questions.answer: *Time stop* has a casting time of **1 action**, requires **verbal (V) components only**, and its duration is **instantaneous**.

questions.question: Which character classes can cast *time stop* (SRD)?
questions.answer: In the SRD, *time stop* is available to Sorcerers and Wizards.

questions.question: When casting *time stop*, what is the spell’s range/targeting—can you cast it on another creature, or is it only on yourself?
questions.answer: *Time stop* has a range of **Self**—you cast it on yourself, briefly stopping time for everyone but you.

questions.question: When you cast **Tiny Hut**, can creatures inside the dome pass through it freely, and can spells or other magical effects be cast or extend through the dome?
questions.answer: Creatures and objects that were within the dome when you cast Tiny Hut can move through it freely, but all other creatures and objects are barred from passing through it. Spells and other magical effects can’t extend through the dome or be cast through it.

questions.question: For Leomund’s Tiny Hut, how many creatures can shelter inside with the caster, what size restriction applies, and what happens if the dome’s area includes a Large (or bigger) creature or more than that number of creatures?
questions.answer: Up to nine creatures of Medium size or smaller can fit inside the dome with you. The spell fails if its area includes a larger creature or more than nine creatures.

questions.question: When you cast *Leomund’s Tiny Hut*, can you change the lighting inside the dome, and how does visibility work through the dome (can people outside see in)?
questions.answer: Yes. Until the spell ends, the caster can command the interior to become dimly lit or dark. The dome is opaque from the outside (of any color you choose) but transparent from the inside—so creatures outside can’t see in, while creatures inside can see out.

questions.question: If the caster of *Tiny Hut* steps outside the dome after casting it, does the spell keep running, or does it end?
questions.answer: The spell ends if you leave its area (the dome remains only while you stay within it).

questions.question: When you’re trying to set up *Tiny Hut* during a short rest, what’s the spell’s casting time, and what material component does it require?
questions.answer: *Tiny Hut* has a casting time of **1 minute** and requires **V, S, M** components, with the material component being **a small crystal bead**.

questions.question: For the Tongues spell, what’s the range and duration, and what exactly does it let the target and nearby listeners understand?
questions.answer: Range: Touch. Duration: 1 hour. The creature you touch can understand any spoken language it hears, and when it speaks, any creature that knows at least one language and can hear the target understands what it says.

questions.question: When you cast *Tongues*, what’s the casting time, and what material component do you need?
questions.answer: Casting time is **1 action**, and it requires **V, M** with the material component **a small clay model of a ziggurat**.

questions.question: Which classes can cast the *Tongues* spell?
questions.answer: *Tongues* is available to these classes: Bard, Cleric, Sorcerer, Warlock, and Wizard.

questions.question: When you cast *Tongues*, do you have to concentrate on it to keep it active?
questions.answer: No. *Tongues* doesn’t require concentration; it simply lasts for 1 hour after you cast it.

questions.question: When you cast *Transport via Plants*, what are the size and type requirements for the origin plant, and how much movement does it cost a creature to enter the plant and exit from the destination?
questions.answer: The origin must be a **Large or larger inanimate plant** within range. For the spell’s duration, a creature can step into the origin plant and exit from the destination plant by using **5 feet of movement**.

questions.question: For *Transport via Plants*, do you have to be familiar with the destination plant, and can you use the spell to travel to a plant on another plane of existence?
questions.answer: You must have seen or touched the destination plant at least once, and the destination plant must be on the same plane of existence as the origin plant (though it can be at any distance on that plane).

questions.question: In play, what are the range and duration of the *Transport via Plants* spell?
questions.answer: *Transport via Plants* has a range of 10 feet and a duration of 1 round.

questions.question: When casting **Transport via Plants** at the table, what’s the spell’s casting time and what components (V/S/M) does it require?
questions.answer: It has a casting time of **1 action** and requires **verbal and somatic components only (V, S)**—no material components.

questions.question: When you cast *Transport via Plants*, can only the caster use the plant link, or can other creatures step through it as well?
questions.answer: For the spell’s duration, **any creature** can step into the target plant and exit from the destination plant (using 5 feet of movement).

questions.question: For the Tree Stride spell, how far away can your destination tree be, how much movement does it cost to enter and exit a tree, and how often can you use the tree-to-tree transport each round?
questions.answer: With Tree Stride, you can move from inside one tree to inside another tree of the same kind within 500 feet. It costs 5 feet of movement to enter a tree and another 5 feet of movement to appear within 5 feet of the destination tree. You can use this transportation ability once per round for the spell’s duration (up to 1 minute).

questions.question: With Tree Stride, if you enter a tree but have no movement left to complete the transport, where do you appear?
questions.answer: If you have no movement left, you appear within 5 feet of the tree you entered (instead of emerging by a destination tree).

questions.question: For the Tree Stride spell, what kinds of trees can you travel between (type/living/size requirements), and do you have to end your turn inside or outside a tree?
questions.answer: You can move only between living trees of the same kind, and both trees must be at least the same size as you. You must end each turn outside a tree.

questions.question: Does the Tree Stride spell require concentration, and what is its duration?
questions.answer: Tree Stride does not require concentration (its duration line is not marked as concentration). Its duration is up to 1 minute.

questions.question: If a player wants to cast *Tree Stride*, which classes have it on their spell list, and what components are required (does it need any material components)?
questions.answer: *Tree Stride* is available to Cleric, Druid, Paladin, and Ranger. It requires only verbal and somatic components (V, S) and has no material component.

questions.question: If I keep concentration on **true polymorph** for the full 1-hour duration, how long does the transformation last afterward, and what ends it?
questions.answer: If you concentrate on true polymorph for the full duration, the transformation lasts until it is dispelled (otherwise it ends when the duration ends, or earlier if the target drops to 0 hit points or dies).

questions.question: When you cast **true polymorph** on an unwilling creature, what saving throw does it make, and what happens if it succeeds?
questions.answer: An unwilling creature can make a **Wisdom saving throw**; on a success, it **isn't affected by the spell**.

questions.question: For the *true resurrection* spell, how long can the creature have been dead, and what kind of death can’t it undo?
questions.answer: The target must have been dead no longer than 200 years, and it can’t have died of old age (it can be restored only if its soul is free and willing).

questions.question: For the *true resurrection* spell, what material components are required, and does the spell consume them?
questions.answer: It requires a sprinkle of holy water and diamonds worth at least 25,000 gp, and the spell consumes the diamonds (and the listed material components are consumed as part of the casting).

questions.question: If the target’s body no longer exists when you cast *true resurrection*, what extra step do you have to take, and where does the creature reappear?
questions.answer: If the original body no longer exists, you must speak the creature’s name; it then appears in an unoccupied space you choose within 10 feet of you.

questions.question: When you cast *true resurrection*, what conditions or afflictions does it remove from the creature, and does it restore missing body parts?
questions.answer: The spell closes all wounds, neutralizes any poison, cures all diseases, and lifts any curses affecting the creature when it died, and it also replaces damaged or missing organs and limbs.

questions.question: What are the casting time and range of the *true resurrection* spell?
questions.answer: *True resurrection* has a casting time of **1 hour** and a range of **Touch**.

questions.question: When you cast *true seeing*, how far does the target’s enhanced vision extend (for truesight/seeing into the Ethereal Plane and noticing magically hidden secret doors)?
questions.answer: For the spell’s 1-hour duration, the willing creature you touch has truesight, notices secret doors hidden by magic, and can see into the Ethereal Plane, all out to 120 feet.

questions.question: When casting *true seeing*, what material component do you need (including cost), and is it consumed by the spell?
questions.answer: You need an ointment for the eyes worth 25 gp, made from mushroom powder, saffron, and fat, and the ointment is consumed by the spell.

questions.question: When you cast **true seeing**, what’s the spell’s casting time and what range do you need to be within of the target to cast it?
questions.answer: **Casting Time:** 1 action. **Range:** Touch (you must touch the willing creature).

questions.question: When you cast *true seeing*, how long does the effect last, and do you need to maintain concentration on it?
questions.answer: The spell lasts 1 hour, and it does not require concentration (its duration is simply “1 hour,” not “Concentration”).

questions.question: For the *true strike* cantrip, what do you gain on your next turn after casting it, and what condition has to be true for that benefit to apply?
questions.answer: On your next turn, you gain advantage on your first attack roll against the target you pointed at, provided the spell hasn’t ended.

questions.question: For the *true strike* cantrip, what are the casting time and range, and which spell components does it require?
questions.answer: Casting time is 1 action, range is 30 feet, and it requires only somatic components (S).

questions.question: Which character classes can learn or cast the *true strike* cantrip?
questions.answer: Bard, Sorcerer, Warlock, and Wizard.

questions.question: What is the duration of the *true strike* cantrip?
questions.answer: Its duration is **up to 1 round**.

questions.question: Is *true strike* a cantrip or a leveled spell, and what school of magic is it?
questions.answer: *True strike* is a **cantrip** in the **Divination** school.

questions.question: For the Unseen Servant spell, what happens if you command the servant to perform a task that would move it more than 60 feet away from you?
questions.answer: If you command the unseen servant to perform a task that would move it more than 60 feet away from you, the spell ends.

questions.question: Can an Unseen Servant make attacks or otherwise deal damage in combat, and what are its basic defenses (AC and hit points)?
questions.answer: No. The unseen servant can't attack. It has AC 10 and 1 hit point (and if it drops to 0 hit points, the spell ends).

questions.question: For *Unseen Servant*, what action do you use to issue commands in combat, and how far can the servant move when you do?
questions.answer: Once on each of your turns, you can use a **bonus action** to mentally command the unseen servant to **move up to 15 feet** and **interact with an object**.

questions.question: What components (including the specific material component) are required to cast *Unseen Servant*?
questions.answer: *Unseen Servant* requires verbal and somatic components, plus a material component: “a piece of string and a bit of wood” (V, S, M).

questions.question: When you cast *Unseen Servant*, is it a ritual, and what are its casting time and duration?
questions.answer: *Unseen Servant* is a 1st-level conjuration spell that can be cast as a ritual. Its casting time is 1 action, and its duration is 1 hour.

questions.question: For the Vampiric Touch spell, what happens on a hit with the melee spell attack—how much necrotic damage does it deal and how much does the caster heal—and can the caster make the attack again on later turns while the spell lasts?
questions.answer: On a hit, the target takes 3d6 necrotic damage, and the caster regains hit points equal to half the necrotic damage dealt. Until the spell ends, the caster can use an action on each of their turns to make the attack again.

questions.question: What components do you need to cast *Vampiric Touch*, and which classes can cast it?
questions.answer: *Vampiric Touch* requires verbal and somatic components (V, S), and it’s on the Warlock and Wizard spell lists.

questions.question: When you upcast *Vampiric Touch*, how does its damage scale with higher-level spell slots?
questions.answer: If you cast *Vampiric Touch* using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 3rd.

questions.question: For *Vampiric Touch*, what’s the spell’s range, and how close do you need to be to a target to use it?
questions.answer: The spell’s range is **Self**, and you make a **melee spell attack against a creature within your reach**.

questions.question: During combat, what’s the casting time for *Vampiric Touch*, and how long can it last at most?
questions.answer: *Vampiric Touch* has a casting time of 1 action, and its duration is up to 1 minute.

questions.question: When you cast *Vicious Mockery*, what saving throw does the target make, what damage type/die does it take on a failed save, and what attack-roll penalty applies?
questions.answer: The target makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save it takes 1d4 psychic damage and has disadvantage on the next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn.

questions.question: When casting *Vicious Mockery*, does the target have to understand your insults for the spell to work, and what must be true about the target for it to be affected?
questions.answer: No— the target doesn’t need to understand you. It just must be able to hear you to be affected by the spell.

questions.question: For the cantrip *Vicious Mockery*, at what character levels does its damage increase, and what does the damage become at each of those levels?
questions.answer: Its damage increases by 1d4 at 5th level (2d4), 11th level (3d4), and 17th level (4d4).

questions.question: For the spell *Vicious Mockery*, what are its casting time, range, and components?
questions.answer: *Vicious Mockery* has a casting time of 1 action, a range of 60 feet, and components of V (verbal only).

questions.question: When you cast *wall of fire*, what are the two possible shapes/sizes you can form it into, and what Dexterity save and damage does a creature take when the wall first appears?
questions.answer: You can shape it as either (1) a wall up to 60 feet long, 20 feet high, and 1 foot thick, or (2) a ringed wall up to 20 feet in diameter, 20 feet high, and 1 foot thick. When it appears, creatures in its area make a Dexterity saving throw, taking 5d8 fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful save.

questions.question: When you upcast **wall of fire**, how does its damage scale with higher-level spell slots?
questions.answer: If you cast *wall of fire* using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the spell’s damage increases by **1d8 for each slot level above 4th**.

questions.question: For *wall of fire*, when does a creature take the ongoing fire damage after the wall is created (e.g., ending its turn near it or moving through it), and how much damage is dealt?
questions.answer: One side of the wall (chosen by you when you cast the spell) deals **5d8 fire damage** to any creature that **ends its turn within 10 feet of that side or inside the wall**. A creature takes the **same 5d8 fire damage** when it **enters the wall for the first time on a turn** or **ends its turn there**. The other side of the wall deals **no damage**.

questions.question: When you cast **wall of fire**, does it deal damage on both sides of the wall, and how do you decide which side is the damaging side?
questions.answer: No. One side of the wall—chosen by you when you cast the spell—deals 5d8 fire damage (to creatures that end their turn within 10 feet of that side or inside the wall, and when a creature enters the wall for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there). The other side of the wall deals no damage.

questions.question: When casting *wall of fire*, what specific material component do you need to provide for the spell?
questions.answer: It requires a material component: **a small piece of phosphorus** (along with verbal and somatic components).

questions.question: If I cast *Wall of Force* and it appears intersecting a creature's space, what happens to that creature, and can the wall be removed by *dispel magic* or damaged normally?
questions.answer: If the wall cuts through a creature’s space when it appears, the creature is pushed to one side of the wall (your choice which side). The wall is immune to all damage and can’t be dispelled by *dispel magic* (though *disintegrate* destroys it instantly).

questions.question: When you cast *wall of force*, what shapes can you form it into, and what are the maximum dimensions for each option?
questions.answer: You can form the wall into either (1) a hemispherical dome or a sphere with a radius of up to 10 feet, or (2) a flat surface made up of ten contiguous 10-foot-by-10-foot panels.

questions.question: Does *wall of force* stop creatures from bypassing it via the Ethereal Plane (for example, using ethereal travel), or can they go around it that way?
questions.answer: *Wall of force* extends into the Ethereal Plane, blocking ethereal travel through the wall.

questions.question: What material component do you need to cast *wall of force*?
questions.answer: It requires a material component of "a pinch of powder made by crushing a clear gemstone."

questions.question: When you cast *wall of force*, what are the spell’s casting time and range?
questions.answer: *Wall of force* has a casting time of **1 action** and a range of **120 feet**.

questions.question: For the *wall of ice* spell, what saving throws are involved and how much cold damage does a creature take on a failed save when the wall appears versus when it moves through the lingering frigid air?
questions.answer: When the wall appears and cuts through a creature’s space, the creature must make a **Dexterity saving throw**; on a failed save it takes **10d6 cold damage** (half on a success). After a 10-foot section is destroyed, it leaves frigid air; a creature moving through that frigid air for the first time on a turn must make a **Constitution saving throw**; on a failed save it takes **5d6 cold damage** (half on a success).

questions.question: For *wall of ice*, what are the wall’s AC and hit points per 10-foot section, and what happens when a 10-foot section is reduced to 0 hit points?
questions.answer: The wall has AC 12 and 30 hit points per 10-foot section. When a 10-foot section is reduced to 0 hit points, that section is destroyed and it leaves behind a sheet of frigid air in the space the wall occupied.

questions.question: When you cast *wall of ice*, what shapes can you form the wall into, and what are the maximum size/coverage limits for each option?
questions.answer: You can form the wall into either (1) a hemispherical dome or a sphere with a radius of up to 10 feet, or (2) a flat surface made up of ten contiguous 10-foot-square panels (each panel must be contiguous with another).

questions.question: For *wall of stone*, what happens if you maintain concentration for the spell’s full duration—does the wall become permanent, and can it be dispelled?
questions.answer: If you maintain your concentration for the spell’s whole duration, the wall becomes permanent and can’t be dispelled. Otherwise, it disappears when the spell ends.

questions.question: If a creature wants to break through a *wall of stone*, what AC does each panel have, and how many hit points does it have based on the wall’s thickness?
questions.answer: Each panel has **AC 15** and **30 hit points per inch of thickness** (so a standard 6-inch-thick panel has 180 hp; the alternative 3-inch-thick panel has 90 hp).

questions.question: When you cast *wall of stone* in a way that would completely surround a creature, what saving throw does it make, and what can it do on a successful save?
questions.answer: If a creature would be surrounded on all sides by the wall (or by the wall and another solid surface), it can make a Dexterity saving throw. On a success, it can use its reaction to move up to its speed so it is no longer enclosed by the wall.

questions.question: When using *wall of stone* to create a bridge or ramp, what do you have to do if you try to make a span longer than 20 feet?
questions.answer: If you create a span greater than 20 feet in length, you must halve the size of each panel to create supports.

questions.question: When casting *wall of stone*, what material component do you need to provide (in addition to verbal and somatic components)?
questions.answer: It requires V, S, M, with the material component being **a small block of granite**.

questions.question: For the Wall of Thorns spell, what saving throw do creatures make when the wall appears, and how much damage do they take on a failed vs. successful save?
questions.answer: When the wall appears, each creature in its area makes a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save it takes 7d8 piercing damage; on a successful save it takes half as much damage.

questions.question: For the *Warding Bond* spell, what benefits does the warded creature gain while it stays within 60 feet of the caster, and what happens to the caster when the target takes damage?
questions.answer: While the target is within 60 feet of you, it gains a +1 bonus to AC and saving throws and has resistance to all damage. Each time the target takes damage, you take the same amount of damage.

questions.question: During play, what conditions cause the *Warding Bond* spell to end, and can the caster end it early without dropping to 0 hit points?
questions.answer: *Warding Bond* ends if the caster drops to 0 hit points, if the caster and target become separated by more than 60 feet, or if the spell is cast again on either of the connected creatures. The caster can also dismiss the spell as an action.

questions.question: When casting *Warding Bond* in play, what material component is required, what minimum value must it have, and who has to wear it for the spell to function?
questions.answer: It requires a pair of platinum rings worth at least 50 gp each, and both you and the target must wear the rings for the duration.

questions.question: For the Water Breathing spell, how many creatures can you affect at once, and what’s the spell’s range?
questions.answer: Water Breathing can affect up to ten willing creatures you can see within range, and it has a range of 30 feet.

questions.question: When you cast *Water Breathing*, how long does the spell last, and can the affected creatures still breathe normally in addition to breathing underwater?
questions.answer: The spell lasts **24 hours**, and affected creatures **retain their normal breathing pattern** (so they can still breathe normally while also being able to breathe underwater).

questions.question: When casting *Water Breathing*, what components do you need, and what is the specific material component?
questions.answer: It requires verbal, somatic, and material components (V, S, M). The material component is a short piece of reed or straw.

questions.question: For *Water Breathing*, can you cast it as a ritual, and what’s its normal casting time?
questions.answer: Yes—*Water Breathing* is a 3rd-level transmutation spell with the ritual tag, and its normal casting time is 1 action.

questions.question: Does the *Water Breathing* spell require concentration to maintain, or does it last its full duration without concentration?
questions.answer: *Water Breathing* does **not** require concentration; its duration is **24 hours**, so it lasts for the full 24 hours once cast.

questions.question: When you cast Water Walk on a creature that’s submerged in a liquid, how quickly does the spell bring them up to the surface?
questions.answer: If you target a creature submerged in a liquid, Water Walk carries the target to the surface at a rate of 60 feet per round.

questions.question: When you cast **Water Walk**, how many creatures can you grant the effect to, and what are the targeting requirements (willingness/visibility/range)?
questions.answer: Water Walk can affect **up to ten willing creatures** that **you can see within 30 feet** (within the spell’s range).

questions.question: If a character casts **Water Walk** to cross molten lava, does the spell prevent them from taking damage from the lava?
questions.answer: No. Water Walk lets creatures move across the surface of molten lava as if it were harmless solid ground, but creatures crossing molten lava can still take damage from the heat.

questions.question: What types of surfaces can the Water Walk spell let creatures move across, and how does it treat those surfaces while the spell lasts?
questions.answer: Water Walk lets affected creatures move across **any liquid surface**—such as **water, acid, mud, snow, quicksand, or lava**—as if it were **harmless solid ground** (though crossing molten lava can still deal damage from the heat).

questions.question: Does the **Water Walk** spell require concentration, and how long does it last?
questions.answer: Water Walk does **not** require concentration (its duration is simply listed as **1 hour**), and it lasts **1 hour**.

questions.question: For the *Web* spell, what saving throw does a creature make when it starts its turn in the webs or enters them, and what happens on a failed save?
questions.answer: A creature must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, it is restrained as long as it remains in the webs or until it breaks free.

questions.question: If part of a **Web** spell area catches fire, how quickly does a 5-foot cube of webs burn away, and what damage does it deal (and to whom)?
questions.answer: Any 5-foot cube of webs exposed to fire burns away in 1 round, dealing 2d4 fire damage to any creature that starts its turn in the fire.

questions.question: For the *web* spell, what happens if you conjure the webs without anchoring them between solid masses (or layering them across a floor/wall/ceiling), and when does the spell end in that case?
questions.answer: If the webs aren’t anchored between two solid masses (like walls or trees) or layered across a floor, wall, or ceiling, the conjured web collapses on itself, and the spell ends at the start of your next turn.

questions.question: For the *Weird* spell, what kind of saving throw do affected creatures make, what area does it affect, and what happens to a creature that fails the initial save on subsequent turns?
questions.answer: Creatures in a 30-foot-radius sphere centered on a point you choose within 120 feet must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed initial save, a creature becomes frightened for up to 1 minute; at the start of each of its turns while frightened it must make another Wisdom save or take 4d10 psychic damage, and a successful save ends the spell for that creature.

questions.question: If a creature is flying in Wind Walk cloud form when the spell ends, how does it come down—what’s the descent rate and what happens if it still hasn’t reached the ground after 1 minute?
questions.answer: When Wind Walk ends on a creature that’s in cloud form and flying, it descends 60 feet per round for 1 minute until it lands safely. If it can’t land after that 1 minute, it falls the remaining distance.

questions.question: While a creature is in Wind Walk's cloud form, what actions is it allowed to take, and what happens mechanically when it reverts to its normal form (including how long it takes)?
questions.answer: In cloud form, the only actions a creature can take are the Dash action or to revert to its normal form. Reverting takes 1 minute, and during that time the creature is incapacitated and can’t move.

questions.question: When casting *Wind Walk*, how many creatures can you bring along, and how close do they need to be to you when you cast it?
questions.answer: You can affect yourself and up to ten willing creatures you can see within 30 feet (the spell’s range).

questions.question: When you cast *Wind Walk*, what material components do you need to provide?
questions.answer: The material components are fire and holy water.

questions.question: When a creature is affected by *Wind Walk* and is in its cloud form, what flying speed does it have, and what kind of damage resistance does it gain?
questions.answer: In cloud form, the creature has a flying speed of 300 feet and has resistance to damage from nonmagical weapons.

questions.question: When you cast *Wind Wall*, what saving throw does a creature in the wall’s area make when the wall appears, and how much damage does it take on a failed save (and on a successful one)?
questions.answer: When the wall appears, each creature in its area must make a Strength saving throw. It takes 3d8 bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

questions.question: If a creature casts *Wind Wall*, what happens to arrows, bolts, and other ordinary projectiles fired at targets on the far side of the wall—and are boulders hurled by giants or siege engines affected the same way?
questions.answer: Arrows, bolts, and other ordinary projectiles launched at targets behind the wind wall are deflected upward and automatically miss. Boulders hurled by giants or siege engines (and similar large projectiles) are unaffected.

questions.question: When you cast *Wind Wall*, how big can you make the wall (maximum length, height, and thickness), and what restriction is there on how you can shape it?
questions.answer: You can make the wall up to 50 feet long, 15 feet high, and 1 foot thick. You can shape it however you like as long as it forms one continuous path along the ground.

questions.question: When you cast *Wind Wall*, how does the wall interact with fog, smoke, and other gases—and can a creature in gaseous form move through the wall?
questions.answer: The wall’s strong wind keeps fog, smoke, and other gases at bay, and creatures in gaseous form can’t pass through it.

questions.question: When *Wind Wall* is up, can Small (or smaller) flying creatures or objects pass through it, and what happens to loose, lightweight materials that get brought into the wall?
questions.answer: No—Small or smaller flying creatures or objects can’t pass through the wall. Any loose, lightweight materials brought into the wall are blown upward (they fly upward).

questions.question: When you cast **wish** for an effect other than duplicating another spell, what damage do you take from casting spells afterward until you finish a long rest, and can that damage be reduced or prevented?
questions.answer: After enduring the stress of using wish for something other than duplicating a spell, each time you cast a spell until you finish a long rest you take **1d10 necrotic damage per level of that spell**, and **this damage can’t be reduced or prevented in any way**.

questions.question: If I use **wish** to undo a recent event, how far back can I force a reroll, and can I give that reroll advantage/disadvantage and choose between the new result and the original?
questions.answer: Wish can undo a single recent event by forcing a reroll of any roll made within the last round (including your last turn). You can force that reroll to be made with advantage or disadvantage, and you can choose whether to use the reroll or the original roll.

questions.question: When you use *wish* to create a nonmagical object, what are the limits on its value and size, and where can it appear?
questions.answer: Using *wish* this way, you can create one object worth up to 25,000 gp that isn’t a magic item. The object can be no more than 300 feet in any dimension, and it appears on the ground in an unoccupied space you can see.

questions.question: If I use **wish** to make the party immune to a specific spell or magical effect, how many creatures can I target, and how long does that immunity last?
questions.answer: You can grant **up to ten creatures you can see** immunity to **a single spell or other magical effect**, and that immunity lasts **8 hours**.

questions.question: When you cast *wish* to simply duplicate another spell, what’s the highest spell level you can duplicate, and do you have to meet that spell’s normal requirements (like costly material components)?
questions.answer: Using *wish*’s basic function, you can duplicate any other spell of 8th level or lower, and you don’t need to meet any of that spell’s requirements, including costly components—the duplicated spell simply takes effect.

questions.question: When casting *word of recall*, how many creatures can you teleport with you, what range do they need to be within, and what condition must be met for the spell to work at all?
questions.answer: You can teleport yourself and up to five willing creatures within 5 feet of you. The spell only works if you have previously designated a sanctuary by casting the spell within a location dedicated to or strongly linked to your deity; if you haven’t prepared a sanctuary (or the location isn’t dedicated to your deity when designating it), the spell has no effect.

questions.question: For *zone of truth*, what saving throw does a creature make when it enters the area or starts its turn there, and what happens on a failed save?
questions.answer: A creature must make a **Charisma saving throw** when it enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there. On a failed save, the creature **can’t speak a deliberate lie while within the spell’s radius**.
